status_message:
Reporting by Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Read more in tomorrow's Navajo Times.

Rickie Fowler's spot on the Olympic team has put him in an elite class of Native Olympians alongside athletes like Jim Thorpe and Billy Mills. 
Fowler, 27, is the No. 8 ranked golfer in the world and is a member of the 2016 U.S. Olympic Men's Golf Team in the Olympic games in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
It also happens to be golf's return to the Olympics after it was absent for 112 years. 
In a past interview with the Times, Fowler shared that his mother, Lynne Fowler, was half Navajo and Japanese and his father was Caucasian. He talked about his Navajo grandmother Jeanie (Yellowhair) Tanaka and how she educated him about his Diné roots, and how he used to visit and spent time in Tuba City, Arizona. 
He started golfing at about three years old; first having learned with his grandfather and eventually growing a deep love for the sport. 
Fowler will tee off Thursday, Aug. 11, at 7:58 a.m. MST and Friday at 6:03 a.m. MST. Viewers can tune in on the Golf Channel.

status_message:
Press release and photo from Office of the President and Vice President

For additional information pick up the Navajo Times Thursday

WINDOW ROCK -- President Russell Begaye and Vice President Jonathan Nez signed a Declaration of Emergency on Sunday, Aug. 7, ordering the heads of all Navajo Nation Divisions and Departments to immediately respond to those communities impacted by the heavy rainfall caused by the recent monsoon storms.
The declaration also applies to applicable Chapter Service Coordinators and orders all aforementioned heads and directors to coordinate response to areas impacted by the rainfall.
On Friday, Aug. 5, the community of Shiprock was impacted by flash floods. The flash floods destroyed several homes, roadways and also affected livestock.
"I traveled to Shiprock on Saturday to assess the damage to the community. Roads had been washed out and homes had been destroyed," President Begaye said. "Although we are thankful for the monsoon rains, at this time we see that it's necessary to implement a declaration to assist those that are currently displaced and are in need of food, clothing or shelter."
Many residents affected by the rainfall were relocated to the Shiprock Chapter House where the Red Cross was set up to assist families.
"Many of our community members have been severely impacted by the recent monsoon rainfalls where their homes and property have been damaged or destroyed," Vice President Nez said. "We are asking all departments and divisions to assist in responding to affected communities."
Because many have been negatively impacted in ways that have affected their livelihood, the Office of the President and Vice President implemented this Declaration of Emergency to direct resources in assisting these communities.
link_name: Timeline Photos

Press release Office of the President and Vice President

For additional information pick up the Navajo Times Thursday

WINDOW ROCK -- President Russell Begaye and Vice President Jonathan Nez signed a Declaration of Emergency on Sunday, Aug. 7, ordering the heads of all Navajo Nation Divisions and Departments to immediately respond to those communities impacted by the heavy rainfall caused by the recent monsoon storms.

The declaration also applies to applicable Chapter Service Coordinators and orders all aforementioned heads and directors to coordinate response to areas impacted by the rainfall. 

On Friday, Aug. 5, the community of Shiprock was impacted by flash floods. The flash floods destroyed several homes, roadways and also affected livestock. 

"I traveled to Shiprock on Saturday to assess the damage to the community.  Roads had been washed out and homes had been destroyed," President Begaye said. "Although we are thankful for the monsoon rains, at this time we see that it's necessary to implement a declaration to assist those that are currently displaced and are in need of food, clothing or shelter."

Many residents affected by the rainfall were relocated to the Shiprock Chapter House where the Red Cross was set up to assist families.

"Many of our community members have been severely impacted by the recent monsoon rainfalls where their homes and property have been damaged or destroyed," Vice President Nez said. "We are asking all departments and divisions to assist in responding to affected communities."

Because many have been negatively impacted in ways that have affected their livelihood, the Office of the President and Vice President implemented this Declaration of Emergency to direct resources in assisting these communities.

Updates and photos by Alysa Landry. 

Photos of floodwater damage, after heavy rains in Shiprock Chapter early Saturday morning. 

The chapter declared a state of emergency after floodwaters displaced 27 people. 

The Shiprock Chapter is seeking donations of water, food items, bedding, linens, hygiene and toiletry items, toys, school supplies and clothing. Drop off donations anytime at the chapter house.
link_name: Photos from Navajo Times's post

status_message:
by Alysa Landry

The Shiprock Chapter early Saturday morning declared a state of emergency after floodwaters displaced 27 people and washed away entire homes, farms and livestock.

The flood occurred in the Salt Wash area, about four miles northwest of Shiprock. It began with heavy rains late Friday night, said Chapter President Duane "Chili" Yazzie. By midnight, about 30 residents had sought refuge at the chapter house, where they slept on cots.

Only minor injuries were reported, but at least two families lost everything they had, Yazzie said. 

"At least 10 families had to leave their homes because of the water," he said. "They came with stories about rising water, standing in their homes with water at waist level, water rushing in with the sound of thunder."

The Shiprock Chapter is seeking donations of water, food items, bedding, linens, hygiene and toiletry items, toys, school supplies and clothing. Drop off donations anytime at the chapter house.
Christopher S. Pineo with international endurance athlete and local Navajo sponsored skateboarder Cecely Todacheenie.

status_message:
Gallup PD needs help ID'ing remains 

By Christopher S. Pineo
Navajo Times
 

GALLUP –- Police need help to identify the remains of a man they say appears to be a Native American.
"We're going to need the media to see if anyone is missing a loved one," Lt. Rosanne Morrissette of the Gallup Police Department, said.
The victim was found wearing black pants with a black belt, black lace-up shoes, white socks, and a long-sleeved white shirt with a blue checker pattern on it. Police said the victim had long hair, but decomposition had made identification difficult.
Police said the body was found just north of Four Corners Welding between Route 66 and I-40 in a ditch near the train tracks.
"He'd been there for a few weeks," Morrissette said.
A male led the police to the location, where he said he had seen the body some days earlier.
Police said they do not suspect foul play, but an autopsy at the Office of the Medical Investigator in Albuquerque should determine the cause of death.

Mexican Springs man killed

Navajo Times 

    GALLUP - The Mexican springs Chapter is hosting a meeting at 6 p.m. tonight for the family of Edison Morgan who was killed over the past weekend.
    Details of the killing were not been released by either the Navajo Nation Police or the the FBI on Monday but officials of the Mexican Springs Chapter said that is one of the purposes of the meeting, besides getting donations to help defray funeral expenses.
    The McKinley County sheriff's Office said a suspect, who is from the Mexican Springs area, is in custody. The suspect barricaded himself inside his house but police were able to get him out, according to a sheriff's report.
    Funeral arrangements are pending.

status_message:
DOJ to investigate shooting of Loreal Tsingine

Navajo Times

GALLUP - Navajo Nation Speaker of the Council LoRenzo Bates announced in a statement on Saturday that the U.S. Department of Justice said it would begin an investigation into the fatal shooting of Loreal Tsingine during a confrontation with Winslow police officer Austin Shipley. 
On Wednesday, Shipley's body cam video of his March 27 confrontation with Tsingine was released. 
Shipley responded to a woman shoplifting from a Circle K convenience store.
In Shipley's body cam video, he is seen struggling to detain Tsingine. 
The video shows Tsingine holding a pair of scissors in her left hand as she continues to scuffle with Shipley. At which time, Tsingine falls and he backs away. Tsingine stands up and starts walking toward him. 
As Tsingine continues to walk toward Shipley when he draws his pistol. He fires his weapon at her. 
Their confrontation lasts less than 30 seconds. 
The Council was hopeful the DOJ investigation would bring justice for the Tsingine family, the statement reads. 
Bates said the Council was elated the DOJ made a decision to review the investigation into the shooting death of Tsingine at the hands of Officer Shipley. 
"The council wholeheartedly supports the decision of the DOJ.... The Office of the President and Vice President, (and) the Navajo Nation Human Rights Commission have all sought the intervention of the DOJ," Bates said in the statement.

status_message:
Protest held in response to Winslow police officer fatal shooting of Loreal Tsingine

By Donovan Quintero
Navajo Times

WINSLOW - Like he did in the 1960s fighting for the rights of Native people, Shiprock Chapter President Duane "Chili" Yazzie walked in protest over the Easter Sunday shooting that led to death of Loreal Tsingine during confrontation with Winslow police officer Austin Shipley. 
Yazzie said the similarities between what he fought for then and now were not too different. 
"We've seen this too often, Yazzie said. "We've experienced this in Farmington and, more recently, in Gallup."
"We supposedly live in America that professes equality and justice for all," Yazzie continued. "But we have a situation like this with Loreal (Tsingine) and the government and the powers that say that he didn't do anything wrong." 
Yazzie walked near the back as protestors, organized by the Red Nation, carried picket signs that read Justice for Loreal" and "Shipley must go to jail." 
The protest walk began from the Winslow City Hall and ended at the police department parking lot. 
The protest was held in response to Shipley's body cam that was made public on Wednesday, as well as Maricopa County Attorney Bill Montgomery's decision to not charge the Winslow police officer for fatally shooting Tsingine on March 27 of this year. 
For Yazzie, the fatal shooting of a Native woman was something he said he's seen too many times since he began his advocacy for Native rights. 
"It's the same situation. It's really unfortunate that we have to demand justice when the evidence is so clear that there was a wrongdoing," he said. "There's got to be accountability. That's what we demand here."

status_message:
BREAKING

Maricopa County Attorney Bill Montgomery: No charges will be filed against Winslow police officer 

By Donovan Quintero
Navajo Times

WINSLOW - Winslow police officer Austin Shipley, who was involved in the Easter Sunday shooting death of Loreal Tsinigine, will not be charged in her death, according to Maricopa County Attorney Bill Montgomery. 

"After careful review of the facts surrounding this case, including available video evidence and witness statements from all involved my office has found no evidence of criminal conduct on the part of officer Shipley," Montgomery said.

Winslow police received multiple calls from Circle K employees of a woman shoplifting and harassing store employees and threatening a store employee with scissors, the Maricopa County press release stated. 

Police officers responded to the scene, but the suspect had already left the store. Officers begin to search for her and Shipley located the suspect, the press release continued. Officer Shipley attempted to detain her, but she did not comply. While attempting to detain her, Shipley saw that she was holding scissors, which she swung at him. 

Shipley then retreated with his weapon drawn and gave multiple commands for the suspect to stop and drop her weapon, the statement continued. She did not comply and instead got up and aggressively advanced on the officer with scissors in hand. Officer Shipley discharged his weapon and the suspect was pronounced deceased at the scene. 

The City of Winslow simultaneously released a statement saying they would respect and abide the Maricopa County Attorney's and the Arizona Department of Public Safety's determinations, but would continue its own internal investigations into its police department, which is to be conducted by the Mesa Police Department.

status_message:
Child mauled to death by dogs

By Cindy Yurth

Tséyi' Bureau

WINDOW ROCK — A three-year-old boy was mauled to death by a pack of dogs in Seba Dalkai Thursday, the boy's mother confirmed Monday.

Kimasha Begay of Gallup said her son, Kayden Colter Begay, was visiting his paternal grandparents, David and Sharon Begay, in Seba Dalkai and had followed his aunt out to get the cattle when a pack of 12 pit bulls owned by the family's neighbor, Marlinda Begay (a relation on Kayden's father's side) attacked him.

"From what I was told, the aunt didn't know Kayden had followed her," said Kimasha Begay, holding back sobs. "She turned around and saw the dogs gathered around something. She went to see what they were doing, and that's when she found my son."

Kimasha Begay said she was told the left side of Kayden's face had been torn off and his thigh was gnawed to the bone.

According to Kimasha Begay, people in the area had repeatedly complained to the Navajo Nation Rangers about the pack of dogs attacking livestock, but nothing was ever done.

"They weren't registered, they weren't vaccinated, and they were skin and bone," she said. "They were probably hungry."

Kimasha Begay said by the time she drove from Gallup to Seba Dalkai after she learned of her son's death, the police and Rangers were there.

"They destroyed some of the dogs, but I don't think they got all of them," she said.

A spokeswoman at the Navajo Nation Criminal Investigations Office in Dilkon confirmed that Criminal Investigations is investigating the incident. No charges have yet been filed.

The family has put up a GoFundMe page, "Funeral Expense for Kayden Begay," to help defray funeral costs.

Kimasha Begay described her son as "the happy kid who ran around shaking everyone's hand."

"He loved to watch bullriding, and he loved to follow his nali around," Begay said.

status_message:
Smoke from North Rim fire impacting Navajo

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

KAIBAB NATIONAL FOREST – A lightning-caused fire in the North Rim of the Grand Canyon increased to 13,685 acres on Monday, July 18, impacting at least seven Western Navajo communities, according to an update from fire officials.

With moderate fire growth, fire managers anticipate light smoke from fire activity today. And smoke may spread to the northeast, reaching the communities in Lake Powell Country and Kayenta.

Higher humidity throughout the day will reduce fire spread along most of the fire perimeter, according to fire officials.

The Fuller Fire started on June 29 and was allowed to burn for a week before suppression efforts started. The fire remains zero percent contained.

More than 500 firefighters, including the Navajo Hotshots and the Navajo Scouts, are battling the massive fire near Point Imperial here (Nát'oh Dziil in Diné bizaad), said Alan Sinclair, incident commander for the Southwest Area Incident Management Team 3.

"It grew a lot bigger than we expected," Sinclair said. "In recorded history, (we) have never seen a fire like this in the North Rim."

Dozens of Diné residents in northwestern Navajo beginning July 13 said the smoke from the fire has been affecting their health.

Vann Smith, superintendent of the Navajo Interagency Hotshot Crew, explained in Navajo that his crew is battling the blaze.

Winds yesterday, July 17, continued to spur natural fire growth to the north across the fire-adapted landscape. Increased cloud cover and higher humidity moderated fire behavior allowing for additional control work to the northeast and to the south, according to fire officials.

Crews conducted burnout operations on the northeast end of the fire in the South Canyon Point area. Crews also conducted two miles of burnout operations overnight along Cape Royal Road to help prevent new fire spread on the Walhalla Plateau.

Arizona State Route 67 is open, but the roads to Point Imperial and to Cape Royal are closed.

status_message:
Storage tanks burn Nageezi 

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

KAYENTA – More than 30 temporary storage tanks are on fire this morning, July 12, near the community of Nageezi, New Mexico after an explosion at a WPX Energy property, located about 36 miles south of Bloomfield, New Mexico. 

One family had to be evacuated, said Kelly Swan, spokesperson for WPX Energy, which produces oil and natural gas. 

"That's what's on fire right now," Swan said. 

Swan says when the explosion occurred at about 11:15 p.m. on Monday, there was no drilling going on and there was no drilling rig at the property located near the intersection of County Road 7890 and U.S. Highway 550. 

"The immediate priority is the safety of the immediate community (where a majority of the residents are Diné allottees)," Swan said.

Swan added that one family living adjacent to the 5-acre WPX property was evacuated about two hours after the explosion. 

The fire though will burn for several more hours.

"Right now, the fire is intense enough that it is safest for the firefighters to establish a perimeter around the site, that no body can get access to it," Swan added. "(The) first order of business is let the fire burn out itself. That's the safest thing for everyone."

The Nageezi Chapter is currently serving as a safe haven this morning for members of the community.

The cause of the explosion is unknown and there were no report of any injuries, Swam said.

Missing Louisiana woman may be on Navajo, father believes
 

By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 

WINDOW ROCK — The father of Diana Zacarias, the 22-year-old tourist from Louisiana who disappeared April 2 from Grand Canyon National Park, believes she might be on the Navajo Nation or another Arizona Indian reservation.
"Please ask your people to look for her," pleaded Alejandro Zacarias of Natchitoche, Louisiana. "We're running out of resources."
Zacarias said a search by the family and the National Park Service in the canyon has revealed no clues, and he now thinks Diana may have gone to live with a Native American tribe.
"She always said someday she would like to go and live with the Indians," he said. Zacarias said he also plans to contact the Havasupai Tribe at the bottom of the canyon.
In an interview with Univision, Zacarias said Diana had called her family Friday, April 1, saying she had toured the canyon and wanted to do another hike the next morning. Her mother had reminded her that her flight from Flagstaff back to Louisiana was at 5:30 p.m., so she should make sure to be back on time.
Saturday, Diana's parents followed her Facebook page and saw beautiful photos of Diana and the Grand Canyon, Zacarias said.
Later that afternoon, Diana's mother, worried she would miss her flight, texted her daughter, "Dianita, are you already on your way to the airport?"
According to Zacarias, Diana texted back, "No, I am not going."
That was the last they heard from her. Phone calls went straight to voicemail, which wasn't like her, her father said.
Zacarias and his wife reported Diana missing that evening and jumped in their car for the 20-hour drive to Flagstaff, arriving the following Monday. They discovered Diana had never checked in with the airline and never changed her reservation.
The Park Service mounted a full-scale search-and-rescue operation by land and air on Wednesday, but found no trace of the young woman.
Zacarias said his daughter was a model student at Northwestern State University of Louisiana, where she was a junior majoring in industrial engineering. She had never expressed a desire to leave home and had no reason to, he added — but he recalled her stating on multiple occasions that she would someday like to live on a Native American reservation.
"This is really the only hope I have, that she has gone to live among the Navajos or other Indians," he said. "Please help us find our daughter."
Diana is described as a petite Latina, about 5-foot-2 and slim, with short dark hair. In her last Facebook posts, she was wearing a pink hat, purple sweater and glasses.
Anyone with information is asked to call 318-609-0012.

status_message:
Tsingine's family files wrongful death lawsuit 

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

PAGE, Ariz. – The family of a Diné woman who was fatally shot by a Winslow, Arizona police officer three months ago filed a $10.5 million wrongful death lawsuit against the city on Friday. 

The claim states that Officer Austin J. Shipley violated the civil rights of 27-year-old Loreal Juana Barnell-Tsingine in the shooting and that "the city of Winslow was negligent in hiring, training, retaining, controlling and supervising" Shipley. 

The claim also states that the city "uniformly ignored warning signs that Austin Shipley was a threat to the public."

According to the claim, at least two field training officers who trained Shipley had concerns about his work, including being "quick to go for his … weapon when dealing with people," falsifying reports, among others that the officers wrote in their daily notes during his training in 2013. 

Shipley allegedly shot and killed Tsingine on Easter, March 27. Shipley responded to a shoplifting call at a Winslow convenience store where Tsingine was shot five times after allegedly brandishing a pair of scissors at Shipley that evening outside. 

The claim names the city of Winslow, Shipley, and Winslow Police Chief Stephen Garnett as defendants. Tsingine's 8-year-old daughter, Tiffany Robbins, and her husband, Michael Tsingine, are the claimants. 

Shipley remains on standard, paid administrative leave since the March shooting. An investigation has been conducted but not yet made public.

status_message:
Accident in Kaibeto kills two kids

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

KAIBETO, Ariz. – Two children were killed, one child was flown to the hospital, and a portion of Arizona Route 98 was closed sometime around Monday afternoon after a Pepsi semi truck and a motorhome collided on the roadway Monday afternoon.

The roadway between mileposts 332 and 334 will be closed for at least six hours, said Police Sgt. Mike Wischmann of the Page, Arizona, Police Department.

Wischmann said according to witnesses, the driver of the Pepsi truck was traveling westbound (toward Page) and went left of center into the eastbound lane, colliding with the side of a motorhome with at least eight persons in it.

Wischmann said two children were pronounced dead at the scene and a 10-year-old was flown to Flagstaff Medical Center by Guardian Air.

Police have rerouted all eastbound traffic toward Navajo Route 21 then onto U.S. Highway 160, and all westbound traffic have been rerouted back toward 160.

Wischmann said there aren't a lot of accidents on SR 98 and this is the first one of this magnitude that he has seen.

"We do have serious-injury accidents like this but generally they are few and far between," Wischmann said. "Usually … somebody's going in the opposite lane of traffic –– speeding or passing where they shouldn't."

Wischmann said with the tourism traffic in Lake Powell Country this time of year, the police are encouraging people to slow down.

"Especially with Fourth of July weekend coming up," he said. "A lot of the problems we (law enforcement agencies) are seeing is (motorists) passing when they shouldn't, excessive speeds, and hazardous driving. We want everyone to be wearing their seatbelt and to be cautious, and not to be texting and driving."

The Arizona Department of Public Safety, the Navajo Nation Division of Public Safety, and the Page Police are investigating the accident.

Firefighters extinguish brush fire near Window Rock

Navajo Times

WINDOW ROCK – The Navajo Nation Fire Department with assistance from Navajo Estates Volunteer Fire Department, McKinley West Fire Department and BIA Forestry quickly took out a brushfire spanning about a quarter mile about 3 miles east of Window Rock on State Highway 264 Friday afternoon.

According to Lt. Jeffrey Morgan with the Navajo Nation Fire Department, firefighters extinguished three separate fires, burning almost an acre. About 16 firefighters and wildland firefighters wasted no time putting out the fire.

With the Fourth of July weekend a week away, Morgan said despite the Navajo Nation not having a fire restriction in place, it was still illegal to have fireworks on the reservation. The Navajo Nation Fire Department will be enforcing the no fireworks restriction, Morgan added.

Morgan said the cause of the brushfire was not yet determined. No injuries were reported.

status_message:
Begody-Begay's signatures challenged
 
By Bill Donovan
Special to the Times
 
PHOENIX — A registered voter in Navajo County has filed a challenge to the candidacy of Candace Begody-Begay.
Begody-Begay is running in the Republican primary for Arizona State Senate District 7, a position that is currently held by her husband, Caryle Begay, who has filed to run in the Republican primary for Congress.
In his complaint, Eric Kramer is claiming that Begody-Begay, a former editor for the Navajo Times, failed to get enough valid signatures to be on the ballot.
She was required under state law to get 294 signatures and turned in 325.
Kramer claims that at lest 226 of the signatures she collected are not valid.
In some cases, the signer was not a registered voter or was not registered as a Republican. Others, he said, were not registered in the district for which she is running.
There are also cases, Kramer said, where the signer signed the petition more than once or signed the petition of another candidate. Arizona election law allows a person to sign only one petition during each election period.
In several cases, he said, the signer's address does not match the one on his or her voter registration card.
A hearing on the claim is scheduled to be held on June 24 before a superior court judge in Phoenix.
Begody-Begay does not have any opposition in the Republican primary.
A total of 12 challenges were filed against candidates running in this year's primary. Two of them have since been withdrawn leaving 10 to be decided in court hearings.

status_message:
McKinley County man dies of Hantavirus

Navajo Times

     GALLUP - A 25 year-old man from McKinley County has become the latest victim of the Hantavirus, officials for the New Mexico Department of Health announced Tuesday.
    He is the fifth victim of the Hantavirus this year.
    Health officials did not say if the victim lived on or off the Navajo Reservation.
    The springtime and early summer are the prime months for catching the disease as people clean out their storage sheds and breath in fumes from urine and feces left there by rodents who have the disease.
    Health officials strongly recommend that people who clean out their sheds wear medical masks to protect themselves from the possibility of breathing in fumes.
    The deer mouse is the primary rodent that carries the disease, according to state health officials.
    Health officials said they plan to do an environmental investigation at the victim's home to determine if their were risks for other members of his family.

Open house set on Horseshoe Bend improvements

By Krista Allen

Western Agency Bureau

            PAGE, Ariz. – Page City and National Park Service officials are seeking public input on the development of a master plan for the Horseshoe Bend Overlook, which officials say is located within city limits, not in the Navajo Nation.

            Mayor Bill Diak says the overlook, which is part of Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, has gotten so popular that the city and the Park Service have to do something to not only protect it, but to offer a better experience for those wanting to view the spectacular, almost circular meander of the Colorado River.

            "The congestion – getting in and out of the parking lot, the number of people trying to do the trail, which is very, very cumbersome for most people," Diak explained. "And doing those improvements, we're looking … to change the visitor's experience. How do we make it better?"

            Officials at a June 2 open house, which took place at the Glen Canyon National Recreation Area headquarters, said a master plan is needed to provide a high-quality visitor experience, improve accessibility, address safety concerns and prevent resource damage.

A second open house is slated for tomorrow (Tuesday) from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m. DST at Page City Hall on Vista Ave.

            "We're trying to collect as many ideas as we can so … we build a plan for that," Diak said. "It's going to be a big project and we want as much input as we can get. We want to satisfy our people who live here and to satisfy (the visitors)."

            Officials said the idea of a master plan started more than a year ago.

            "Now we're into building the plan stage," Diak said. "We can come up with a lot of ideas but they might not fit somebody else's ideas."

            A Diné woman from Bitter Springs, Ariz., who did not want to be named, said her ideas include permission for Navajo jewelers to sell their handiwork.

            "We (the Navajo Nation) had to give up part of our land for the city of Page," the woman said. "The city should give people consideration because not everyone wants to move away to find a job. That's how we can support (ourselves) –– we want in on the action of tourism too."

            The woman also said she'd like to see railings at the overlook seeing as visitors "are all over the place."

            "The (Colorado River) is a sacred river –– to the Natives, it's sacred," the woman added. "People should not be climbing and crawling. Visitors need to have respect for the Natives."

            Meanwhile, officials said there could possibly be a fee, which Diak said visitors could pay down the road.

            "But no decisions have been made," Diak said. "Public input has a lot to do with that."

            Officials said they are currently working on emergency improvements at the overlook. Improvements include designated parking areas for RVs, boats, and buses; and widening the entrance, among others.

            A second open house was held Tuesday. Those who missed the open house events can complete a survey online at surveymonkey.com/r/6QSJY9V

status_message:
By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau
 
NAATSIS'ÁÁN-RAINBOW CITY, Utah – Ryan Hueston says his late grandfather would be proud of a renovation project he is spearheading here.
"It's a really beautiful thing to hear my family say that my grandpa, (Harold Drake Sr.), would be proud of this (project)," said Hueston, Diné-Anglo, whose family lives in Newport Beach, Calif. but calls Navajo Mountain home.
The Navajo Mountain Boarding School Project, Hueston's team says, aims to empower the community's creative potential through renovation and reinvention of Navajo Mountain Boarding School into a community center.
Hueston says his grandmother, Stella Rose Begay-Drake, 94, taught there and his mother, Mabelle Drake Hueston, along with her siblings went to school there.
Ryan Hueston said the defunct boarding school buildings have always been vacant since he was a child.
"I've always heard stories about them," he said. "And they've always been architecturally fascinating to me."
In terms of what they represent historically, he says, the buildings symbolize cultural hybridity, meaning the blending of elements from different cultures.
"The buildings are a hybrid as well … of Navajo hogan architecture and of Western architecture (from the Progressive Era) when John Collier, (former Commissioner of Indian Affairs), created the second era of boarding schools," Ryan Hueston explained. "(These) are buildings like the ones my grandfather was taken to in Tuba City where his hair was cut off … abused, and beaten if he spoke his language."
Ryan Hueston said the vacancy and the potential of the old buildings here, which are located near the senior center, is special.
"(They) hold so many memories and so much energy that (they) need some sort of catalyst," he said. "There's so much use."
Ryan Hueston says the project had some rumblings about it being an arts and culture center, an archives center, among others for people visiting the area.
"But my dream has always been an arts and culture center just because there's so much to be taught," he said. "I see the elders getting older, like Mary Ann Owl, (San Juan Southern Paiute basket maker). It's getting harder for (elders) to gather stuff. And I want a new generation to be able to do that, taught by the (elders), how they're supposed to be taught, first hand with experience."
Ryan Hueston says the project ultimately is about creating a space for that, which the Center for Art and Public Life at California College of the Arts' IMPACT Social Entrepreneurship Award allowed him and his team to do.
On April 7, Ryan Hueston and his team – Graeme Aegerter, Magdalena Härtelova, Lillian Makeda, and Ella Schoefer-Wulf – were presented one of the three $10,000 grants "to create innovative and creative solutions to social problems by collaborating with community experts and partners."
The Navajo Mountain Boarding School Project team arrived here on Wednesday and began work on Thursday morning.
The team is now seeking volunteers to help fulfill the project.
Team member Schoefer-Wulf, a German-American writer who's studying at CCA for a master's degree, says a community dinner will take place today, June 13, outside the boarding schools at 4:30 p.m. and dinner will be served at 5:30 p.m.
"We want the community dinner to be an opportunity for people to have a look at the buildings and we will present the project and the history of the boarding school to everyone," Schoefer-Wulf said. "We want this to be a time to share stories of the past and ideas about how we can best use this space in the future, and how we can serve the community."
Those interested in helping with the project can email the team at mountainschoolproject@gmail.com.
Information: navajomountainschoolproject.com.

status_message:
Alleged kidnapper found, not charged

By Donovan Quintero
Navajo Times

 GALLUP — The man alleged to have kidnapped two young boys from Wheatfields Lake Saturday was located by New Mexico State Police and the FBI Monday, but no charges have been filed pending further investigation, according to an FBI press release.
 Vivian Randolph, the mother of the boys and the girlfriend of the alleged kidnapper, said FBI agents informed her they had interviewed suspect Clinton Johnson, 26, and released him.
 The press release does not state whether Johnson is in custody.
 Navajo Police Officer Garrett Thomas of the Crownpoint Police District said Lyric Gray, 5, and his brother, Kerwin Gray, 7, were found in an abandoned white Oldsmobile Alero off of Red Beard Road, about 10 miles west of here Sunday afternoon. The children are in the custody of Navajo Nation Social Services.
 Randolph had told police Johnson had driven off with the children.
 She says she fears for herself and her family since Johnson is not custody.
 "How am I supposed to make sure my family, myself, my kids are going to be safe?" she said. "If he was captured ... why didn't they call me? They have my information on how to get a hold of me.
 "So who releases a person that kidnaps another father's children?" Randolph continued during an interview with the Navajo Times. 
 An Amber Alert for the boys was issued by Utah around 1 a.m. Sunday. Around 10 a.m. an Amber Alert was issued in New Mexico. 
 Navajo Nation Police Chinle District is leading the investigation.

status_message:
Excessive heat and strong thunderstorms warnings issued for parts of reservation 

Navajo Times

GALLUP - A line of strong thunderstorms with a potential for dropping hail and wind gusts up to 50 mph are moving across parts of the Eastern Agency and Alamo Navajo in New Mexico, the National Weather Service reports. 

Torrential rainfall is occurring with storms, which may lead to flash flooding, NWS states. 

Meanwhile, Coconino County in Arizona continues to remain under an excessive heat warning. 

According to the NWS, temperatures could reach as high as 111 degrees for areas with an elevation under 4,000 feet. 

Both warnings issued by NWS will remain in effect until Monday. NWS also advises not to cross flooded areas and to stay out of the heat.

Brothers found safe, Amber Alert cancelled, Navajo police says

By Krista Allen and Donovan Quintero 
Navajo Times
 
GALLUP, N.M. – An Amber Alert was canceled Sunday afternoon after two missing Diné brothers were found safe. But police are still looking for the suspect who took the boys. 
Navajo Police Officer Garrett Thomas of the Crownpoint Police District said Lyric Gray, 5, and his brother, Kerwin Gray, 7, were found in an abandoned white Oldsmobile Alero off of Red Beard Road, about 10 miles west of here. 
The Amber Alert was issued this morning around 12:50 a.m. for the brothers after their mother, Vivian Johnson, reported that her boyfriend, Clinton Johnson, 26, took the boys following a verbal confrontation between the two. 
The alert was first issued in Utah early Sunday morning. However, it was cancelled by the Utah Bureau of Criminal Identification shortly after 8 a.m. when officials no longer believed the suspect was headed for the Beehive State. The alert though remained in effect in Arizona and in New Mexico until the boys were found shortly after noon. 
Vivian Johnson said she took her family camping on Friday in Wheatfields Lake, Ariz. to celebrate her birthday. 
"Everything was OK, nothing happened on Friday," Vivian Johnson said. "It wasn't until Saturday afternoon that I noticed Clinton was acting funny. I don't recall him pulling out any beer at all … on this trip." 
Around 3 p.m. on Saturday, Vivian Johnson said, Clinton Johnson started arguing with her about keys to their car.
"I kept repeating myself, 'I don't have the keys!'," Vivian Johnson said. "I left it alone, but he (started) cursing at me and calling me names." 
When Johnson found the keys to their car, he got in. At that time, the brothers, along with their older brother, Raydell, were playing in the water. 
Later he started another argument, Vivian Johnson said. 
"He continued," Vivian Johnson said. "I didn't want to get into an altercation with him because I didn't want it to go beyond that extent where he would start beating me. So I left it alone." 
Vivian Johnson said she had more than $200 in the glove compartment of the car  that she was saving for the children. At one point, she told Raydell to get the money out of the glove compartment.
Clinton Johnson however saw what Raydell was doing and stopped him. Then another argument ignited.
"I was hoping that our neighbors who were fishing not too far from us would call the cops for us if they hear us arguing and yelling," Vivian Johnson said. "Knowing the fact that the kids were there, but nobody helped us at all." 
New Mexico residents say they received the alert shortly after 10 a.m. on Sunday reading, "Chinle, AZ AMBER Alert: LIC/238TMB (NM) White Oldsmobile Alero." 
According to the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children's AMBER Alert Program, the suspect, Clinton Johnson, took the children in a white 2000 Oldsmobile Alero and may have headed towards Mentmore, N.M. 
Vivian Johnson said Clinton is from Mentmore, where he is originally from. Clinton Johnson is reported to be 5 feet 5 inches tall with tattoos reading "Johnson" on his left forearm and "Kiarra" on his left hand. His ring, middle, and index fingers on his left hand are missing. 
The Navajo Times was not able to get a comment from law enforcement immediately after the initial alert was issued.

Amber Alert 

Two young brothers taken from Wheatfields Lake 

Navajo Times

WHEATFIELDS LAKE, Ariz. – An Amber Alert has been issued for two missing boys who were taken from Wheatfields Lake on Saturday. 

According to the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children's AMBER Alert Program, Lyric Gray, 5, and Kerwin Gray, 7, were taken on June 4 by Clinton Johnson, who was drinking, and may be headed towards Mentmore, N.M. in a white 2000 Oldsmobile Alero with New Mexico plate No. 238TMB.

Lyric Gray is 3 feet 6 inches tall. He was last seen wearing a gray shirt with blue underarm, black jeans, and red and black shoes. Kerwin Gray is 4 feet tall. He was last seen wearing a multicolored Angry Birds shirt, blue jeans, and white Air Jordan high tops. 

Johnson is reported to be 5 feet 5 inches tall, with tattoos reading "Johnson" on his left forearm and "Kiarra" on his left hand. His ring, middle, and index fingers on his left hand are missing.

Anyone with information should call their local police department.

status_message:
Navajo Code Talker passes on

Navajo Times

WINDOW ROCK - Navajo Code Talker Arcenio Smiley has passed on.

According to the Navajo Nation President's Office, they were informed by his granddaughter that her grandfather died Wednesday in Phoenix, Ariz. 

Smiley was born in Toadlena, N.M., a small community nestled against the Chuska Mountain,, about 20 miles west of Burnham, N.M. He joined the U.S. Marine Corps on in 1944 and became a code talker. From 1945 to 1946, Smiley served in the Pacific fighting the Japanese. After completing his service, Smiley was honorably discharged and left the Marine Corps as a corporal. 

Smiley earned the marksman level qualification with the rifle. He was also awarded the Congressional Silver Medal and Good Conduct Medal for his service as a Navajo Code Talker, the press release states. 

Smiley worked for the Navajo Service Warehouse (1949-1951), Gallup Navajo Clinic (1951-1953), and the Gallup Indian Medical Center's Office of Environmental Health where he retired after 30 years of service in 1981.

"Our grandfather was a great man who was very proud of his heritage and service to his country," his grandchildren said. "He will be missed by all, as great warrior who is on his journey back home."

Smiley was Tse' Naabilnii (Sleep Rock People), born for Hona'gha'ahnii (One-Walks-Around). His maternal grandfather's are Naakaii Dine'e' (Mexican) and paternal grandfather's are Hashtl'ishnii (Mud).

Funeral services for Smiley will be held on Monday, June 6, 2016, at 10 a.m. in Newcomb, N.M. at the Newcomb Assembly of God Church.

status_message:
Hundreds await SFIS commencement speech to be delivered by First Lady

By Arlyssa Becenti
Navajo Times

SANTA FE- Hundreds of people stood outside the Pueblo Pavilion Wellness Center at the Santa Fe Indian School waiting to get a seat to not only see their graduates receive their high school diploma but to also witness a historical event of hearing the First Lady of the United States Michelle Obama give the commencement speech.

Carrying a bouquet of yellow roses for his niece, Florentino Loretto had been waiting in line for more than an hour and right before he walked through the metal detectors to get into the pavilion, he emphasized how excited he was the First Lady was here.

"I think this is great," said Loretto. "It's a once and a lifetime event."

Santa Fe Indian School is owned and operated by the 19 Pueblos of New Mexico and serves 650 students from the 19 Pueblo, Navajo and Apache tribes of New Mexico. There will be 105 graduates this year and most will continue onto to college at distinguished institutes such as: Stanford University, Dartmouth, Columbia, NYU, and Harvard. 

For a more in-depth story and photos on the First Lady's speech, grab your copy of the next edition of the Navajo Times at your nearest newsstand next Thursday.

status_message:
Tuba City man shot, killed after carjack attempt 

By Krista Allen
Navajo Times

            TUBA CITY – Officers from the Flagstaff and the Northern Arizona University Police Departments fatally shot a Diné man after he attempted to carjack an individual at gunpoint on Monday morning.

            According to a Flagstaff Police Department press release, Verl Bedonie, 26, from Tónaneesdizí was shot and killed after leading police on a foot chase that ended in a confrontation in the Plaza Vieja neighborhood where the investigation reveals that Bedonie fired one round at the officers.

            Before the deadly shooting, Flagstaff Police received a called around 7:48 a.m. (Arizona time) reporting a Native American man carrying what looked like a BB gun, which turned out to be a 9 millimeter handgun, inside the High Country Conference Center where officers discovered Bedonie holding a firearm.

            Bedonie ignored commands to drop his weapon and left the conference center and walked west along Butler Avenue, toward South Milton Road, according to police.

            While walking across Drury Inn's parking lot, near the north campus of NAU, Bedonie was seen turning towards pursuing officers, raising his gun at one of the officers. FPD's Cpl. Ben Sandoval and Officer Eric Tomperi responded by firing a total of five shots, all of them missing Bedonie.

            With the officers approximately 20 to 30 yards behind him, commanding him to stop, Bedonie then walked across South Milton Road.

            Officers followed Bedonie westbound on West Clay Avenue, where he started running northbound on South Florence Street.

            "At one point, the suspect pointed his gun at a taxi cab driver parked at the carwash located on Clay," a FPD press release states. "Schools in the area were ordered on lockdown…"

            Police believe that Bedonie fired one round in an alley between South Florence Street and South Park Street.

            When an undercover Flagstaff police officer arrived to the area in an unmarked vehicle, the officer saw Bedonie get into the passenger side of a vehicle, in which Bedonie pointed a gun at the driver and demanded to be taken to Phoenix.

            Believing that Bedonie would either take the driver hostage or harm him, the officer decided to ram the driver's vehicle to prevent it from moving.

            "When the vehicle was struck, the suspect who had been in the passenger seat exited the vehicle, walking around the car to the north side of the street," the release states. "Numerous officers at the scene continued to give commands for the suspect to drop the gun…"

            Bedonie raised the gun towards the officers and was shot.

            Shortly after the shooting, it was discovered that one of the officer's rounds penetrated a residence, injuring a dog, which is expected to recover after surgery.

status_message:
Elderly man with Alzheimer's disease found, family says

Navajo Times

 WINDOW ROCK - Milton Yazzie, 60, from Mariano Lake, N.M., who's been missing since May 4, has been found.

 According to Lindsey Nez's mother Melinda Nez, Yazzie showed up at his mother's place in Manuelito, Ariz., around 2 p.m., Wednesday. 

 "He's ok. We found dad" Melinda said. "He just popped up at his mom's place. Now we are going to take him home and give him his (Alzheimer's disease) medication and some clean clothes."

 Nez is not sure of how Yazzie took care of himself or where he was, but said they'd find out soon enough.

 On Friday, Yazzie's filed a missing person report with the Crownpoint Police Department asking for the public's help. 

 Yazzie's daughter said her father had left to renew his ID, but did not come home.

Now that he's been found, Nez said the family would have to take down the missing person report at the police station and missing person flyers that they hung up. 

"We are going around canceling everything now," she said.

Delegate ordered to serve 3 years jail time, pay restitution of $33,400

 

By Bill Donovan

Special to the Times

 

            WINDOW ROCK – Window Rock District Court Judge Carol Perry Tuesday gave former council delegate Mel R. Begay a three-year tribal jail sentence after being found guilty of conspiracy and nine counts of submitting false vouchers.

            She also is requiring him to pay restitution of  $33,400 and pay fines totaling $5,000. Those must be paid immediately, Perry said.

            The three-year sentence is not three years, however. Under tribal law a person earns one day of good time for every day served if no jail rules are violated.

            Begay was ordered to begin serving the time immediately even though his attorney urged Perry to allow his client time to get his affairs in order and allow time for the appeals process to go through.

            Perry, after listening to his argument, adjourned the court and Begay was escorted downstairs to begin serving his jail time.

            It was brought up during the two hours of debate over sentencing that Begay was offered a plea agreement before the trial that that would have required him to pay only $17,000 in restitution and no jail time.

            Begay turned down the proposal, according to his attorney, because he did not and still does not feel he violated any criminal law in approving 59 requests from his family for grants from the tribal discretionary fund.

Diné man killed in Phoenix shootout
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — A former Chinle man was killed by Phoenix police in a shootout after apparently shooting and killing his longtime girlfriend Saturday.
Francis Clark, 43, and his girlfriend Mercy Cordova, 41, both died at the scene. Two Phoenix Police officers wearing bullet-proof vests were shot and injured.
According to a press release from the Phoenix Police Department's Public Affairs Bureau, police responded to the Shadow Tree Apartments at 3737 W. McDowell Road in Phoenix about 1:30 p.m. Saturday after a 911 caller reported a home invasion.
As they proceeded to the apartment building in question, a man later identified as Clark began shooting at them with a handgun, the release states. Both officers were struck by bullets, but one officer was able to return fire and struck Clark. Clark was pronounced dead at the scene.
Additional officers dispatched to the scene found Cordova's body, the release states.
Witnesses told police Clark lived at the complex and had been in a romantic relationship with Cordova for years. The couple had no children in common.
Both the injured officers were treated at a local hospital and released.

status_message:
Utah Amber Alert results in rescue of two children in Gallup

 

By Christopher S. Pineo

Navajo Times

 

GALLUP – The Amber Alert System worked in Gallup on May 5, as two children were rescued when a Motel 6 employee called police.

            The employee made the call after receiving an Amber Alert issued from Utah, and officers were dispatched at 4:06 a.m. according to a statement from the Gallup Police Department.

            Marae Montoya, 3, and Cynthia Montoya, 11 months, went missing from the home of a babysitter in Clinton, Utah at around 3 p.m. on Thursday and were rescued within 14 hours. The Amber Alert was issued within seven hours of the abduction according to a post on the Department of Justice's official Amber Alert account on Twitter – just before 11 p.m. Thursday.

            Gallup's Lt. Rosanne Morrissette said the clerk and locals may have been paying closer attention to the Amber Alert System after a recent Amber Alert on the Navajo Nation for an 11-year-old girl whose funeral was held on May 6 in Shiprock. That Amber Alert took more than 10 hours to activate after that incident took place on Monday at 4 p.m.

            "It's hard to say why it took that long," she said. "Authorities didn't have information at the time. On this one the authorities had immediate information."

            She said the alert from the previous case may have heightened awareness.

            "This clerk at the Motel 6, she really paid attention," Morrissette said.

Gallup police arrested Christopher John Montoya, 35, and Monica Jody Martinez, 27, without incident according to a police report. Police await extradition of the two, who are parents of the children, to Utah at McKinley County Adult Detention Center, while Children Youth and Family Department has the two children in custody.

            Morrissette said police in Utah will have to come to New Mexico to retrieve the suspects.

            According to Gallup PD the children were unharmed and police bought diapers, formula, and other items to care for the children. Morrissette said the arresting officer noticed that the room contained no such items for childcare.

            "Immediately, Sgt. Emery Holly initiated the purchase of diapers, formula, and other items that the children needed," Morrissette said.

            Morrissette wanted to remind the community of the importance of responding to Amber Alerts by calling authorities as the clerk did.

            "Just continue to be alert," she said. "Take these Amber Alerts very serious."

Chinle student dies during JROTC exercise

By Cindy Yurth
Tseyi' Bureau

CHINLE - A Chinle High School student died Saturday morning while crossing Clear Creek near Winslow, Ariz. on a zip line during a JROTC training exercise.

According to a press release from the Navajo County Sheriff's Office, Marisa Trujillo, 17, unclipped herself from the zip line about halfway across the creek and plunged 60 feet into the creek at about 11:30 a.m.

Witnesses told sheriff's deputies other students had done this in the past as a daredevil stunt and had swum to shore unhurt. Trujillo allegedly had told other students she was planning to unclip herself and the students said they had tried to discourage her.

A diver stationed in the creek as a precaution swam out to where she entered the water within seconds, the witnesses told deputies, but was unable to find her.

The Winslow dive team recovered her body two hours later.

Maj. Richard Rail (ret.), Army instructor at the high school, declined to comment on the incident. The Chinle Unified School District did not return a call seeking further information.

status_message:
Remembering Ashlynne

Eulogy: 'Our little Angel, whose life was short-lived' 

 

By Arlyssa Becenti

Navajo Times

 

FARMINGTON – Ashlynne Mike's little white casket was placed in the center of the Farmington Civic Center stage Friday morning surrounded with colorful, bright flowers.

With a slide show of pictures of her playing the xylophone, as well as her artwork she had drawn, her family stood up and spoke about their unique and talented daughter and sister.

 "How do I begin a farewell, when I still can't believe you're gone," said Pamela Foster as she gave her daughter's eulogy. "Our little Angel, whose life was short-lived. However, her beauty and magic will linger forever in our hearts and in those for whom she's touched."

 Before the beginning of the services it was announced that there were 3,000 people waiting outside wanting to attend the service. Since it was first reported of Ashlynne's abduction Monday, there had been a widespread support throughout the Navajo Nation and New Mexico to help find her. When it was reported Ashlynne's body was found not far from the Shiprock Pinnacle the next day, an even greater amount of support came together to show their grief and outrage.

 "I'm heartbroken as I stand here today," said New Mexico Gov. Susana Martinez who spoke at Ashlynne's funeral. "The many people who loved Ashlynne described her as fun loving and always smiling. She was kind and quiet. She would've gone on to make a much better place."

 Ashlynne's untimely, tragic death had sparked the conversation as to why the Navajo Nation lacks an Amber Alert system that could've possibly help locate her a lot sooner after she and her younger brother Ian Mike were abducted. 

 Tom Begaye Jr., 27, of Waterflow, N.M., was later arrested in connection with the abduction.

 As he spoke about his little sister, Ryan Begay said when he heard about Ashlynne's disappearance he drove to the Shiprock Pinnacle with a friend and searched for her. He said he had reported Ashlynne's disappearance at 10:30 p.m. but the alert didn't go out until 2:30 a.m. the next morning.

 "I wish this alert went out sooner when I called it," said Ryan Begay. "That night I heard she was kidnapped, I spent a long time at the pinnacle driving late at night. I needed help. I thought that there would be a lot more people out there."

 Aside from the family's disappointment in the lack of response from authorities they also spoke emotionally on the kind of little girl Ashlynne was. Her older sister Brittany Begay, said Ashlynne was a talented artist. 

It was mentioned how much the fifth-grade student from Ojo Amarillo Elementary loved playing the xylophone and piano, and was a gifted student having made student of the month numerous of times and had near perfect attendance.

 "She was such a sweet, funny little sister," said Brittany. "She was so creative. She would sit by me and watch me as I draw and try to mimic it…sometimes I would get our art work confused because she was that good."

'Threat of child abduction is real'

Family, community mourns loss of 11-year-old girl

status_message:
Begaye charged with kidnapping, murder
 

By Cindy Yurth
Navajo Times
 
CHINLE — Tom Begaye Jr. of Waterflow, N.M., made his initial appearance Wednesday morning on charges of kidnapping and murder in connection with the abduction and killing of 11-year-old Ashlynne Mike on Monday.
At the appearance before Magistrate Judge B. Paul Briones in Farmington, Begaye was determined to qualify for a court-appointed attorney. His preliminary hearing was set for Friday at the federal courthouse in Albuquerque. A detention hearing will also take place at that time. He will remain in federal custody until then.
Elizabeth Martinez, spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney's Office in New Mexico, said a plea is not generally offered at an initial appearance on a federal charge, "and anyway, he wouldn't enter a plea until he has the benefit of counsel."
According to the criminal complaint, Begaye enticed Ashlynne and her nine-year-old brother, Ian, into his van near Shiprock Monday evening and drove them toward the Shiprock pinnacle. Ian told investigators Begaye parked the car and took his sister out of the car, carrying a piece of metal. He allegedly returned an hour later, carrying the piece of metal but without Ashlynne.
Begaye then told Ian to get out of the vehicle and drove away, Ian told investigators. He and another witness were able to provide a description of both Begaye and his vehicle to investigators, who located and arrested Begaye at a sweat lodge near Shiprock.
Police found Ashlynne's body near Navajo Route 13. Her injuries were consistent with blunt force trauma to the head.
If convicted of kidnapping a minor, Begaye faces a minimum of 20 years in prison. The murder charge carries a minimum of life in prison.
The FBI and Navajo Nation Division of Public Safety investigated the case with assistance from the U.S. Marshals Service, New Mexico State Police, San Juan county Sheriff's Office and the Farmington Police Department.
Assistant U.S. Attorneys Niki Tapia-Brito and David Adams are prosecuting the case.

Arraignment set in child murder

By Cindy Yurth
Navajo Times

 

            WINDOW ROCK - Tom Begaye Jr., the 27-year-old Waterflow, N.M. resident suspected in the abduction and murder of an 11-year-old Shiprock girl, will be arraigned at 10 a.m. today (Wednesday) at Farmington Municipal Court, a court spokeswoman confirmed.

            Elizabeth Martinez, spokeswoman for the U.S. Attorney for New Mexico, said at 8:45 a.m. she had not yet been told what the exact charges will be.

            The body of Ashlynne Mike was found near the Shiprock pinnacle yesterday morning. She and her younger brother, Ian, reportedly got into a van driven by a man after school on Monday. Ian Mike told police the man let him out and he was picked up by a passerby while walking home.

            Begaye was arrested Tuesday evening.

            Navajo Nation President Russell Begaye issued the following statement: "Our Nation has just gone through a tragic event. I am pleased to know that both Navajo and outside law enforcement were able to work together and share information. This led to the arrest of an individual who is believed to have caused a horrendous crime on one of our Navajo children.

            "Now, we must continue to heal as we have all been impacted.  We must also work hard to protect our children.
            "I express my deepest appreciation to law enforcement officials and I would also like to again extend my condolences to the family of Ashlynne Mike."
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Arrest made in murder; community gathers for vigil

By Arlyssa Becenti
Navajo Times 

  SAN JUAN- Ashlynne Mike, 11, played the xylophone and was in fifth grade at Ojo Amarilo Elementary. 

  On Monday, she along with her brother Ian Mike were abducted by a man who reportedly was driving a maroon van with tinted windows in the Fruitland area.  Ian was able to escape, but Ashlynne wasn't. Her body was found Tuesday morning near the Shiprock pinnacle. Tuesday evening, the FBI announced they had arrested a suspect in the case: Tom Begaye, 27, of Waterflow, N.M.

  "The community responded really well today," said Shawn Mike, cousin to Ashlynne's dad, Gary Mike. "Thank you for your support."

  Shawn Mike continued to rehash the day Ashlynne and Ian were taken. Shawn said his nine-year-old son had also encountered the man in the van and he too was offered a ride, with the enticement of seeing the movie "Zootopia." When that failed, Shawn Mike recounted, the man simply offered to take the boy home from school. 

  "The threat of child abduction is real," said Shawn Mike. "My son was approached by this van ... They asked, 'We're going to the movies' ... and my son said no ... My son came home and said 'Dad, Ian and Ashlynne are in the van. Ashlynne was waving at me,' not knowing her fate." 
  
Tuesday,Ashlynne's body was found approximately 6 miles south of the Shiprock Monument. 

  "This is like an atomic bomb dropped on a community," said San Juan Chapter President Rick Nez. 

  Tuesday night hundreds of grievers came out in solidarity, reacting to the tragic news. 

  "It's a big weight off your shoulder knowing the suspect was found," said Graham Beyale who was one of the volunteers in the search party for Ashlynne. "It's heartwarming to see all these people here for her." 

  What came out of the vigil was not only remembering the precious little girl. It also sparked a conversation on needed laws on the Navajo Nation regarding sex offenders and child molesters, as well as encouraging an honest dialogue between parents and children. 

  Council Delegate Amber Crotty (Beclabito/ Cove/ Gadi'i'áhi/To'Koi, Red Valley/ Tooh Haltsooi/ Toadlena/Two Grey Hills/ Tsé ałnáoz't'I'í) along with Council Delegate Nathaniel Brown (Kayenta/ Chilchinbeto/ Dennehotso) were the only Navajo Nation leaders that attended the vigil and said they will assist the community in any way they can as well as advocating for stiffer laws.

  "I know you look to us in leadership for strength and guidance," said Crotty as she cried. "Our babies should not be targeted. That whoever wants to take them from us, knows there's a swift and harsh consequence."

status_message:
Body of 11-year-old found, police search for suspect

By Arlyssa Becenti
Navajo Times

WINDOW ROCK - The body of Ashlynn Mike, the 11-year-old girl who was abducted yesterday triggering an Amber Alert, was found earlier today. 

Shawn Mike a relative of Ashlynn said that the family is taking it hard and is hoping the suspect is found. 

"This is a complete shock," said Shawn Mike during a phone interview. "We put trust in the Lord that he'll make a way. For this individual to do what he did, you don't know how cruel some people are. The cruelty to take this little girl when her life was just beginning." 

Ashlynn and her younger brother Ian Mike were taken by an unknown suspect reportedly driving a maroon van with tinted windows in Lower Fruitland Monday afternoon. 

Ian was later found after it was reported he was able to escape. Shawn Mike said he spoke to Ian and told him to continue to pray . 

"I talked to him and I encouraged him and said that, 'God was with you and allowed you to escape,' said Shawn. 

Shawn Mike also said the suspect, who has been said to be a Native American man in his 30s, tried to also lure his son in his vehicle along with Ashlynne and Ian.

"He actually tried to entice my son to go also," he said. "We need to better stress to children the importance of staying away from strangers." 

Mike said right now the family is in shock after they had been hoping for a better outcome.  They will have a candlelight vigil at 6 p.m. at San Juan Chapter House tonight. 

"If anything please keep the family in your prayers," said Shawn Mike. "You can't imagine this happening in your community so close to your home. The family is in shock."
A sample of sights and sounds from the grand entries at the 33rd annual Gathering of Nations Powwow, held April 27-30 in Albuquerque. (Navajo Times | Adron Gardner)

status_message:
Begaye, Bates blast EPA at hearing
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — Navajo Nation President Russell Begaye and Speaker LoRenzo Bates blasted the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at a field hearing in Phoenix Friday regarding the Gold King Mine Spill.
Over the eight months since the spill, Begaye told the Senate Indian Affairs Committee, "the USEPA has avoided any real sense of accountability for its actions, even though it repeatedly and publicly claimed responsibility last fall."
Among other things, Begaye charged that the EPA has yet to fully compensate the Navajo Nation or individual Navajo farmers; that it has yet to designate the Upper Animas Mining District as a Superfund site and that it has not given the Navajo Nation the tools it needs to conduct its own testing and mitigate future impacts.
Bates, who represents most of the chapters affected by the spill, said the EPA must provide "assurances and tangible evidence" to Navajo farmers that their livestock and agricultural products will be safe for sale and consumption.
He added that the different entities testing the water were providing inconsistent information, which confuses the public.
"I urge all of the entities involved in monitoring the Animas River and the San Juan River to coordinate and to speak with one consistent voice when informing the Navajo people," he said.
Both leaders stressed that the river is important to Navajo spirituality.
"The spill has contaminated or destroyed many of the essential elements of our
religious practice, and desecrated a river that we have treated with reverence since time
immemorial," Bates said.
Mathy Stanislaus, assistant administrator of the Office of Land and Emergency Management within the EPA, testified that the agency has already spent $22 million on response efforts and planned to do more, including continued monitoring of the river, fish and soil, and providing support for the Navajo Environmental Protection Agency.
"We are currently reviewing additional costs incurred by the Navajo government," he said.
Stanislaus admitted that the agency "could improve its communications regarding releases and other environmental events that affect multiple jurisdictions."

status_message:
Ranchers scramble to get cattle back
 

By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
KYKOTSMOVI, Ariz. — Four Navajo ranchers must raise over $4,000 and procure enough stock trailers to move 66 head of cattle by 9 a.m. tomorrow (Tuesday) in order to get their cattle out of impoundment.
The cows were impounded last Tuesday by Hopi Rangers who said John Benally, Irene Benally, Ruth Benally and Lita O'Daniel did not have current permits to run cattle on Hopi Partitioned Land.
"They (the cattle) were trespassing on HPL land," explained Lt. Virgil Platero of the Hopi Rangers. "Our policy is to impound them, and if no one gets them out of impound in five days, we take them to auction."
The five days are up tomorrow, and after meeting with Priscilla Pavatea, director of the Hopi Office of Rangeland Management, the Navajos were given until 9 a.m. tomorrow to raise $4,284 plus whatever impoundment fees accrue overnight and take the cattle somewhere else.
Grassroots activist Elouise Brown, who is advocating for the ranchers, said Monday evening a safe place for the cattle has been secured and she is trying to get the Navajo Department of Agriculture to supply some cattle trucks to move the herd.
O'Daniel said she had failed to renew her permit because she was in the hospital following a car accident. Irene Benally said she is willing to renew her permit, originally obtained by her mother and never officially transferred, but was told it would not be ready until next year.
"Where am I supposed to put my cows in the meantime?" she asked.
Added O'Daniel, whose Angus bull was impounded, "The tribe is always buying land. Why can't they give us some land for our cattle?"
Those who want to help or follow the situation may visit the Facebook page "Emergency on HPL-BIA war against Navajo Grandmothers" or call 505-592-1453.

status_message:
Police seek info on suspected shooter at TCUSD 

By Krista Allen 

      TUBA CITY – Police are looking for the suspect in a shooting that occurred within the Tuba City Unified School District on Friday afternoon. 
      Someone used a CO2 – carbon dioxide, or compressed air – powered pellet gun to shoot out four school bus windows, a TCUSD security said Friday evening. 
      Rosanda Suetopka, spokesperson for TCUSD, said in a statement that the incident occurred around 3 p.m. while students were loaded on a departing bus. 
      No one was hurt, a Tuba City Police District spokesperson said. "But it was somebody shooting a BB gun." 
Suetopka also stated that the school busses were escorted off district by police units and continued along bus routes. 
      The police is investigating the incident. 
      The suspect's vehicle is being described as a gray-silver Hyundai Sonata with tinted windows. The vehicle was last seen near Tuba City Junior High School, traveling eastbound on a dirt road. Anyone with information is asked to call TCPD at 928-283-3111.

Human remains removal case goes back to court
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — A case involving human remains removed from Canyon de Chelly has been remanded to U.S. District Court for Arizona.
On April 6, the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the district court's dismissal of the case, saying the National Park Service's letter refusing to turn the remains over to the Navajo Nation was "final agency action," and thus obligates the U.S. Government to waive its sovereign immunity in the case.
The U.S. Department of the Interior had claimed the government was protected by sovereign immunity and could not be sued in this instance.
The Navajo Nation claims that over 300 human remains were removed from the canyon over the years following archeological expeditions. They are currently housed at the Western Archeological and Conservation Center in Tucson. The tribe wants to rebury the remains in Canyon de Chelly.
"The Nation's position is that the Nation has the right of control over the remains because they were removed without its consent from tribal trust lands affirmed as reservation land under the treaty (of 1868)," the Navajo Nation Office of the Attorney General stated in a press release. 
"Therefore, the National Park Service does not have 'possession or control' as required to allow it to conduct a cultural affiliation determination under the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act, the release reads.

By Cindy Yurth
Tseyi' Bureau

CHINLE -- Winslow Police Officer Austin Shipley, a three-year veteran of the Winslow Police Department, is the officer being investigated in connection with the shooting death of a Navajo woman on Easter Sunday, the Arizona Department of Public Safety revealed today. 

The Winslow Police Department had been withholding his name until today.

According to the ADPS, Shipley shot Loreal Tsingine five times after she allegedly threatened him with a pair of scissors during a skirmish near a convenience store about 4 p.m. March 27. He had been trying to arrest her in connection with a shoplifting incident at the store.

The investigation is being done by "a team of competent and experienced state detectives who conduct these types of investigations for other agencies regularly throughout the state of Arizona," according to ADPS spokesman Raul Garcia. 

Garcia said investigators "have spent much of the last week in Winslow interviewing leads and conducting follow up."

status_message:
Gusting winds flips plane in Shiprock

By Sunnie R. Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
FRUITLAND— An aerial sightseeing trip came to an unexpected end Monday morning when high winds turned over a propeller plane that left one passenger hospitalized.
The plane successfully landed on the runway at Shiprock Airport around 11:30 a.m., before winds flipped it over, according to Navajo Department of Transportation Senior Public Information Officer Carl Slater.
Slater said the pilot of the plane, Joe Tumminaro, was transported to San Juan Regional Medical Center for non-life threatening injuries, while passenger Ryan Arroyo, walked away from the incident, but received medical attention as a precaution.
"They came out here to do some sightseeing," Slater said. "They landed and high winds flipped it over as it was moving down the runway. The crash was after it already landed."
At about 7 p.m., Slater said the plane had been removed and Navajo D.O.T crew was cleaning up debris from the runway. He added that the airport would reopen at 8 a.m., Friday morning.
Slater said Tumminaro and Arroyo, both from Durango, Colo., were on a sightseeing trip when they landed on the airstrip.
He said the winds were strong enough to roll the plane over once before it came to a standstill. First responders showed up shortly after. Slater said Tumminaro needed assistance getting out of the plane while Arroyo was able to get out on his own.
Slater said NNDOT was made aware of the incident at about 2:15 p.m., and NNDOT officials then alerted the Federal Aviation Administration and National Transportation Safety Board.
He said both the FAA and NTSB will look into the incident and the FAA will conduct their own investigation from their headquarters in Chicago.
"They're not going to come out because they don't think it was severe enough to take a look into," he said.
As of Monday evening, San Juan Regional Medical Center spokeswoman Laura Werbner said Tumminaro remained hospitalized.
"We do have him and he is here at San Juan Regional Medical Center in serious condition," she said.

status_message:
UPDATE

Weapon was scissors in Winslow shooting, DPS confirms

By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau

 

            CHINLE — A spokesman for the Arizona Department of Public Safety has confirmed the Navajo woman shot to death by a Winslow Police officer Sunday was armed with a weapon "described to us as scissors."

            Raul Garcia also confirmed Loreal Tsingine, 27, was shot five times by one of the two officers at the scene. The Winslow Police Department has not released the officer's name, but stated in a press release he is on administrative leave.

            According to the press release, Tsingine struggled with police who were trying to arrest her on suspicion of shoplifting at a Circle K convenience store, and threatened an officer with a weapon.

            The incident is under investigation by the DPS's Major Crimes District.

Officer placed on leave after shooting

 

By Cindy Yurth

Tséyi' Bureau

 

            CHINLE — The Winslow Police officer who shot and killed a 27-year-old Navajo woman Sunday has been placed on administrative leave pending an investigation, according to a press release from the Winslow Police Department.

            The release states Loreal Tsingine of Winslow was shot while struggling with an officer who was trying to take her into custody as a suspect in a shoplifting incident at the Circle K store at 323 North Williamson Ave.

            According to the release, police had responded to the shoplifting call about 4 p.m. and found Tsingine, who fit the description employees gave of the shoplifter, in the 100 block of West Fourth Street.

            "While attempting to take the subject into custody, a struggle ensued," the release reads. "At this time the subject displayed a weapon which presented a substantial threat to the officer. The officer discharged his weapon resulting in the unfortunate death" of Tsingine.

            Arizona Department of Public Safety spokesman Raul Garcia would neither confirm nor deny Facebook posts alleging Tsingine's weapon was a pair of scissors.

            "We have already released all of the information available at this time," Garcia wrote in an email. "The investigation is in the preliminary stages."

            An employee who answered the phone at the Winslow Police Department would not release the name of the officer involved and referred this reporter to Garcia for any further information.

            The incident is being investigated by DPS's Major Crimes District.

            "We are confident that DPS will be conducting a thorough and unbiased investigation," states the release. "The Winslow Police Dept. wishes to express our deepest sympathies to Miss Tsingine's family the officers and the community of Winslow."

            Meanwhile, the family is still trying to "piece together what happened," said the victim's aunt, Shundeen Smith, who described Tsingine as "a loving, happy and beautiful mother of one and a wife."

            The family has set up a Gofundme account for Tsingine's funeral expenses at https://www.gofundme.com/loreal. Another account is posted but Smith said this account, set up by the victim's brother, is the only one authorized by close family members.
