status_message:
Begay to lose council seat after being found guilty of slush fund charges

By Bill Donovan
Special to the Times

    WINDOW ROCK - It took a Navajo jury less than two and a half hours, including a supper break, to find Navajo Nation Council Delegate Mel Begay guilty of all charges.
    Begay, who represents Coyote Canyon, Mexican Springs, Naschitti, Tohatchi and Bahastl'a'a' chapter, sat quietly as he watched Window Rock District Court Judge Carol Perry read from each of the 10 charges and pronounced him guilty.
    Because of the conviction, he will lose his seat on the council and may even get a possible jail sentence, which would make him the first sitting council delegate to ever be sent to tribal jail.
    He will also face having to make restitution of the $33,000 that he was accused of taking from the tribal discretionary fund program and giving to his children between 2006 and 2010.
    That's going to be a lesser burden because when he is removed from the council, he will be eligible for his deferred comp which, given the years he has been in office will be somewhere in the neighborhood of $75,000 to $85,000.
    Perry scheduled Begay's sentencing for May 17. Until then he will continue to be released on his own recognizance.

status_message:
Navajo and Apache counties pick Trump, Clinton; Coconino feels the Bern
 

By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — Unofficial election results show two of the three counties that overlap the Navajo Nation have chosen Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton as the Republican and Democratic nominees for President, respectively, in the Arizona Presidential preference election.
The results mirror the rest of the state so far, with 404 of 487 districts reporting.
Coconino County, however, was bucking the Democratic trend, with Bernie Sanders ahead of Clinton by more than 1,200 votes. Ninety-one percent of its precincts had reported as of 11 p.m.
Among registered Democrats in Navajo county, Clinton logged 2,121 votes to Bernie Sanders' 1,278, not quite a two-to-one margin. Martin J. O'Malley trailed with 80 votes, followed fairly closely by Roque De La Fuente (58), Michael Steinberg (55) and Henry Hewes (37).
Navajo County Republicans picked Trump over Ted Cruz by a similar margin, 2,360 to 1,739. Marco Rubio was a distant third at 616 votes, followed by John R.Kasich with 292 and Ben Carson with 236. The rest of the field was in single or double digits.
Apache County gave Trump a narrower lead, 1,724 to 1,336 for Cruz, and Kasich was the third-place finisher there with 202 votes. Democrats chose Hillary (3,010) over Sanders (1,562).
Coconino, which includes Flagstaff and is by far the most populous of the rez counties, gave Sanders 6,941 votes to Clinton's 5,738. If the results hold up after all the precincts have reported, it will be the only Arizona County to go for Sanders.
The county's Republicans, however, followed Arizona's trend, with 3,324 for Trump, 2,843 for Cruz and 1,058 for Rubio.
So far, Arizona as a whole is overwhelming opting for Trump (206,544 votes, or 46 percent) and Clinton (210,026 or 60 percent) over Cruz (101,208, 23 percent) and Sanders (130,248, 37 percent) in their respective races.
In the Green Party primary, Jill Stein had a commanding lead with 505 votes to Kent Mesplay's 108.
Navajo County picks Trump, Clinton
link_name: Navajo County picks Trump, Clinton - Navajo Times

status_message:
Sanders and Clinton neck-and-neck at Window Rock

By Cindy Yurth
Tseyi' Bureau

 WINDOW ROCK  — An informal exit poll at the Navajo Nation Museum, the polling place in the Navajo Nation's capital, showed Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton in a dead heat among Democratic voters in Arizona's Presidential preference election between 2 and 3 p.m.
 In general, voters under 40 were feeling the Bern while those middle-aged and up were leaning toward Clinton.
 Only two Republican voters surfaced during that time (at least among those who would talk to a Times reporter). One voted for Donald Trump while the other marked her ballot for Ohio Gov. John Kasich.
 Davis Begaye, who at 18 was voting in his first Presidential election, typified Sanders' supporters. 
 "All these others are funded by big companies," he said, "so they'll give them more leeway. If you're for the people, like Bernie, you do things like fix the roads and improve the schools."
 "He's more about helping the people than big business," echoed Shunah Sandoval, 29, who happened to have taken her daughter to the museum but planned to vote in her home chapter of Rock Springs, N.M.
 The elder crowd, like Louis Begay, 67, remembered Clinton from her stint as head of Legal Services Corp. in the 1970s, when she helped establish DNA People's Legal Services.
 "She knows us," said Begay.
 A handful of female voters admitted they voted for Clinton because they are ready to see a woman president.
 "Give a lady a chance!" urged a cheery matron who declined to give her name. "People are saying a lady can't be a leader. But that's mostly men saying that."
 The lone Trump supporter to brave the dusty wind gave only his first name, Wally. 
 "I think he's the one who can change everything around," Wally said. "We need to get this nation back on track."
 A middle-aged Republican who declined to give her name, on the other hand, said she went for Kasich because "I'm not voting for Donald Trump, that's for sure."
 While southern Arizona news sources were reporting long lines at the polls, the flow at Window Rock was slow but steady. Polls on the Navajo Nation will close at 6 p.m. (an hour earlier than the rest of Arizona because of the time difference). According to the Arizona Secretary of State's website, results should start being posted at 8 p.m.Arizona time, which is 9 p.m. on the Navajo Nation.
 Utah is also holding its primaries today.

status_message:
High winds expected for the Navajo Nation 

Winds up to 70 miles per hour are forecast for parts of the Navajo Nation tonight and tomorrow.

The National Weather Service has issued a high wind advisory for Black Mesa, the Chinle Valley and the Little Colorado River Valley until 7 p.m. Tomorrow, with a high wind warning for the Chuska Mountains and Defiance Plateau. A high wind watch is in effect for the New Mexico side of the Chuskas until 9 a.m. March 23. 

For more weather in your area, check with your local TV stations.

status_message:
Twin Arrows to host Bernie Sanders

By Christopher S. Pineo

Navajo Times

 

WINDOW ROCK – U.S. Presidential candidate Bernie Sanders will make an appearance at the Twin Arrows Casino in Flagstaff on Thursday. 

            Doors open to the public at 5 p.m. and the event is free. According to the Sanders campaign website, the event will be a town hall style event.

            Tickets are not required, but guests are encouraged to RSVP at go.berniesanders.com/page/event/detail/rally/4gwr8. Admission is on a first come, first serve basis and guests should enter the casino by the main east doors of the building.

            For security reasons, guests should not bring bags and limit items carried into the event to small, personal items like keys and cell phones. Weapons, sharp objects, chairs, and signs or banners on sticks will not be allowed through security. Parking will be available on-site.

            Derrick Watchman, CEO of Navajo Nation Gaming Enterprise, told the Navajo Times Wednesday that the Sanders campaign contacted Navajo gaming officials on Tuesday. He also reacted to the news that the campaign would be making a stop on the nation.

"I'm excited," said Watchman. "They reached out to our general manager saying they would like to use our facility because it's on the reservation and it's close to Flagstaff. I'm delighted and excited that they're coming out tomorrow."

He said he would welcome any and all use of casino facilities for such events.

"It's good business for us," he said.

status_message:
Lady Pirates end state title drought with win over Rock Point

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

PRESCOTT VALLEY, Ariz. – After four years of chasing a state title that pursuit came to an end for the Valley Lady Pirates on Saturday morning at the Prescott Valley Events Center.

The top seeded Lady Pirates defeated No. 3 seed Rock Point, 77-40, to claim this year's Arizona Division V title and capped the year at 28-1.

With the win, the Lady Pirates girls' basketball team became the first sports program to win a team championship according to athletic director Marcus Forrester.

In 2013, the Pirates lost the Divison III state title to Winslow by a 45-40 count and last season they came up six points short in the Division IV finals against Phoenix Christian.

"This feels pretty exciting," said Valley senior guard Latisha Nastacio. "I am happy that we won this year; last year it was heartbreaking."

Nastacio finished the game with 15 but the Pirates got some inspired play from junior Cherelle Speen as she scored 19 points in the opening half as Valley gained a 46-19 advantage at the break.

"I wanted to come out and do this for the team," said Speen, who finished with a game-best 23 points. "I was really motivated by my team and the fans that supported us."

Valley coach Dorothy Mitchell said the entire team played up to their potential to beat sectional rival Rock Point for the third time this season. 

"The bench also came in and made some key shots and they were playing defense," she said. "They all worked together as a team."

The Valley coach said the focus from the get go was to contend every shot and make Rock Point work for every made basket.

"We wanted to shut down the three-point shooters," she said, while adding that they gave multiple looks on the defensive end.

"We changed everything around and they went with it," she said.

Valley also had freshman guard Valiyah Yazzie in double figures with 13.

Rock Point got 14 points from Pashen Johnson while Crystanya Begay added 12.

Lady Cougar coach Lorna Tsosie said it was unfortunate that her team experienced a bad shooting day, especially after they averaged 64.5 points in their first three state playoff games.

"Our shots were not falling for us, especially our threes," Tsosie said. "They tried though. They went up against the odds with all that pressure on them."

For a more in-depth story and photos pick up Thursday's Navajo Times.

Ganado shoots its way into Division IV finals

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

PRESCOTT VALLEY, Ariz. – The Ganado Lady Hornets had to steadied itself to get by top seeded Phoenix Christian on Friday night.

The Hornets hit 11-of-14 free throws in the fourth quarter and held off the Lady Cougars 39-35 in the semifinals of the Division IV state girls basketball tournament at the Prescott Events Center in Prescott Valley, Ariz.

No. 5 Ganado will play No. 2 seed Thatcher in the finals on Saturday at 2 p.m. Thatcher defeated Sedona Red Rock, 58-46, on their side of the bracket.

"That team has talented athletes and that is why they were ranked No. 1 the whole season," Ganado coach Mike Bitsuie said of the Lady Cougars. "But my girls were not scared and we knew that we could take it to them and we knew that we could beat them."

After taking down Arizona Lutheran by a 52-36 count on Thursday night, Bitsuie said that 16-point victory instilled some much-needed confidence for Friday's game.

"You know they only had two losses but numbers are just numbers," he said. "We knew we could do it and I am just so proud of the girls on how they played tonight."

Bitsuie said hitting those free throws down the stretch were huge, especially since the Hornets hit a lull at the start of the third quarter. Ganado missed six baskets, including four threes and did not score until junior JaeLynn Curley knocked down a pair of free throws at the 2:41 mark.

"It's hard to get that first one because they (Phoenix Christian) are athletic and tall," Bitsuie said. "It's hard to do our normal cuts and get our passes because they are so lengthy."

The flow of the game went Ganado's way midway through the fourth quarter as they erased a 30-26 deficit with five minutes left in regulation. Some key steals by the Hornets changed the complexion of the game as a two-point bucket from senior post Tierra James helped start a 9-0 run.

During that stretch Curley hit 4-of-6 free throws and finished with 10 points.

Senior Chasity Gorman capped the run with Ganado leading 35-30 with 1:14 left in regulation.

Phoenix Christian made it one possession game when senior guard Mariah Leary converted an old-fashion three-point play with 52 seconds left as Leary led all scorers with 21 points.

Nevertheless, Ganado sealed the victory by connecting on four free throws. For the game Ganado hit 17-of-22 from the charity line.

"We shot too many threes and when they didn't go in (the Cougars) got rebounds and they made some shots in transition," Bitsuie said. "I told them lets get in the bonus so that we can shoot free throws. We finally did that and I am so proud of them."

status_message:
Lady Scouts stun Page in quarterfinals

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

GLENDALE, Ariz. – A new Division III girls champion will be crowned on Saturday night.

Window Rock's defensive performance powered the Lady Scouts to a 41-39 upset win over Page in Thursday's quarterfinal game at the Gila River Arena in Glendale, Ariz.

In other quarterfinal action, the No. 4 seed Chinle Lady Wildcats advanced with a 48-37 win over No. 5 Safford. Top seeded Chandler Valley Christian took care of Winslow, 57-47, while No. 3 seed Phoenix South Mountain defeated No. 6 Pueblo Magnet, 64-33.

In Friday's semifinals, No. 7 seed Window Rock will play South Mountain at 1:45 p.m. while Valley Christian and Chinle will square off at 5:15 p.m. The winners will advance into Saturday's championship game. Tipoff is scheduled for 6:30 p.m. in Glendale.

Window Rock held the defending state champions to 12-of-53 shooting, which included a 1-for-11 effort in the opening quarter. The Scouts also forced three early turnovers and converted them for points for a 12-2 advantage after one quarter of play.

"With our press we got them to turn it over at the start," Window Rock coach Mac Beach said. "That got us clicking and that got everybody's confidence going.

"We worked together as a team and today that worked for us," he added.

The Scouts led from start to finish but they withstood a furious rally from Page as the Sand Devils cut an 11-point deficit down to 41-39 with 24 seconds on a putback from junior guard Ariel Austin. 

On Page's next possession, the Sand Devils had three different looks to either win it or send the game into overtime. Needless to say, junior post Kaitlynn Begay missed her three-point attempt and the two offensive boards Page collected fell to the wayside.

"We beat them in every statistical category except shooting," Page coach Justin Smith said. "That is how we lost the game."

Page senior Ashley Dempsey turned in a double-double performance with 12 points and 16 boards.

Window Rock, meanwhile, had senior post Alicia Hale finish with 10 points and 10 boards. Senior Triana Francis and sophomore Venessa James added nine and seven, respectively.

Beach said he's expecting another tough matchup with South Mountain and he's hoping they can stop shooting guard Najiyyah Pack from going ballistic.

"Tomorrow is going to be a different game," Beach said. "We just have to make sure No. 30 (Pack) does not kill us."

In the earlier game, the Wildcats held a good Safford squad to three points in the final quarter. That superb effort actually started in the third quarter as Chinle battled back from a seven-point deficit and tied the game at 34-all going into the fourth.

"We had a good first quarter and in the second and third we struggled a little bit," Chinle coach Pete Butler said, while adding that run in the third quarter changed the momentum of the game.

"They picked it up," he said. "We pressured the ball more, we doubled team more and we got some good steals. Defense won the game tonight and that is the one thing we pride ourselves in."

As a team Chinle finished with 15 steals with junior guard Nahatabaa Nacona collecting eight steals to go along with her 12 points and seven boards.

Junior Quannah Ryan added 10 points while seniors Kalli Hunter and Nikesha Eagleman helped out with nine points each.
link_name: Photos from Navajo Times's post

status_message:
Winslow boys reach semifinals

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

GLENDALE, Ariz. – With a timeout to burn, Winslow coach Scott Corum gave Mingus Union Gerardo Angulo some time to think about his free throw attempt.

With three seconds left in regulation, Angulo had missed his first attempt of a two-foul shot that prompted Corum to sidetrack the Mingus Union post player.

That brief timeout seemed to work as Angulo's last attempt hit the back end of the rim as Winslow escaped with 50-49 victory in the quarterfinals of the Arizona Division III state playoffs at the Gila River Arena in Glendale, Ariz.

"We called a timeout to make him think about it," Corum said. "We drew up a play just in case he made it. Unfortunately for him he missed but for us we secured the rebound."

With the one-point victory, Winslow advances into the Final Four round and will play top seed Goodyear Estrella Foothills at 7 p.m. Friday night at the arena in Glendale. Estrella Foothills took care of No. 9 seed Yuma Cibola 69-55.

The winner advances in Saturday's 7:30 p.m. championship game.

After leading 13-10 at the close of the first stanza, Winslow put together its best quarter of the game by outscoring Mingus Union 15 to 7. Nate Hollins led Winslow's attack as the junior guard put in five of his eight points in that stanza with the Bulldogs leading 28-17 at the break.

That 11-point deficit did not faze the 22-8 Mingus team. The Marauders got three inside buckets from Angulo while teammates Fabian Navarro and Ashton Loring both hit two crucial treys to pull Mingus within 36-35 heading into the fourth.

The lead changed hands five times in that final quarter with Navarro pacing Mingus with five of his team-best 16 points.

His trey at the 0:49 mark earned Mingus a brief 49-48 lead.

The Bulldogs, however, got the eventual game-winning basket by senior guard Dalvin Benally with 21 seconds left. Benally hit a close range shot after teammate Akeem Foster dribbled through the top of the key and found Benally open for a shot.

Winslow hit two earlier buckets in that manner and erased a 44-40 deficit midway through the fourth quarter.

"We wanted to attack that zone and I think we were settling for too many threes," Corum said. "Late in the game we started being aggressive and we dished out to the open guys."

Corum was proud of the way his team held their composure as they turned in a gutsy performance.

"Things didn't go our way in the second half but we found a way to persevere," he said.

Junior guard Nathan Hanley led the Bulldogs with 16 points. Winslow also had Rory Billie, Hollins and Foster finish with eight.

In other Division III action, Scottsdale Christian ended Window Rock's season by hitting 20-of-44 field goals en route to a 54-34 win.

Scottsdale Christian built an early 16-0 lead and never looked back as hey had eight players score including three in double figures. Freshman center Ethan Spry led the way with 13 points. Senior forward Brad Swetonic and freshman guard Reed Myers both finished with 10 points.

Senior guard Shammond Goodman led Window Rock with 10 points while senior post Myron Wauneka racked up eight points and 10 rebounds.

Windy Thursday expected for parts of the reservation 

Navajo Times

             WINDOW ROCK - A weather alert was issued Wednesday for the Chinle and Chuska Mountain areas predicting high winds in those areas all day Thursday.
            The National Weather service out of Flagstaff said the winds will begin after sunrise and will get worst throughout the day with winds of 20-35 miles per hour gushing up to 40 to 55 miles per hour later in the day.
            These winds can make driving difficult especially for high profile vehicles, the weather service said, adding that residents would be advised to secure any loose belongings on their property.

status_message:
TC schools closed tomorrow to get rid of rodents 

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

TUBA CITY – Tuba City Unified School District schools will be closed tomorrow (Friday, Feb. 12) to take care of an apparent rodent infestation, according to Harold Begay, superintendent of schools at TCUSD.
In a letter written to parents today, Begay wrote that there is evidence of rodent harborage in various parts of school buildings district-wide. And as a result of these reports, the district is working with Coconino County Health Dept., Tuba City Regional Health Care Corp., and University Termite & Pest to clean up. 
The district had its first pest case last Wednesday, according to Cheryl Barlow, superintendent and board secretary.
Barlow said the district contacted Angie Maloney, environmental health director of the Arizona Division of Environmental Health Services, to do an inspection. Maloney, however, denied the district. 
"So we called (University Termite & Pest from Flagstaff)," Barlow said. "And they inspected every room in every building." 
Begay said that the district is taking measures so that the pest control service, along with the maintenance and the custodial staff, will have the time tomorrow and the three-day weekend to thoroughly clean and remove any evidence of rodent harborage. 
Begay also said the County and TCRHCC are also assisting the pest control service in further inspection of school facilities to mitigate and to abate any evidence of pest and rodent infestation. 
"Plus, we're looking for any holes in the buildings," Barlow said. "(Workers) will enclose those. And they're going to pull furniture away from the walls to check corners, vents, and outlets." 
At Tuba City High School this evening, members of the staff were moving things away from the walls and cleaning up. 
"They'll be fumigating the building," receptionist Michelle Nutumya said as she disinfected office surfaces. 
Begay said pests and rodents though are nothing new. 
"It's always ongoing, different pest problems," Begay said. "Especially with rodent droppings, which is a serious public health issue. We're not going to tolerate additional reporting or any (pest and rodent) evidence."
"This isn't anything new," he continued. "I just want to get it cleaned and stopped." 
And there's a way to do that, which is pest control, but the district has to wait until school is out for the summer for preventative measures.
Schools within the TCUSD will resume on a normal schedule Tuesday, Feb. 16.

status_message:
Tuba City, Window Rock boys advance 

By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times

CHINLE - With an at large berth on the line, the Tuba City Warriors increased its chances of making the Division III state basketball tournament. 

The Warriors posted a huge 65-61 win over Holbrook in opening round of the sectional tournament at the Wildcat Den in Chinle on Wednesday. 

"We're on that bubble whether we make it or not but the big motivation was we had to come out, we had to execute and do what we needed to do," Tuba City coach Ryan Brown said. "Fortunately, we did that. We showed up tonight and the defensive intensity was there."

On the other side of the bracket, the Monument Valley Mustangs fell to Window Rock by 62-60 count on a last-second shot by junior Tyrese Brown. That basket by Brown may have cost MV's chances of making state as the Mustangs are on the outside looking in.

On Friday, Window Rock plays No. 2 seed Winslow at 5:15 p.m. while Tuba City will take on top seed Snowflake with the winner's advancing into Saturday's championship game. 

The state seating committee will release the state tournament bracket this weekend with the top 24 teams making state. 

"We're sitting at No. 29, but hopefully the other teams will lose down the stretch," Monument Valley coach Anderson Holiday said, while adding that they lost a few close games to some of the top teams in Division III. 

"These tough losses really took a toll on us," Holiday said. 

In Wednesday's contest the Mustangs got off to a great start with Royce Charley and Kane Parrish combining for 20 points in the opening quarter as the Mustangs led 20-14. 

Holiday said his club shot the ball very well by being patient on offense. In addition, he said his kids stuck to the game plan defensively. 

Despite turning the ball over six times in the next period, MV closed out the first half on a 7-2 run after Window Rock momentarily gained a 27-26 lead on a basket by senior post Myron Wauneka. 

In that run the Mustangs hit four free throws and got a three-point basket by Merwin Sullivan. 

After the break Window Rock capitalized on a few Mustang turnovers and regained the lead at 40-37 on a three-point shot by Casey Billy. Nonetheless, the Mustangs managed to tie the game at 42 all at the end of the third quarter. 

The game remained tight as both teams went back and forth before the Scouts opened a 57-50 advantage with 2:05 left in the game on a putback by Brown.

Window Rock coach Raul Mendoza said they gave up too many open looks but he felt they gave a better effort in the second half to gain that seven-point advantage late in the game.

"They shot the ball very well," he said of MV. "Defense has been our strength all year but tonight we seemed like we were not ready to play defense. We became impatient." 

The Scouts did receive a scare late in the game when MV's Mitch Hurley hit three consecutive treys and tied the game at 60-all with six seconds left in the game. Rather than call a timeout, Mendoza allowed his players to make the final call as Brown hit a baseline drive just as time expired.

"If we didn't get a good shot right off the back I was going to call a timeout," Mendoza. "Fortunately, we did something right for once. We got the ball to the open man and made a layup."

In the earlier game, the Warriors withstood a 19-point first half effort turned in by Holbrook's Abrian Dixon. Dixon scored 14 of those points in the opening quarter that earned his team a 17-16 lead. 

The Warriors, however, used a 15-0 run that started at the tail end of the first quarter into the second to gain a 31-22 halftime cushion. 

"We made some adjustments to how our game plan was set up," Brown said. "We wanted to pressure the guards up on top. They were still getting some open looks whether we were in a zone or matching up."

Nonetheless, Brown said they contested most of those shots as he eluded to Dixon's outburst.

"We knew that we needed to really watch where he was on the floor at all times," Brown said of Dickson. "When we made that big push we were moving and being active on defensive, and we able to produce some points as well."

Brown felt that Joey Mathias lifted the team offensively as a sophomore scored eight of his 17 points in that run. 

In the second half, the Warriors built a 46-36 lead with 2:36 left in the third quarter after Urijah Yazzie capped a 10-6 run. 

To their credit, Holbrook got within a few buckets in the fourth quarter, but Tuba City answered each run with a basket to regain the momentum. 

"They have the shooters and guards to make that push from time to time but we were able to get some stops and get the momentum going," Brown said. "We were able to get that going late in that third and we were able to make a run for ourselves." 

Davian Yazzie led with 21 points while Mathias had 17. For Holbrook Dixon finished with 27 points, which included 7 treys.

status_message:
Code Talker Alfred Peaches passes
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
DURANGO, Colo. — Code Talker Alfred James Peaches passed away on Jan. 16 at the Flagstaff Medical Center, according to a press release from the Navajo Nation President and Vice President's Office.
He was 90.
A memorial service will be held at 11 a.m. Jan. 23 at Leupp First Presbyterian Church, with the Ira H. Hayes American Legion Post 84 providing color guard and the Navajo Hopi Honor Riders escorting.
Peaches was born on April 28, 1925 in Shonto, Ariz. to the late Adelaide Donald and Henry Peaches, the release states.
He was Bitter Water Clan born for White Corn Clan. His maternal grandfather was Water's Edge and his paternal grandfather was Zuni.
Peaches served in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1943 to 1946, attaining the rank of corporal, according to the release. He served again in the Korean War.
He is survived by his wife, Jeanette Hillis Peaches, daughters Doris Ross and Terri Peaches, and sons Glenn and Nathaniel Peaches, as well as five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Two sons, Vernon and Albert, preceded him in death.
President Russell Begaye has ordered flags on the Navajo Nation to be flown at half-staff on Jan. 23.
"The Navajo people have lost another warrior that defended freedom and the American way of life during World War II," Begaye stated in the release.
Vice President Jonathan Nez, who hails from Peaches' home chapter of Shonto, said the legacy of Peaches and the other Code Talkers can be carried on by preserving the Navajo language.
Peaches' daughters issued a statement thanking the "excellent" nurses and staff at the Flagstaff Medical Center for their care of their father while he was there.

status_message:
Police seek info on suspected child abductor

By Christopher Pineo
Navajo Times

On Jan. 14, Window Rock Unified School District notified local parents through Facebook of an attempted child abduction that happened in Gallup on Tuesday. The Facebook post said it was reported that an older gentleman was trying to lure children in his white van at local bus stops. The post assured the public that the staff at the school, aware of the alert, would remain vigilant in ensuring the children's safety.

The school encouraged parents to discuss this topic with their children tonight.

On Jan. 12 at about 7 a.m. at a school bus stop in the area of the Cedar Hills Apartments, a white box van occupied by at least one male individual was seen attempting to entice a child into the vehicle according to Gallup officials. Witnesses said the man had a foreign accent. The nationality of the man is unknown at this time. The vehicle was last seen traveling east from Cedar Hills Drive turning south onto South Second Street.

Superintendent Lynette Michalski noted the distance of the school from Gallup, but said it was important to notify parents and the public anyway.

"We sent out that notice just to let our parents know. Keep a watchful eye," Michalski said.

Anyone with information is asked to notify local law enforcement if they see anything suspicious, or call Crime Stoppers in Gallup at 505-722-6161.

Both vehicles in photographs provided by the city matched the description given by the child, and were in the area during the time of the incident. Note that one vehicle in the photographs has an access door on the passenger-side wall of the box.

status_message:
To'hajiilee, Alamo Navajo boys to renew rivalry in SENAI tourney finals
 
By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times
 
ALBUQUERQUE – There will be a huge game basketball game on Saturday at the University of New Mexico's Johnson Arena.
With a pair of wins in Friday's semifinals, the To'hajiilee Warriors will renew its rivalry with nearby Alamo Navajo in the championship game of the small schools bracket at the 5th annual Striking Eagle Native American Invitational. Tipoff is scheduled for 2:30 p.m.
"It's a big thing for both communities," To'hajiilee coach Roberta Secatero said of the showdown. "There's a lot of excitement when we play them and its something we both enjoy."
Alamo Navajo was the first team to punch its ticket in the championship game as they held off a pesky Navajo Pine squad with a 74-70 win.
The Cougars played one of its finest quarters of the season as they led Navajo Pine 28-13 in the opening stanza.
"Our defense, passing and shot selection were great," Alamo Navajo coach Marcus Pino Jr. said. "We were hitting on all cylinders."
Nevertheless, the final three quarters played out in Navajo Pine's favor with the Warriors drawing within four points at the end of regulation.
"We started to play their game," Pino said of Tohatchi. "They were turning us over and we let them back into the game."
It didn't help that Alamo Navajo lost three starters to fouls and afterward Pino credited the bench for securing the win.
Alamo Navajo had four players finish in double figures with Ben Guerro leading the way with 22 points while Marcus Pino had 13. Shawntel Guerro and Jade Lomahitewa added 11 points apiece.
Late Friday night, To'hajiilee got by Tsé Yi' Gai in their half of the bracket to make the finals with a 61-52 victory.
"They played an awesome game," Secatero said of her squad. "They came together and they worked as a team. That is what we are looking for every game. We want them to find that spark."
The To'hajiilee coach felt that senior point guard Isaac Ignacio carried the team on his shoulders as he finished with 11 points and six assists.
"He took over the leadership role today," she said.
In addition, the Warriors got 14-point efforts from Jayshawn Guerro and
Tyrique Winstead while Trevor Platero added nine.
For Tsé Yi' Gai, Ross Whitehorse finished with 16 points in the losing effort while Jacob Trujillo helped out with 14.
In the large school girls' division, the Tohatchi Lady Cougars will face Monument Valley in Saturday's finals as both teams posted double digit wins. They are scheduled to play at 7:00 p.m.
Monument Valley defeated Grants, 59-40, while the Cougars pulled away from Santa Fe Indian School in the fourth quarter and picked up a 57-45 win.
"We were in a zone (defense) the whole game and then we went man-to-man," Tohatchi coach Tanisha Bitsui said. "Once we went full court it changed the momentum of the game and it was in our favor. We scored off their turnovers."
Bitsui said she is looking forward to facing Monument Valley for the second time this season as her squad defeated the Lady Mustangs by 76-54 count on Jan. 2.
"They stayed with us in the first half," Bitsui said of MV in their last outing. "In the second half the girls really stepped it up defensively and that was how we ran away with it."
In the other brackets, the Monument Valley Mustangs will face SFIS in the big school boys' bracket at 8:30 p.m. while Navajo Prep will take on Cuba in the medium school division in a game scheduled for 5:30 p.m.
The medium girls finals is scheduled for 4 p.m. as Rock Point faces the winner between Newcomb and the Cuba/Whitehorse survivor. In the small schools girls bracket, Tsé Yi' Gai plays Mescalero at 1:00 p.m.

status_message:
More winter weather to hit Navajo Nation

By Christopher S. Pineo

Navajo Times

WINDOW ROCK -- With a couple winter storms in northern Arizona and western New Mexico, the Navajo Nation can expect snow and ice on roads and trails this week.

            According to information from the National Weather Service in Flagstaff and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), northern Arizona and western New Mexico will see two or more storms.

The first storm should escalate in the afternoon and continue until noontime on Wednesday. Areas above 6,000 feet are expected to receive moderate to heavy snowfall.

A colder storm is due to hit the area Wednesday night with periods of moderate to heavy snow lasting until Friday morning. Above 4,000 feet should get snowfall on Thursday night.

In Apache County, a winter weather advisory remains in effect until noon Wednesday and a winter storm watch also remains in effect from Wednesday evening through Friday afternoon. Heavy at times, snow will continue as the colder system moves into the area late Wednesday, and brings snowfall through midday Friday with accumulation of two to seven inches. Elevations above 7,000 feet will get more snow.

Areas of Navajo County and Coconino County have winter weather advisories and winter storm warnings in effect, with parts under hazardous weather outlooks likely to create hazardous driving conditions.

On the New Mexico side, McKinley County, San Juan County, and Sandoval County have both winter weather advisories and winter storm watches in effect.

McKinley County could get between two and seven inches as a series of storms impact the area through Friday.

            San Juan County and Sandoval County could get two to six inches with locally higher amounts on west facing slopes and higher peaks. Snow accumulation is expected until Friday. Heaviest snowfall is expected above 6,500 feet.

Currently, San Juan County in Utah only has a winter weather advisory that remains in effect until midnight, with precipitation most significantly impacting areas above 5,500 feet, including Blanding. Snowfall between three and six inches should continue through the day and decrease in the evening.

            The Four Corners area could get rain according to NOAA.

status_message:
BREAKING 

Police search for robber in Chinle
 
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — Chinle Unified School District schools and teacher housing have been on lockdown since about 1:30 p.m. as police search for a person or persons who robbed the Conoco station adjacent to the Pic 'N' Run convenience store on Navajo Route 7.
At least one suspect is believed to be armed.
The parking lot of the Best Western Motel, adjacent to the Pic 'N' Run, is barricaded and police appeared to be concentrating their search there.
As of 2 p.m., a SWAT team from Window Rock was dispatched to the scene.
No further information is available at this time.

Snow in the forecast of most of the Navajo Nation
 

The National Weather Service is reporting extreme weather conditions in the Four Corners area, beginning Tuesday afternoon and lasting through late Wednesday afternoon.

The prediction is for anywhere from three inches in the lower elevations to six inches in the higher elevations.

Driving throughout Tuesday evening and into the early morning of Wednesday is expected to be hazardous, with snow-packed roads on Tuesday evening and icy roads Wednesday morning.

This is expected to be the worst snowstorm of the winter so far, and the National Weather Service is urging drivers, who have to be on the road during these hours to expect hazardous driving conditions.

To keep in touch with the latest weather news call 1-888-411-7623.

status_message:
Fiber cable damage caused outage for Frontier customers

Navajo Times

WINDOW ROCK - According to a media statement from Frontier Communications, the primary Internet service provider for the Navajo Nation, approximately 8,300 of its customers in the St. Michaels area and parts of Apache County, lost Internet services on Dec. 28 

Frontier Communications officials said the outage was due to a fiber cable outage in the Internet provider CenturyLink's network. According to CenturyLink's website, the company provides broadband, voice, video, data and managed services over a 250,000-route-mile fiber network in the United States.
 
A Frontier spokesperson said its customers could still use phone service to dial locally and long distance, but Internet data transmission was impacted by the outage that began at 9:14 a.m. MST Monday morning.
 
Frontier technicians continue to test its network and communicate with CenturyLink techs throughout the process of restoring service. Frontier said it had not received an estimated time for when service would resume.

status_message: The young brothers Aztlan, 4, left, and Anthony, 3, Champagne from Jeddito, Ariz., who spent a cold night in the woods after getting lost on Oct. 27 stand with their arms around each other Tuesday in St. Michaels. The Navajo Police, Hopi Search and Rescue, Apache County Sheriff's Posse and a helicopter from the Arizona Department of Public Safety searched throughout the night for the two toddlers as temperatures dropped below freezing. On the morning of Oct. 28, the boys' aunt Phildina Tapaha, began searching for her nephews early that morning. After calling out to them, she heard them calling back. Tapaha says the two boys came running out from the trees crying for her. Both boys only sustained minor scratches, and were dehydrated and hungry. Tapaha also added that they battled with zombies and hid from UFOs throughout the night. The Navajo police officers Philbert Toddy and Chris Holgate, who searched for the boys, met with the boys and their family. Holgate said he and fellow officer Toddy gave them toys and treated them out to lunch.

status_message:
Winter storm warning

As much as ten inches of snow, winds blowing more than 40 mph and icy driving conditions are expected for parts of the Navajo Nation in the higher elevations, beginning Tuesday morning and lasting through Christmas, according to the National Weather Service. The Chuska Mountain and the Eastern Agency are forecasted to be impacted the most. Window Rock and Ganado, could also see snow Tuesday morning through Wednesday. State Highway 264 from the New Mexico State line through Ganado, U.S. Highway 491 from Gallup through Tohatchi, and Navajo Route 12, from Window Rock, Ariz., through Tsaile, Ariz., and Navajo Route 9 from Twin Lakes, N.M., to Crownpoint, N.M., could quickly become snow packed and icy due to heavy snowfall and accumulating snow. Occasional snow falls and windy conditions are forecasted to last through the weekend for most of of the reservation. Check your local weather stations for more weather updates in your area. As with any inclement weather during the winter season, prepare for potentially slick and icy roads to exist.

status_message: Monday's afternoon snow and winds brought on very icy conditions for drivers who were caught by surprise. Snow plows eventually salted the roads.

Weather brings snow, icy roads across most of the reservation

GALLUP - Navajo Nation police along with law enforcement agencies in Apache and McKinley County are urging people to stay home tonight because of icy conditions on most of the roads.
    A snowstorm Monday afternoon created near white out and icy conditions on most of the primary roads and all of the secondary roads on the reservation and in the two counties.
    On U.S. Highway 491, traffic in both directions quickly came to a stop around the four mile marker because vehicles started sliding off the road due to a long stretch of extremely icy roads. McKinley County Sheriff's deputies and New Mexico State Police brought out their shovels and began placing dirt on the slippery highway, which helped stuck vehicles trying to gain traction. Traffic backed up for over four miles. 
    Other reports of numerous calls for assistance from motorists kept officers busy with more accidents and slide offs on Interstate 40, State Highway 264 and U.S. Highway 491. Officers as well as paramedics and fire fighters, themselves cautiously responded and had to traverse the roads cautiously. 
    Area schools on the reservation, such as St. Michael Indian School, released their students early from their classes. Schools in McKinley County, Cuba Independent Schools, University of New Mexico - Gallup Campus, Window Rock Unified School Dist. 8, Wingate High School and Wingate Elementary School, Western New Mexico University - Gallup; are all on a two-hour delay. 
Tuba City High School, Monument Valley High School in Kayenta, Ariz., and Page High School are not on two-hour delays. However, Shonto Preparatory School in Shonto, Ariz., will start at 10:30 a.m.
According to Public Information Officer for the Office of President Vice President Mihio Manus, Navajo Nation employees in the Executive Branch are also on a two hour delay.

status_message:
Office of President and Vice President to host public meetings 

By Christopher S. Pineo
Navajo Times

WINDOW ROCK - The Navajo Nation is hosting a series of public forums to discuss the upcoming Navajo Nation Veterans Act. 

The Office of the President and Vice President's veteran's liaison Jamescita Peshlakai and Department of Navajo Veterans Affairs director Edsel Pete hosted veterans and interested community members at two of what the Navajo Nation is calling Veteran Public Hearings this weekend.

At an event this past weekend Peshlakai encouraged veterans, family of veterans, and any interested community members to attend the upcoming events. 

She stressed that the Navajo Nation is looking for community feedback on the act, because it is not finalized yet. 

Upcoming meetings will be Wednesday, December 16 at 12 p.m. in To'nanees'dizi Chapter, 220 Main St., in Tuba City, Friday, December 18 at 12 p.m. at the Navajo Technical University Wellness Center at 371 Lowerpoint Rd. State Highway in Crownpoint, and Saturday, December 19, at 10 a.m.  at the Tohajiilee Senior Center in Tohajiilee, N.M. 

For a more in-depth story, grab your Dec. 17 copy of the Navajo Times newspaper at your nearest newsstand.

status_message:
Tsinigine wins world title

By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times

LS VEGAS, Nev. – A few variables needed to take place for Tuba City, Ariz., cowboy Aaron Tsinigine to win his first world title in the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association ranks.
With a 4.1 run in the 10th round at the 2015 Wrangler National Finals Rodeo at the Thomas & Mack Center in Las Vegas, Nev., Tsinigine placed first in the final round of team roping competition with partner Ryan Motes to push his year-end total to $227,671. 
"Two or three things needed to go our way for me to be here," Tsinigine said. "We needed to win the round, for starters. If I could have picked anyone to be here with me it'd be Ryan Motes, my partner and my best friend."
In the final round of the 10-day event, world runner-up Jake Cooper finished sixth in the round as his partner, Kollin  Vonah,  legged up. They finished with a 9.6 run as that proved to be the difference for Tsinigine to win the world by a mere $2,685.
"This has been a dream since I was a kid," Tsinigine said. When I was growing up on the reservation I would have never dreamed of winning a world championship. Everything's coming true for me tonight."
For a more in-depth story pick up a copy of next week's Navajo Times.

Special to the Times
Bill Donovan 

    WINDOW ROCK - This is the first day that Star Wars fans will be able to purchase the special edition Star Wars Pendleton blanket at the Navajo Nation Museum.
    Because of this, and only for two days, the museum is selling the blanket for $239.99 said Manuelito Wheeler, director of the museum.
    Wheeler said the museum has been receiving a lot of inquiries about the blanket so he expects sales will be brisk.
    The museum has 32 of the blankets in stock and Wheeler said the museum was able to acquire the blankets because of its special relationship with Lucasfilm that began when the museum worked with the studio to put out a version of the first movie in the Navajo language.

Former NN president passes

 
By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

 
TUBA CITY – Leonard Haskie, a former chairman of the Navajo Nation and a former delegate of the 22nd Navajo Nation Council, died on Dec. 6 after a battle with cancer. He was 71.

It was after the tribe suspended Peter MacDonald Sr. as chairman that Haskie, originally from Sanostee, N.M., served as the interim chairman from March 10, 1989 to Jan. 15, 1991.

Haskie finished second to Peterson Zah in the 1990 election for the then newly created post of president of the Navajo Nation.

At that time, Zah defeated Haskie and Steve Darden by a 46-32 percent margin. Haskie-Darden had 16,354 votes.

In 1995, Haskie was hired at Gallup-McKinley County Schools to assume administrative oversight of construction, maintenance and operations, transportation, and food services.

 Last November, he was appointed delegate representing the communities of Beclabito, Cove, Gadííáhí/Tókǫ'í, Red Valley, Toadlena/Two Grey Hills, Tooh Haltsooi, and Tsé 'Ałnáozt'i'í.

Haskie was a civil engineer. He had a bachelor's and a master's in civil engineering. And for a number of years, he was a licensed engineer in Arizona, Utah, and in New Mexico.

Navajo Nation President Russell Begaye and Speaker LoRenzo Bates, along with the 23rd Navajo Nation Council, extended their condolences to Haskie's family.

"Today we learned that one of our former leaders, who had served both as a Navajo Nation Chairman and President, had passed away last night at Northern Navajo Medical Center in Shiprock, N.M.," Begaye said. "Leonard Haskie was a person with a wealth of knowledge that he used to advance the Navajo Nation toward a better future. It was a pleasure to serve with Leonard Haskie during my time as a council delegate on the 22nd Navajo Nation Council."

Stated Bates in a press release, "On behalf of the Navajo Nation Council, I send my sincerest condolences to the wife, children, and family of Leonard Haskie, a highly respected and distinguished leader of our great Nation."

Haskie was Ta'neeszahnii (Tangle Clan) and born for Táchii'nii (Red-Running-Into-The-Water People Clan). His maternal grandfathers are Tódích'íi'nii (Bitter Water Clan) and his paternal grandfathers are Naakai Dine'é (Mexican Clan).

A service is scheduled at 10 a.m. on Wednesday, Dec. 9 at the Veterans Memorial Center in Sanostee.

To read more, purchase the Dec. 10 edition of the Navajo Times.

status_message:
Chinle water delays Denny's grand opening
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — Somebody should have warned them about the water.
Outside the brand new Denny's restaurant Sunday, the line was snaking through the parking lot and was almost out to the street as people eagerly waited to be among the first served at Chinle's first sit-down chain restaurant.
Inside, owner Romero Brown was trying to get ahold of NTUA and sweating bullets.
"We're supposed to open at 6," he said at about 5:30. "NTUA is supposed to send a guy down to tell us the water is OK. But I haven't seen him yet."
A management team from corporate who had come all the way from Denny's headquarters in South Carolina had taken one look at Chinle's infamous reddish-brown tap water and shut the opening down until they could be convinced it was potable.
"All we need is for someone to take a picture of this water and post it on Facebook," a manager said.
Apparently nobody told the team that that is just the color the water is in Chinle, stained by iron compounds from the red sandstone through which it filters into a deep well. Most Chinleites don't even wash their whites in it; they take them to laundromats in Gallup.
"I tried to tell them the people here are used to it," said Sarah Bitsui of Chinle, Brown's niece. "This is their water. We've been drinking it all this time and we're still here."
By 6 p.m., the line had lengthened to more than 130 people, the temperature had dropped to 30 degrees, the doors were still closed and the NTUA was nowhere in sight. Brown's son Darrell, lead manager for the restaurant, popped out to assure the crowd that in spite of "technical difficulties," the restaurant would be open momentarily.
"We're freezing!" shouted one woman. But Darrell Brown calmed the crowd, assuring them, "We're here to serve you. We love this area. I love my Navajo people!"
"This is crazy," muttered T.J. of Chinle, who refused to give his last name. "It's just like Best Buy in Farmington Thanksgiving night."
Still, no one was going anywhere.
"We like cold," declared Wilhelmina Davis, the first person in line. "I used to go all the way to Window Rock to eat at Denny's. No more of that again!"
For Anna Haskie of Nazlini, Ariz., eating at Denny's was almost a spiritual quest.
"I can't wait to eat in here," she said. "My son was Denny. He passed on. So this is my way of honoring him."
"We just want to see inside, look and eat," added Helen Mego.
"I want burgers!" piped up little Belle DeVeaux, in line next to her.
Inside, the corporate management team played some icebreaker games with the staff to calm their nerves while they waited.
Brown had hired 80 people to work the new restaurant, the management crew having taken an 11-week training course and the wait staff training at Brown's other Denny's in St. Michael's. The Department of Workforce Services had come through with a grant to train the employees, and presented Brown with a plaque for creating so many new jobs on the Navajo Nation.
"I'm happy to have the job," said Phillarena Begay of Round Rock, Ariz., a hostess. "I was a cashier at a convenience store, so this is a step up for me."
It was a step in the opposite direction for chef Cody Rockwell, a culinary school graduate who used to work at a ritzy sushi place in Phoenix. But he was equally grateful to Brown for the job.
"I moved here to be with my girlfriend," he said. "I guess I'm settling for diner food, but I'm happy to have a job in the kitchen. There aren't many jobs like this in Chinle."
Finally, just before 7 — a long, cold hour after the doors were supposed to open — the NTUA guy arrived and gave the water his blessing. The doors swung open and the Browns stretched a length of broad red ribbon across the entrance.
But there was another technical glitch: The giant scissors wouldn't cut the ribbon.
"There's metal in this ribbon or something," muttered Darrell.
A woman in the crowd saved the day, volunteering her pocket knife. After a few seconds sawing at the ribbon, it finally succumbed, amid a heartfelt cheer from the shivering masses. Judging from the smiles as the hostesses seated the hungry, long-suffering families, it was all worth it.
Meanwhile, up the street at the Junction Restaurant, a privately owned diner that's probably Denny's main competition in Chinle, one might have suspected a quiet night since the whole town seemed to be at Denny's.
But the Junction was its usual lively self.
"It looks like about the typical crowd for this time of night," said cashier/hostess Carlelisha Burbank. She added that the restaurant didn't lose any employees to Denny's that she knows of.
"There's room for more restaurants in Chinle," she shrugged.
Maybe even more motels. Brown announced at a VIP luncheon earlier Sunday that he planned to open a motel behind the restaurant, similar to his Navajoland Inn and Suites behind his Denny's franchise in St. Michael's.
Former council delegate Andrew Simpson applauded the move.
"He's been talking about it for 12 years," he confided. "Finally Chinle has a council delegate (Leonard Pete) who will push it through."

Winds gusting up to 55 mph are expected for the Western, Chinle and Fort Defiance Agencies, while a slight chance for sleet and snow are expected to impact the Eastern and Shiprock Agencies in the lower elevations. Temperatures will drop significantly as the weather system works its way through the reservation. Potential for snow in the higher elevations may cause roads to become icy and snow packed while gusting winds may cause limited driving visibility in lower elevations.

Begay changes parties

 

By Cindy Yurth

Tséyi' Bureau

 

            WINDOW ROCK — In a press conference today, Arizona State Sen. Carlyle Begay (Dist. 7) announced he is switching parties.

            Begay, who has been criticized by some of his Democratic colleagues as being too chummy with the Republicans, crossed the aisle for good today, announcing he is becoming a member of the GOP. 

            In a video explaining the transition, Begay said he believes it's best for his poor, rural district that contains several Indian reservations, including part of Navajo.

            "Our rural and Native American families are in crisis," Begay states in the video, citing unemployment rates up to 80 percent, decaying roads and bridges, lack of access to clean water, low high school graduations rates and high rates of suicide.

            "This is not how our distinguished ancestors saw our future," Begay says. "Change must happen now."

            Begay continues he has come to the conclusion that the Republican Party is "the party of progress, the party of opportunity, and, moving forward, my party."

            Begay was appointed in 2013 to fill the unexpired term of Jack C. Jackson Jr. and then elected as a Democrat in 2014.

            Begay's colleague Rep. Albert Hale (D-Dist. 7) wished Begay well.
"All I can say is it's good that he's showing his true colors," Hale said. "I hope that he can accomplish what we've been trying to accomplish for Native Americans all these years."

For more on Sen. Begaye, grab your copy of the Navajo Times at your nearest newsstand this Wednesay.

Snowy weather prompts school delays on the reservation 

    Rainy and snowy weather on Monday throughout the Navajo Reservation and border communities will result in school delays in most, if not all, school districts in and around the reservation.
    The Gallup-McKinley County School district, as well as the Window Rock School District, have already announced two hour delays at the start of school on Tuesday morning. Parents of children going to schools on the reservation are encouraged to call their own school districts to find out their schedule.
    The Gallup Magistrate and District courts have also announced that they will be on a  two-hour delay as well on Tuesday.

CORRECTION: Diné College is not on a two-hour delay and is on a regular schedule. The Times apologizes for the error.

A Winter Weather Advisory has been issued for the Navajo Nation beginning Sunday, Nov. 15 through midnight, Monday, Nov. 16. Expect snow begin to fall early Monday morning with sustained winds blowing between 15 mph to 30 mph, gusting up to 40 mph. Roads may become icy and snow packed.

status_message:
Pinon captures first-ever state volleyball crown

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

PRESCOTT VALLEY, Ariz. – The state's top seed in the Arizona Division V volleyball bracket put forth a dominant performance in the fifth and deciding set against No. 3 Tonopah Valley in the championship game on Saturday night.

The Pinon Lady Eagles put on a clinic and built a early 10-2 lead with senior middle hitter Raquel Archie putting down three of her 31 kills.

That eight-point cushion was the difference as Pinon picked up its first-ever state volleyball crown by outlasting the Lady Phoenix with a 26-24, 18-25, 25-19, 19-25, 15-7 win at the Prescott Valley Event Center.

"I told the girls that the last set was going to go fast," Pinon coach Nellie McCurtain said. "We just needed a good start and then we had to finish it off."

McCurtain said her team passed the ball exceptionally well, which gave them ample opportunities to put the ball away with Archie leading that department. Sophomore middle hitter Blie Tatianna helped out with six kills, including the game winner.

"I was real nervous but we won the game with a team effort," said Tatianna, who added that she was glad to help out the senior class with a championship trophy.

With the win the Eagles capped their season undefeated with  21-0 record albeit their record excludes regular season tournaments.

"I am just happy that we won state but I am a little sad that I'll be leaving the underclassmen after this year," said Archie.

For a more in depth story pick up a copy of the Navajo Times on Thursday.

status_message:
Chinle High School band to perform on the Today Show

By Cindy Yurth 

CHINLE - In his effort to broadcast the weather from all 50 states within a week, Today Show Weatherman Al Roker will be hitting the Four Corners Monument on Monday and killing four birds with one stone.
As part of the show, musicians from all four Four Corners states will collaborate on a rendition of "America the Beautiful" — the Brigham Young University Choir from Utah, a bluegrass band from Colorado, and two Navajo groups — the Martin Sisters and the Chinle High School Band — will represent New Mexico and Arizona, respectively. The Today Show will begin filming live at the Four Corners at 5 a.m., and spectators from all four states are invited. It will air live on the east coast and be broadcast on local NBC stations at 7 a.m. Roker is taking pledges for Feeding America along the way. The charity is a network of food banks across the country that boasts on its website it is able to feed 11 people one meal for every dollar donated.

Arizona prep volleyball:

Pinon advances to play No. 3 seed Tonopah Valley in Divison V championship game

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

PRESCOTT VALLEY, Ariz. – The Pinon Lady Eagles will play in its first state volleyball championship game after they defeated No. 4 seed St. David in four sets on Saturday morning.

The Lady Eagles advanced with a 25-9, 22-25, 25-16, 28-26 win in the semifinals of the Arizona Division V state volleyball tournament in Prescott Valley, Ariz.

Pinon will play No. 3 seed Tonopah Valley at 4 p.m. at the Prescott Valley Event Center for the state title.

Tonopah Valley came from one set down and beat No. 2 seed St. Michael 21-25, 25-22, 25-15, 25-10.

"We had a really great season," St. Michael coach Andrea Ashkie said. "The girls exceeded my expectations and we had a great run. I know they are capable and they showed this season. Going this far was well-deserved."

status_message:
Local contestants to vie for INFR titles
 
By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times
 
LAS VEGAS, Nev. – Several local contestants secured their spot in tonight's short round performance at the 40th annual Indian National Finals Rodeo.
The final round is scheduled to start at 7 p.m. at the South Point Equestrian Center in Las Vegas, Nev.
Rough Rock, Ariz., cowgirl Sheila Sells, who registered three solid runs during the weeklong event, leads the average race in the breakaway event with a 7.89 aggregate.
Sells has a slight lead over Serena Dahozy as the Fort Defiance cowgirl comes in second with a 9.57 average on three heads.
In the tie-down event, Donovan Yazzie is sitting second with a 29.23 aggregate and trails event leader Sherrick Dillion. On three runs, Dillion has the early advantage with a 27.98 average.
Mulholland Well, N.M., bull dogger Sheridan Jodie trails Trevin Fox and Casey Stone going into the tonight's final round as the steer wrestling event is shaping out to be an exciting event to watch.
Fox leads the field with a 15.33 aggregate ahead of Stone (15.45) and Jodie (15.53).
In the bull riding event, three local cowboys have covered two of their first three draws headed by Justin Granger of Tuba City.
Granger has amassed 167 points, which is currently good enough for third place. With 159 points, Lupton, Ariz. cowboy Tustin Daye is sitting fourth while Gallup bull rider Ty Toadlena is in sixth place with 141 points.
In the team roping, there are five teams that have caught all of their draws, headed by the Collin Begay and Levi Bears Claw. The two cowboys lead the average race with a 23.20 aggregate.
Montana heeler Spider Ramone, who has roots in the Crownpoint-area, is sitting third with partner Scott Rogers with a 27.46 average. Local team ropers Blaine Red Horse and Myles John enter tonight's round with a 29.88 aggregate, which places them fourth overall.

Arizona state volleyball:
Pinon, St. Michael advances
 
By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times
 
PRESCOTT VALLEY, Ariz. – The Pinon Lady Eagles needed a few more extra rallies to finally close out Mogollon in the second round of the Arizona Division V state volleyball playoffs.
The top seeded Eagles advanced into Saturday morning's semifinal with a 20-25, 25-12, 25-19, 28-26 win on Friday night at the Prescott Valley Event Center.
"Oh my gosh that last set was so hard," Pinon coach Nellie McCurtain said. "We were trying to win the game. My setter and my hitters got it done."
On the other side of the bracket, the No. 2 seed St. Michael Lady Cardinals posted a 25-9, 29-27, 19-25, 25-13 win over St. Johns.
St. Michael coach Andrea Ashkie was pleased with how her team held their composure, especially in the second set when her team erased two game-point opportunities that St. Johns had.
"That game reassured the girls their capabilities," Ashkie said. "Their mental game is becoming stronger and stronger. The girls are performing at their best"
With both teams advancing, the two top seeds remain on a collision course to meet in Saturday night's championship game. Of course, they have to get past their next round with Pinon taking on No. 4 seed St. David while St. Michael plays No. 3 seed Tonopah Valley. Both games are scheduled for 9 a.m. on Saturday.
The championship game is set 4 p.m. on Saturday.

Flagstaff schools on two-hour delay due to snow

A WIND advisory has been issued for Apache and Navajo Counties today from 11 a.m. until 6 p.m. MST. Sustained winds between 25 mph and 35 mph are expected with gusts up to 45 mph throughout the day. Light snow accumulation is also expected for parts of McKinley County in New Mexico. Limited visibility is possible due to blowing dust. Ice may also accumulate on roads. Drive with caution.

status_message:
Robbery suspect apprehended

A suspect has been apprehended in the robbery of the Wells Fargo Bank in Chinle Monday, an FBI spokesman said.

Kurt A. Remus, special agent in charge of media coordination for the Phoenix FBI office, said the suspect will not be named until formal charges are filed. He did not provide any details of the capture.

Despite the FBI not releasing a name, the Navajo Nation Police said Monday they were searching for Rolando Lopez as a person of interest in the case. 

The bank was robbed of an undetermined amount of cash at about 11 a.m. Monday. Police were still searching for the suspect as of Monday evening.

The FBI is involved in the investigation because bank robbery is a federal crime.

Suspect ID'd in bank robbery

Navajo Nation Police have identified a possible suspect in the robbery of the Wells Fargo Bank in Chinle late this morning.

A police spokeswoman said police are searching for Rolando Lopez, age unknown, as a person of interest in the case. He is described as a dark-skinned non-Native, possibly Hispanic, with a beard. Lopez is about 6 feet tall and slim. He was last seen wearing camouflage pants and Army boots with a black sweater over a white hooded sweater. Witnesses to the robbery described him as smelling strongly of cigarette smoke.

If you see anyone matching this description, call the Chinle Police Department at 928-674-2111. Do not approach the suspect as he is considered dangerous.

Wells Fargo Bank in Chinle robbed

A Navajo Nation Police vehicle blocks the entrance to Wells Fargo Bank in Chinle Monday. Police at the scene refused to confirm or deny there was a robbery, but Kurt Remus, special media coordinator for the Phoenix FBI office, confirmed the bank was robbed and agents are on their way to Chinle to investigate. Schools were on Code Orange alert and a sign on the bank door said the bank was closed due to an unforeseen emergency. Information will be posted on this page as it is obtained.

status_message:
NAU shooter charged with one count first degree murder, three felony counts of aggravated battery

FLAGSTAFF - Northern Arizona University freshmen Steven Jones, 18, who allegedly shot and killed fellow student Colin Brough, and injuring Nicholas Prato, Kyle Zientek, and Nicholas Piring, early Friday morning has been charged with one count of first degree murder and three felony counts of aggravated assault, and is scheduled to appear at the Coconino Superior Court this afternoon.

According to an NAU press release, campus police responded to a shooting call around 1:20 early Friday morning of shots fired on north campus. Police arrived at the scene and detained Jones at 1:22 a.m. At around 1:33 a.m., emergency personnel arrived and began to assist the victims.

During an early morning press conference, NAU police chief Gregory T. Jones stated that Jones had allegedly pulled out a handgun during a confrontation between two groups of students.

Prato, Zientek and Piring, the three shooting victims were taken to the Flagstaff Medical Center for treatment. Their extent of their injuries are not known.

The shooting occurred at the northeast end of the Flagstaff campus. University police along with Flagstaff police are continuing to investigate the shooting.

status_message: Parents also may call 928-523-0007 for info regarding the shooting at NAU. A family assistance center has been set up in the ballroom of 1899.

FLAGSTAFF - According to Northern Arizona University police chief Gregory T. Fowler, the alleged shooter, Steven Jones, 18, pulled out a handgun during a confrontation and shot four people. 

Jones was taken into custody without further incident, Fowler said. 

The shooting occurred at 1:20 A.M., during a confrontation between Jones and several other students.

The shooting occurred on a school campus parking lot, Fowler added at an early morning press conference.

Classes at NAU will proceed as scheduled. 

University police are continuing to investigate.

Breaking 

Early morning shooting at NAU leaves one person dead, three wounded

An early morning shooting at the Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff, Ariz., has left one person dead and three people wounded, according to press release by Sen. John McCain (R-AZ). 

"My thoughts and prayers are with families of the person who was killed and the three others who were wounded," McCain said. I" appreciate the efforts of all state and local law enforcement officials, first-responders and school administrators."

No other information is available at this time. The Times will continue to provide information as it comes in.

T-storms buffet rez

By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau

 CHINLE — Chinle Unified School District closed all its schools Tuesday as a barrage of thunderstorms continued to pelt the Navajo Nation, leaving up to an inch of precipitation in some locations and turning dirt roads to quagmires.
 Observers in Western Agency reported a skiff of snow on the San Francisco Peaks.
 A flash flooding advisory was in effect for parts of Arizona and New Mexico Tuesday.
 According to the National Weather Service, the widespread low-pressure system that caused the storms was heading southeast and gradually losing steam by Tuesday afternoon.
 Isolated thunderstorms will persist through Wednesday, after which there will be a warming trend, the NWS predicted.

A Special Weather Statement has been issued by the National Weather Service: Strong thunderstorms, winds gusting up to 50 mph, hail, thunder and heavy rainfall are expected for Sanostee, Shiprock, Nenahnezad areas in northwest New Mexico. Do not cross flooded ravines and roads.

status_message:
Letters: Facebook, Twitter forms of free speech

Last week Council Delegate Leonard Tsosie wrote a letter critical of negative characterization of public officials on social media and suggested we should ban these activities.

Fundamentally I disagree, but I think his point should be acknowledged.

The type of activity we witness on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter can be overly negative or mean-spirited.

But the Internet and forms of social media are powerful new forms of communication and ones that have ramifications on the politics everywhere, including the Navajo Nation.

We see social movements across the planet ebb and flow through these technologies, from the Arab Spring, to Occupy, to Idle No More, to Black Lives Matter. This doesn't mean it's an ideal form of communication. But it is one of consequence.

For the Navajo Nation, it has become an important place for political discourse, linking people in and outside of the reservation to happenings in Window Rock.

It is wrong to call for prosecution of slanderers on Facebook and elsewhere. We are protected by a tradition of free speech that includes satire and making fun of public officials, even where these characterizations are untrue or skewed.

It may seem overly negative and at times unreasonable — and often these characterizations are Ðbut it's necessary in order to have robust political discourse.

It's the choice of the people to determine between what is true and what is just rumor or misinformation. We need to maintain a high standard of evidence before we believe everything we hear or are told.

You don't need Facebook to spread misinformation. You just need a press release officer. And almost every well-staffed Window Rock office has one.

Andrew Curley
Sanders, Ariz.

status_message:
Begaye disputes EPA's testimony, calls for more help

By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau

CHINLE — At hearings before the U.S. Senate's Indian Affairs Committee Wednesday, President Russell Begaye disputed U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Gina McCarthy's testimony that the EPA is continuing to supply hay and water to communities affected by the Aug. 5 Gold King Mine Spill.
"The EPA has abandoned us," Begaye told the committee. "The water tanks are being pulled out. The feed for our livestock is no longer there."
In earlier testimony, McCarthy had told the senators "We are continuing to provide hay. The BIA has continued to supply water."
Begaye, however, testified that the last time he had talked to McCarthy, she was unaware that the regional EPA office had suspended aid Aug. 21, after learning that the Navajo Nation EPA had declared the San Juan River safe for irrigation.
According to Begaye, McCarthy agreed to reinstate aid at that time, but only until this Friday. "How convenient!" Begaye said.
In other conflicting testimony, McCarthy said the EPA was continuing to work with the Navajo Nation to develop a long-term plan to deal with the contamination and the relationship between the tribe and feds was improving.
For a full story, pick up tomorrow's Navajo Times.

By Krista Allen
Navajo Times

             WINDOW ROCK - Alyson Jeri Shirley from Tolani Lake, Ariz. was crowned Miss Navajo Nation, becoming the 69th titleholder, during the coronation ceremony at the Navajo Arts & Crafts Enterprise Saturday. 
            After she was crowned, the 20-year-old stand out said in Navajo that she was in a state of euphoria.
            "I've been preparing ever since I was small," Shirley told the Navajo Times. "I knew I was going to win. I knew I had it. I believed in myself. I did it."
            During her acceptance speech, Shirley thanked her maternal grandmother Lorraine Nebitsi Chee for helping her win the difficult, three-day competition that she and four other young women – Crystal Littleben from Round Rock, Ariz.; Farrah Mailboy from Lukachukai, Ariz.; Ann Marie Salt from Kayenta; and Starlene Tsinniginnie from Nahata Dziil, Ariz. – endured this week at the 69th annual Navajo Nation Fair.

DV fugitive arrested 

By Cindy Yurth and Donovan Quintero 
Navajo Times 

WINDOW ROCK — After escaping from the scene of a domestic violence call with a hostage and eluding police for 16 hours, a suspect was arrested about noon Wednesday, Navajo Nation Police Capt. Bobby Etsitty confirmed. 
Kevin Ray Yellowman, 33, of Valley Store, Ariz., is expected to face federal charges. 
According to Navajo Nation Public Safety Director Jesse Delmar, a Navajo Nation police officer responded to a domestic violence call near Valley Store about 8 p.m. Tuesday. The officer attempted to arrest Yellowman, but he grabbed her gun, which discharged through the holster during the struggle. 
Yellowman then allegedly fled the scene with a female hostage. 
Chinle area schools were on lockdown Wednesday as police and FBI agents searched for Yellowman. 
Etsitty said he did not have the details of the arrest, but confirmed that Yellowman is in custody. 
Yellowman is a registered sex offender with a previous conviction for aggravated sexual abuse.

Police searching for DV suspect, hostage 

By Cindy Yurth and Donovan Quintero
Tseyi' Bureau 

Navajo Police and the FBI are searching for an armed and dangerous suspect who fled the scene of a domestic violence incident near Valley Store, Ariz. Tuesday evening with a female hostage. 

The suspect, Kevin Yellowman, is described as 33 years old, about 280 pounds, wearing a blue T-shirt and beige cargo pants. His hair is in a short ponytail. 

The search is concentrated around the Chinle area and all local schools are on lockdown. 

Public Safety Director Jesse Delmar said Wednesday Yellowman resisted arrest Tuesday and grabbed the arresting officer's gun. During the struggle a shot was fired through the holster and Yellowman escaped with the hostage. 

Anyone spotting him is urged to call the police immediately.

NACE hosts first skit contest
 
By Stacy Thacker
Navajo Times
 
            WINDOW ROCK — For the first year ever, Navajo Arts and Crafts Enterprise will host a Navajo Skit Night.
            The event is an attempt to bring something new to the usual fair activities. Summer workers who are students at Tsehootsooi Dine Bi'Olta inspired the skit night, as well as the recent drawn out election, said JT Willie, NACE marketing director.
            Willie said with this year's election controversy, NACE was inspired to do something around the Navajo language.
            "It influenced us to do something," he said. "What we could do on our end was to encourage the language."
            Rules of the event include having a group of at least five people, the skit must be done entirely in Navajo, it has to be five minutes long and the skit must be submitted to the judges before hand.
            Skits including coyote or winter stories will not be accepted, Willie said. He added that the season for those stories is gone.
            The event is free and participants will be judged on creativity, originality, use of the Navajo language, timing and the response from the audience.
            Willie said he is hoping to see people expand their thought and creativity while using the language.
            "I think what we're going to get out of this is something political," he said, adding that he's already seen social media posts about possible skits that deal with the election.
            So far Willie said they only have two groups that have inquired about the event but he encourages everybody to come out and give it a try.
            "Even if you don't speak Navajo still try to do the best of your ability," he said.
            The event will take place in front of NACE on Tuesday, Sept. 8 at 5:30 p.m.
            Skits can be summited on the day of the event starting at noon. For more information: (928) 871-4090
