status_message:
San Juan canals still closed
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — In spite of the Navajo Nation Environmental Protection Agency having given the green light to use the San Juan River for irrigation, President Russell Begaye on Monday issued a press release stating he had decided to keep the canals closed, based on a meeting with Shiprock area farmers last Thursday and a Shiprock Chapter resolution passed Sunday urging him not to open the headgates.
Begaye said in the release both the meeting and the resolution indicate farmers still have concerns about using the water, although farmers off the reservation have been using it for over a week and the Animals River upstream is open for boating and fishing.
"I'm glad the water samples indicate the water is safe for irrigation use but I remain concerned over the soil and sediment that lines our river bank," said President Begaye. "Every time a heavy storm hits or the soil is disturbed it can recontaminate the water."
The NNEPA will have final results from their soil samples this week.
Although the USEPA has released data indicating both the Animas and San Juan rivers are back to normal after an Aug. 5 mine wastewater spill the agency accidentally released from an abandoned mine above Silverton, Colo., Begaye blamed the feds for the continued closure.
"I am furious that the USEPA has placed the Navajo Nation into this position. Our farms will not last much longer without water and our resources are depleting," Begaye stated in the release.
The USEPA stopped delivering water and hay to affected ranchers Friday after releasing its latest findings, but Begaye said the tribe and the BIA will continue to assist.
He urged other chapters affected by the closure to pass resolutions on whether or not they approve of opening the headgates to the canals.
Shiprock voted 104-0-9 to leave the water off.

status_message:
Begaye to decide today on opening canals
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
SHIPROCK — President Russell Begaye Friday morning was tracing the route of the Aug. 5 Gold King Mine waste spill with members of the Navajo Nation Council and a medicine man, blessing the rivers and trying to decide whether to open the San Juan River to irrigation.
An emotional seven-and-one-half-hour meeting with farmers in Shiprock Thursday night had provided little guidance. While most of the 35 or so people who spoke begged him to keep the river closed, a subsequent anonymous paper ballot favored opening it.
The canal system, however, is being flushed Friday — an eight-hour process that cleans the silt out in case Begaye decides to open the system.
The U.S. EPA, which has maintained the river is back to pre-spill levels of heavy metals, has announced it will stop delivering replacement water to Navajo farmers Friday, but Begaye said the tribe and the BIA will continue to try to supply water to all who need it until the canals are open.
The Navajo Nation EPA also announced Thursday their independent test results indicated the river is safe for irrigation — though not yet approved for livestock watering. But the vast majority of the farmers who spoke were unconvinced.
"I don't want my children to get sterile!" cried one woman.
"Nobody wants to buy our corn!" said another farmer.
"What's going to happen when people start dying?" asked someone else.
Others questioned why the NNEPA wasn't releasing its test results, other than a vague graph that indicated a spike in contaminants while the plume flowed through and then a steep drop to normal levels over the next few days.
NNEPA Executive Director Donald Benn said the tribe was keeping the results secret because they might be used as evidence in the tribe's planned lawsuit against the USEPA. He said some of the results were very similar to the USEPA's but others were different.
Steve Austin of the Navajo Nation Water Quality Program's Shiprock office showed a graph indicating that even as the toxic plume flowed through the Navajo Nation on Aug. 8, there were no heavy metals that exceeded the Navajo Nation's standards for irrigation water. However, on Aug. 9, a storm around Aneth apparently stirred up some of the contaminants that had settled to the bottom of the river and, downstream from Shiprock, levels of aluminum and vanadium rose to levels slightly higher than the standards.
"They exceeded briefly and went away," Austin said, noting that the vanadium level went up by only 10 parts per billion.
But no amount of science seemed to convince the crowd of about 150 farmers that their water was safe, and in spite of Begaye's repeated iteration that the tribe would sue the USEPA for enough money to build alternative projects, some were still suspicious that the tribe and the federal government were somehow in cahoots.
"The way it sounds, the Navajo Nation is being bought by the EPA," said J.C. Begay, a farmer who says he has already lost two animals to dehydration. "They need to do a lot more homework before they turn on that water."

status_message:
Road closure between Window Rock-Ganado after head-on collision

 

By Terry Bowman

Navajo Times

 

            WINDOW ROCK — A head-on collision occurred on Arizona Highway 264 near mile marker 465 causing a road closure indefinitely, according to a Ganado Fire Department official.

            The accident occurred around 3 p.m. within the two-lane at the top of the summit and has brought emergency response teams from Window Rock and the Western Agency, including a helicopter for emergency medical evacuation.

            According to Ganado Fire Chief Dwayne Woodie, Highway 264 between Window Rock and Ganado will be closed until further notice due to authorities conducting an investigation.

            "We are relying on information from our people on scene at this time," said Woodie.

            He added that fire crews from Ganado and Window Rock along with medical response teams are on scene and will be there until their investigation is finished.

            The vehicles include a grey mini-van, which has rolled over, and a dark SUV.

            People traveling this route after work are encouraged to seek alternatives routes as traffic is backed up for emergency response teams responding to the accident, according to Navajo Nation Police Dispatch.

            According to the Navajo Police dispatch office in Window Rock, Sgt. Terry John is leading the investigation of the two vehicle accident.

status_message:
Animas River spill tough break for Shiprock farmers."

By Donovan Quintero 
Navajo Times

        SHIPROCK, N.M. - Despite the early morning prayer offerings given by Shiprock farmer Earl Yazzie - who has been farming since he was a toddler - to save his fields of corn, squash, melon and cantaloupe, it seems it won't be so.

       According to Shiprock Chapter president Duane "Chili" Yazzie, who is a farmer himself, the farm board made the decision to keep the irrigation closed for the remainder of the season. 

      "You can't describe the extent of hurt that we've been thrown into," Yazzie said.

        During an Aug. 5 excavation conducted by the EPA at the Gold King Mine site, loose material gave way, spilling the contaminated water into Cement Creek, which feeds into the Animas River.

        The bad news is the initial spill was about three times larger than the early estimate of one million gallons.

        On Saturday the orange-colored Animas River merged with the San Juan River. On Monday afternoon, the color seems to have all but disappeared, looking more normal. 

        However, Yazzie said that despite it looking "normal," the Navajo Nation continues to caution community members living along the river to not use it until further notice. 

        "The heavy metals in the contaminants sink to the bottom of the river and are easily agitated when disturbed," Yazzie said. 

        The bad part is that this will stay like for a long time he added. 

        "Don't use or touch it despite it looking normal," he said. 

         Earl and his wife Cheryle Yazzie, who will be celebrating their 39th wedding anniversary on Oct. 2, say all they pray for is for the river to heal. 

         "People see us out here everyday. Hoeing away in the middle of the day and heat, sunburned," Yazzie said. "It is a labor of love." 

          "Me and my wife Cheryle, we sell our crops and hand them out. We also donate some of it to the women's shelter here in Shiprock," he added.

          "We had plans. We were going go make steamed corn and kneel down bread. Now this happens," said Cheryle. "Looks like we aren't gonna have our steamed corn. You know what they say, 'you never make plans.'"

Begaye calls on EPA to bring water

By Cindy Yurth
Tseyi' Bureau

    DURANGO, Colo. -- Saying "Cattle can't wait for test results," Navajo Nation President Russell Begaye Sunday called on the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to bring drinking water for people and livestock to the Navajo Nation to replace San Juan River water contaminated by a three-million-gallon spill of toxic mine waste in Silverton the agency inadvertently caused when digging at an abandoned mine Wednesday.

     After attending a public meeting in Durango that included state and local government officials as well as EPA representatives, Begaye also reiterated his plans to sue the EPA and revealed the Navajo Nation has been taking its own water and sediment samples, which will be sent to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for analysis.

     "We're not going to depend on EPA," he said. "We're going to get our own answers."

     Begaye said three water tanks that draw from the San Juan in Farmington, Aneth and Mexican Hat, Utah have been shut off as well as irrigation ditches in the Shiprock area, and Navajos are hauling water for themselves and their livestock.

    "Farmers are upset," he said.

     EPA officials at the meeting showed graphs of test results showing the major contaminants -- iron, manganese, zinc and cadmium -- had returned to baseline levels in the Animas River in the northern part of Durango by Sunday, after most of the toxic plume had passed, and acidity levels were back to normal.

     Colorado Parks and Wildlife reported only one of the 108 "sentinel fish" planted in cages in the river had died, and Scott Roberts, an aquatic ecologist with the independent Mountain Studies Institute said that soil samples from the river bottom, where the heavy metals are likely to settle as the plume flows downstream, contained live aquatic insects 20 hours after the plume had passed, which is a good sign.

      EPA officials said four settling ponds have been constructed at the Gold King Mine and the waste is being treated before it enters the river. The volume of the discharge has also decreased from 700 to 500 gallons per minute.

      The bad news is the initial spill was about three times larger than the early estimate of one million gallons.

       During an Aug. 5 excavation conducted by the EPA at the mine site, loose material gave way, spilling the contaminated water into Cement Creek, which feeds into the Animas River. 

       Test results from the river are available at epaosc.org/googling one.

status_message:
Police investigating shooting in Sheepsprings

Navajo Times Staff 

   SHEEPSPRINGS, N.M. - A report of an early morning shooting in Sheepsprings, N.M. sent police from Shiprock, Crownpoint and Window Rock to respond.
   According to senior police officer with the Shiprock Police District Grant Keams, around 2 a.m., police received a call of shots fired in the NHA housing are east of Highway 491. Officers immediately responded. 
   Due to the severity of the call, officers from other districts were called in to aid with the search of a possible gunman, Keams said. After a house-to-house search that ended eight hours later, police came up with nothing and called off the search. 
   Investigators from the FBI and Shiprock Police District are investigating the alleged shooting incident after bullet casings were found. No injuries are reported.

status_message:
Power to the People 

New law allows Diné voters – not the courts – to decide language fluency
link_name: Power to the People - Navajo Times

status_message:
Navajo language referendum passes in special election

By Bill Donovan
Special to the Times

     WINDOW ROCK -  Navajo voters decided on Tuesday that it should be the Navajo people and not the Navajo courts who should decide whether a candidate running for tribal president or vice president is fluent in Navajo.
    A referendum to change existing tribal laws on that subject passed  Tuesday by a vote of 13,017 to 11,778, according to the unofficial count done by the Navajo Election Administration. That's a difference of about five percentage points.
    As expected, turnout for the election was low with only 21 percent of the registered voters participating in the election.
    The election count, which was done in the auditorium at the Navajo Nation Museum, showed the first chapter votes coming in just three minutes after the polls closed.  The tallies from the first seven chapters put the yes vote ahead but then about 7:05 p.m., the nays took the lead but that lasted only for about seven minutes as the yes vote took the lead again after 23 chapters and kept it to the end.
    Thomas Benallie, one of the 100 or so people who showed up to watch the count, said the decision by the Navajo voters was a good one because it gives more power to the Navajo voters and gives them a greater say in the running of their government.
    "I don't think that the Navajo people will elect someone with no knowledge of Navajo culture or the Navajo language, but passage (of the referendum)  will allow more people to run for tribal president in the future."
    Voter rights groups on the reservation spent a lot of time in the days before the election trying to explain what the new law would and would not do and clear up any misunderstanding that the Navajo voters may have had. One of these was that passage of the referendum would mean that future tribal leaders would not need to know anything about the Navajo language or culture.
    The requirement that candidates know both English and Navajo will still be on the books and it will now be up to the Navajo voters, and not the tribal courts, to decide whether the candidate is fluent enough in Navajo to properly represent the Navajo Nation.

MORE BREAKING NEWS ...
Two people are in custody in connection with a shooting incident in Pinon yesterday and a suspect is currently being questioned concerning a similar incident around noon today, President Russell Begaye's spokesman said.

Rick Abasta, spokesman for Navajo Nation President Russell Begaye, said no one was hurt in the incidents.

According to a witness to yesterday's shooting, a man fired a shotgun into the ceiling in the foyer of Basha's Dine Market. Abasta did not know the location of today's shooting.

Schools and businesses were on lockdown as police and Apache County Sheriff's deputies responded to the scene.

BREAKING NEWS
 Schools and businesses are on lockdown in Pinon, Ariz. today following the second shooting incident in as many days.
 Yesterday about 3 p.m. shoppers at Basha's reported a shooting in the parking lot. Today around noon Pinon Unified School District employees reported the district is on lockdown following another incident with a gun. Local businesses are also on lockdown, they said.
 "It wasn't at the school," said an employee who declined to give her name. "We're hearing it was at Basha's again."
 Navajo Nation President Russell Begaye's spokesman Rick Abasta, who also acts as the spokesman for the Navajo Nation Police, said he had no information from the police at this time.
 Schools were still on lockdown as of 1:25 p.m.

status_message:
Dynamite cache discovered in home 

By Bill Donovan 
Special to the Times

GALLUP, N.M. -- State police officials said Friday that the department's bomb squad was called to the Red Rock area, about four miles south of Gallup, on Monday to deal with a cache of dynamite that was discovered this past weekend at a Navajo Reservation house.
    Chad Pierce, the spokesman for the state police, said the bomb disposal unit picked up 30 sticks of dynamite that were discovered when the owner died and family members were sorting through the estate.
    The deceased, said Pierce, worked out of Fort Wingate, N.M. 
    The dynamite may have been more than 35 years old but was in stable condition.
    The dynamite was transported to Albuquerque and was destroyed.

Walk, lope or fly to Pet Carnival

By Cindy Yurth
Tséyí' Bureau

 
Residents of Red Lake/Navajo Chapter will have a chance to celebrate their pets Saturday at the Diné bi Pet Carnival.
The event, starting at 10 a.m. at the old Recreation Center parking lot, will include informational booths, presentations, games and contests with prizes for the best pet trick, most obedient, etc.
All animals must be either on a leash or in a carrier.
Prestene Garnenez of the Red Lake/Navajo Community Action Group, which is sponsoring the event, said she started thinking about it when she saw all the starving dogs at the local convenience store.
"I know you're not supposed to, but I always buy a loaf of bread and feed them," she said. "I just can't stand to see them like that."
Then, for a while, "I started taking them home and ended up with way too many dogs," she said.
Garnenez thinks she's typical of many in her community … soft-hearted, but not knowing what the resources are and how to take the best possible care of her pets without draining her savings account.
On the other hand, pet ownership is undeniably a happy experience, and she wants her community to celebrate the joy their pets bring to their lives.
"It's going to be a day of focusing on our pets," she said, "a fun way to spend time with our pets and learn more about proper pet care."
Unfortunately, after the group had already scheduled the event, they learned most Navajo Nation personnel won't work on weekends, so Animal Control and the other Navajo Nation departments that deal with pets won't be represented.
Non-profits like Blackhat Humane Society, however, will set up booths.
The event is free and open to everyone and every species, as long as they are properly restrained and not dangerous to others. Unhealthy animals who may be contagious should be kept home.

Students, former employees protest at Diné College
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
TSAILE — Seven students, former students and former employees of Diné College held protest signs reading "End hostility, discrimination and restore harmony" and "Maggie George violates DC policies" outside the Hatathlie Building as the college's board of regents met inside Friday morning.
The protest was patrolled by an almost equal number of security guards.
Regents walked by the protesters without acknowledging them, and in the meeting only one regent — Council Delegate Nelson BeGaye (Tsé Ch'izhi/Round Rock/Rock Point/Lukachukai/Tsaile-Wheatfields) mentioned them.
While discussing a Sihasin Fund grant for which the college recently applied, BeGaye observed, "As I came in I saw protesters outside. There's a lot of negativity in the media. I've been getting a lot of calls from faculty members."
BeGaye told the board the controversy could hurt the college's chances at the grant money and suggested the regents deal with the protesters' concerns.
Nobody picked up the topic, and the board moved ahead with its agenda, which was not distributed to members of the public attending the meeting and only read aloud into the minutes after Regent Theresa Hatathlie requested that.
George Joe, a former Diné College employee who has a complaint pending with the Office of Navajo Labor Relations for alleged unlawful termination, said the protesters' concerns are basically the same ones addressed in a petition signed by 38 faculty and staff: unqualified faculty members and administrators, preferential treatment for those who keep their mouths shut, and "abuses and violations of policy."
Asked why they were protesting at a board of regents meeting, Joe said the board has lost track of its role as a check against the administration and is allowing College President Maggie George "free rein to do whatever she wants."
Like the petition signers, the protesters want Fannie Atcitty, Loretta Draper and Laurence Gishey replaced on the board — Atcitty and Draper because they have served two years after their terms ended and Gishey because he does not live in the district he is representing.
"The board does not allow any of our complaints to be investigated or even acknowledged," Joe charged.
Asked if she is serving on an expired term, Draper replied, "I can't comment on that right now."
Joe also said he estimates the college has spent more than $150,000 in legal fees defending itself against 10 complaints filed at the ONLR over the last four years.
Student Jay Ross Slivers said he was motivated to join the protest after the reaction he got from a recent letter to the editor critical of the college brass.
"Some of the staff and even community members called me to say they agreed with me and told me their stories," he said. "I'm really concerned that the college's reputation has started to go down."
A security guard tried to dissuade a Navajo Times reporter from entering the BOR meeting, saying the regents "don't want to be bothered right now," but relented when the reporter reminded him it was a public meeting.

status_message:
BREAKING

9 school buses burn in Piñon
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
PIÑON, Ariz. — Nine school buses were consumed by flames in a mysterious fire in the Piñon School District's transportation yard early Thursday morning.
According to District Superintendent Doug Vaughan, "seven were destroyed, and two are severely damaged to the point that I don't feel comfortable putting children in them even after they're repaired."
Vaughan estimated the loss at $1.4 million. The buses are insured.
The blaze is being investigated by the Navajo Nation Fire Department and the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, with assistance from the Navajo County Sheriff's Department.
As bad as the fire was, it could have been an uncontrollable inferno if it had spread to the gasoline tanks located under the parking lot where the buses were parked.
Just last year, said PUSD Facilities Manager Myron McLaughlin, the district had poured a cement cap over the tanks for safety reasons.
Explained Vaughan, "Fire can go through asphalt, but it stops at concrete."
Vaughan said he was awakened at 12:30 a.m. by a call from a campus security guard.
"He told me a bus was on fire," Vaughan recalled. "By the time I got there, three buses were on fire. The fire kept going down the line of buses."
The loss, already almost a third of Piñon's fleet, could have been worse if not for some quick-thinking school employees who jumped in the unburned buses and drove them out of harm's way, Vaughan said.
"The employees, who are heroes in my book, literally risked their safety in order to evacuate the buses," Vaughan said.
The Navajo Nation Fire Department, Navajo Nation Police and Piñon Community School fire department all responded to the blaze, along with "numerous volunteers who showed up on our doorstep asking how they could help," Vaughan said. "Do you think we have a good community here?"
Summer school was canceled Thursday and Friday.
Vaughan said the district is already negotiating with a vendor to replace the buses, known in the industry as "Thomas heavy-duty with the Colorado package." They cost about $150,000 apiece.
"They are the most rugged buses you can find, which is what we need out here," Vaughan said. The first replacement bus is scheduled to arrive Monday, and Vaughan said the district is committed to being back to full fleet status by the time school starts in early August.
While the district is insured and can replace the buses, Vaughn said the children enrolled in summer school won't get back those two days.
"That's what really frosts me," he said.
Vaughan extended appreciation to the Navajo Nation Police and Fire departments, the Office of the Navajo Nation President (who immediately called to make sure no one was hurt in the blaze, Vaughan said), and the Navajo County Sheriff's Department.
"Whoever did this," said McLaughlin, surveying the gray, burnt-out hulks of the buses, "the only people they're hurting are the children."

status_message:
Ketchum - Navajo Code Talker - passes on

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

     TUBA CITY – Bahe Ketchum, a member of an elite group of Marines who helped create the only unbroken code in modern military history, died Monday morning. He was 96.

     Ketchum, a Navajo Code Talker, was born Jan. 15, 1919 and lived in Naatsis'áán, Ariz. for more than 60 years. He is survived by nine sons and two daughters. His wife deceased in 2006.
     "A lot of people looked at him as a community person," said his son, Marvin Ketchum in an interview with the Navajo Times on Monday afternoon. "After the war, when he came back, he did a lot for the community (Naatsis'áán) as a chapter official and a representative.

     "He did a lot for Shonto and Ts'ahbiikin chapters (as well)," he added. 

     Upon discharge from the Marines, Ketchum returned home to north Western Navajo where he raised a family and maintained livestock.
 
     Marvin said his father suffered a number of injuries, falls that have sent him to the hospital within the last couple of months. After a recent surgery, Marvin said his father developed pneumonia. 

     Ketchum also leaves behind a lasting imprint on the Navajo Nation. 
     In 1955, Ketchum served as the Navajo Mountain Chapter vice president. He also served as the secretary-treasure from 1963 to 1975. In addition, Ketchum served as an archeological society guide and a community health representative. 

     Ketchum was Tł'ízíłání (Many Goats Clan) and born for the Tábąąhá (Water's Edge Clan). 

     There will be a meeting for Ketchum at Navajo Mountain Chapter tomorrow evening (June 9). The time is still unconfirmed.

status_message:
BREAKING NEWS: Navajo Nation Chief Justice Herb Yazzie announced his retirement on Wednesday afternoon. Yazzie released the following statement:

"After forty years working in the legal profession for the Diné and with thirty years working in Navajo Nation government, with a stint as Attorney General and more recently as Chief Justice, I will be retiring. My retirement decision has long been urged by my family, relatives and community out of concern for my well-being. For the past ten years, I have been part of a Court that has had to make hard decisions often involving ruptures in relationships that, according to our deeply held principles of k'é, should properly be the responsibility of a better and more traditional system to patiently restore. I have decided now, with full consultation with my elders, to heed their advice.

Our society is a precious one, but one in which isolation and lack of self-esteem can harm our young ones their whole lives. I was such a young one, refusing to see value in myself, yet I survived though many of my generation did not make it and could not provide for the families they left behind. Somehow, I gained experience and knowledge, and was able to reconnect with my loved ones. It is much harder for a young person to reconnect after isolating himself or herself than to understand the value of relationships, k'é, from the beginning and be helped forward. Sometimes to learn this value, there must be a disciplinarian. I have tried to emphasize this value in my participation on the Supreme Court, Hashkééjí Nahatʹá, and by example.

We start with incomplete knowledge in a difficult environment. The difficulties in making ends meet is often unbearable enough and becoming separate from our value system, embodied by our language, can seem insignificant. We can become indoctrinated into believing such identity to be unimportant. Parents may even believe that they are protecting their child by affirming the unimportance of traditional knowledge that the parents, themselves, have not conveyed. To these parents, I would tell a story, that of a young Navajo serviceman troubled at putting on an army dress uniform with insignia of cavalry sabers, feeling a general sense of betraying himself, and unable to put into thought or words how to own his own future.

My folks always said – your experience, your knowledge, we appreciate you putting it to good use on behalf of the people. You now have attained these high leadership positions. But be aware that there will always be people who will insist on behaving as if the function of government is to destroy itself. In your position, don't ever get down to their level, because you have to protect the concept of natanii. You have to maintain integrity for the people, and you should not by your words cause people to lose faith in our value system or respect for the value system. That's not what a leader does. However, there have been a few times that, as part of the Supreme Court, I have had to call the government structure into question in order that the people have knowledge of your government, be engaged in the actions of government, and design and choose your future system of government that affirms who you are rather than merely imitate surrounding states. 

The other day, someone told me that he understands and supports the Supreme Court. He remembered that when the Council declared that Fundamental Law and tradition is only what the Council decreed Fundamental Law to be, it was the Supreme Court that struck down that effort. It was through use of Fundamental Law that the courts were able to rein in corruption in past Councils and strike down enactments that provided cover for embezzlement of the discretionary fund. Concern for the traditional law of the people and the value system of the people have been the duty of the court system since the Navajo Nation began performing decision-making functions free of the burden of elections. It is my steadfast hope that the Judicial Branch may continue to be the disciplinarian and gatekeeper without interference.

The Court takes a comprehensive look at the laws and hears the explanation from those who wish to state their position. The Court cannot ignore other laws, and it cannot pick and choose which law applies when there is a set of laws that all bear on one subject. In the recent election cases, our courts affirmed the rights of the people to choose their leaders. Yet at the same time, it was our elders, our former leaders, who made it very specific, very strong, that you must be fluent in order to be President and Vice President. Our government specifically added the fluency qualification in 1999. We affirmed the validity of the language requirement in our president election laws. We have noted that the President is nihi nanitʹaʹi elected by all the Navajo People while all other offices are elected by communities in smaller areas. The President has the stature of representing the whole Navajo Nation to other sovereigns and the one who is the embodiment of the Nation. The law requires this embodiment to be bilingual. Don't expect to be President without acquiring the qualification.

In closing, I would say that the recent proposed measure to remove me all concern decisions by the Supreme Court, not actions of an individual. The decisions were based on a thorough analysis of the law and declaration of how the law should be applied. Issuing court decisions that are thoroughly explained are manifestly judicial acts, that is what courts do. Our past governmental leaders have always said that when the Supreme Court makes a decision, that is the final decision. That law must be complied with no matter how some may view me as an individual. Seeking to use personal attack does not nullify the Court's decision. I urge the Diné to learn from the actions and words of those who attack our way of life. Learn and protect our heritage. Turn the negative into positive.

I am truly grateful for being able to have worked with all of you. I have become acquainted with many of you personally and know that I have family all over our land. In my retirement, I am sure we will meet and enjoy the beauty of our life and the gifts that have been bestowed on us.

Coming from being a judge, my dream is that when we meet those who find themselves facing harshness of life, that we will help them, especially affirm to the Diné that because we are Diné, we can restore ourselves to the Beauty Way, and thereby also affirm all humanity who are universally linked, as neighbors, as surrogate family, and as partners in a mutual journey.

I'm sure we will see each other soon.

Díné binant'a'íjílį́įgo hanaanish éí t'áá bééhóziní, diné be'iina' bits'íís yá'at'ééhdoo, bits'íís dóó bintsáhákees k'ézdongo yá'átéeh dooleeł dóó yá'át'éehgo hináa dooleeł jinízin dóó honahat'a'go éí bee bá jizį́į dooleeł....

Saad báádahadzidii, saad doo aaníinii, saad bee ahididláásh doo bee yájíł'da, dóó doo baa yáti'da. Yíiyá bááhádzid! Háálá diné baa hajoobá'í, índa diné éí dílzin dóó baa hą́ą́h hwiindzin. Saad kódaat'éí éí doo bee yájíłti'da háálá hazéé' hodiyin dóó naat'áanii jílį́įgo éi doo kót'éigo hazaada.

T'ááhó hazaadígíí éí baajisti', baa jé'jólna dóó hona'nitin át'é áádóó hodine'é dóó ha'áłchíní éí baahasti' áádóó t'ááhódó' haahasti'....

Áko, Diné binant'a'í jílį́įgo, hodine'é kót'éígo saad doo aaniinii yee yádaałti'go éí saad yá'ádaat'éehii, Sa'ąh Naaghéí Saad, Bik'ehózhóón Saad, Tsodizin Saad, índa Yoołgaii Saad, Dootł'izhii Saad, Diichiłí Saad dóó Bááshzhiniin Saad ádaa'éí bee bich'į' yájíłti'go bee bíni' báninájiishǫǫh dóó bee bá nazh nit'áa dooleeł."

Díí kót'éigo na'nitinígíí bik'izh diitį́įhgo dóó binahjį' éí bee naho'ji'áago áko saad doo adaaníinii éí t'áá ałtsxǫ Tádídíín Saad dóó Tó Ałtah Naashchíín bidahtoo' nídadooleeł. 

CHIEF JUSTICE HERB YAZZIE
NAVAJO NATION JUDICIAL BRANCH

status_message:
Community encouraged to attend gathering to share ideas on a Navajo constitution

By Bill Donovan
Special to the Times

 WINDOW ROCK - The White Cone Chapter is spearheading an effort to create a tribal constitution by holding a gathering of grassroots Navajos at the chapter's community building on Saturday.
 The event is set for 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. and will be co-sponsored by Diné Biziil, a reservation-wide grassroots organization. Lunch will be provided.
 Norman Brown, co-founder of Diné Bizill, said that although there have been unsuccessful efforts in the past to develop a tribal constitution, all of which went nowhere, he feels that the efforts this time will be successful because of the recent election of Russell Begaye as tribal president.
 Brown pointed out that Begaye supported the creation of a tribal constitution during his campaign as a way to unify the Navajo people and bring stability to the tribal government.
 He said he wants this gathering Saturday to start the groundwork for the development of a constitution and get people talking about what they would want in it.
 After this gathering, the plans are to hold other gatherings in major communities on the Navajo reservation to continue getting input. There are also plans to hold a rally during the July tribal council session in which grassroots Navajos from all four directions will come in on horseback to urge members of the council to lend their support to the effort.
 Once a constitution is developed, Brown said the group plans to present it to the council and then to the Navajo people through a referendum.
 When asked how long this should take, Brown said he hopes to see a proposed constitution developed by the end of 2016 and final approval within four years.

status_message:
Sovereignty Day based on landmark decision

By Bill Donovan
Special to the Times

     WINDOW ROCK - If you went to Window Rock on Monday, you may have noticed that tribal offices were closed. The reason was that the tribe was celebrating its annual Sovereignty Day.
    The tribe has been celebrating it since 1986 to commemorate a landmark decision by the U.S. Supreme Court that affirmed the tribe's inherent power to tax.
    Former Navajo Tribal Chairman Peter MacDonald began the effort almost seven years before, declaring that all sovereign governments had the right to tax, and his successor, Peterson Zah, kept up the effort.
    The approval resulted in the tribe setting up a series of taxes -- possessory interest, business and gross receipts -- that provided the tribe tens of millions of dollars a year. Until today, the highest source of revenue for the Navajo Nation comes from its various taxes.
    Just how important is this to the tribal government? Since 1986, total tax revenues have far surpassed $1 billion.

Begaye-Nez Inauguration to be held at Fighting Scouts Events Center on May 12

By Bill Donovan
Special to the Times

WINDOW ROCK - Navajo Nation President-Elect Russell Begaye and Vice-President Elect Jonathan Nez this weekend released some details of the upcoming swearing-in ceremony and transition.
    The swearing in will take place at the Window Rock High School Beeholdzil Fighting Scouts Events Center in Fort Defiance, Ariz., on May 12.
    Between then and now, the two will be working on deciding on who will be running the tribal government once the new leaders take over.
    "Now, we roll up our sleeves and get to work," Begaye said on his Facebook page.
     "Our transition team is working diligently to build our administration leading up to our oath of office. While we build a quality team to work for our Navajo people, we also close out our campaign activity.  We invite you to take down our campaign signs around Navajoland as our team is also working to remove signs," he added.
    The campaign is now accepting applications from people who want to work in the new administration and a committee has been formed to help with the vetting process.
    All of the 14 division positions are still open, Begaye said, and the committee is looking for people "with experience, education and passion" to fill them.
    Persons who are interested can send their applications and resumes to P.O. Box 298, Window Rock, Ariz. 86515 or call 505-369-9938. Interested persons can also email to begayenezhr@gmail.com.

link_name: Shooter on loose in Fort Defiance area - Navajo Times

status_message:
UPDATE: According to Rex Kontz, deputy general manager for NTUA, he is 99 percent sure that a NTUA employee was not involved in today's shooting at Fort Defiance. 

"We have a utility operations center where everybody checks in by radio. We received no reports of anyone being shot at," Kontz said, adding that they had all supervisors and managers confirm with their field staff and all field staff have checked in.

"No one reports any shots fired. We're going through the process of checking everyone in our offices," he added.

UPDATE: The road block on Route 110 in front of the Rio Puerco Acres has been lifted, according to Deswood Tome, chief of staff. The community is still under surveillance while officers continue to search for the area for a suspect.

"They are still searching," Tome said, but Navajo Nation Police officers have interviewed two subjects.

UPDATE:

Shooter on loose in Fort Defiance area
 
Navajo Times Staff
 
            FORT DEFIANCE – Navajo Nation Police has reported an "active shooter" is on the loose in Fort Defiance and advises Black Rock Acres and Rio Puerco housing to take precaution and stay indoors.

            According to Deswood Tome, chief of staff to Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly, Navajo police received a call about a suspected shooter firing at a Navajo Tribal Utility Authority employee.

            The active shooter, male subject, is hiding out in the Rio Puerco housing area, Tome said, adding that residents at both Rio Puerco and Black Rock housing areas need to stay indoors.

            At approximately 1:25 p.m. Tome said, "The police are down in this portion of the neighborhood. More backup is on their way."

            That backup includes Navajo Criminal Investigations team, Crownpoint Police District, Window Rock Police District and Arizona Department of Public Safety.  In addition, the Navajo Nation Fire Department and security from the Window Rock Unified School District has diverted traffic.

            Tome said that Navajo Nation Police Captain Bobby Etsitty in charge of the scene.

            "For everyone's safety and safety of the officers, they're calling more police in," he added. "Nobody is hurt."

            Law enforcement does have an idea of where the suspect is, but no exact location. "They are not taking this lightly," Tome noted.

            No updates have been provided about the NTUA employee that was shot at by the suspect, according to Tome.

            According to Deenise Becenti, spokeswoman for NTUA, "We're just allowing law enforcement to do their jobs."

            Schools within the Window Rock Unified School District are also on lockdown, according to Window Rock High School Principal Donna Manuelito.

            Manuelito said the district got a call from Navajo police to go on lockdown at 12:13 p.m.

            This reported shooting in the Fort Defiance area is the second one to occur in the Navajo Nation this week.

            On Wednesday, Navajo Technical University in Crownpoint, N.M., was also on lockdown, after an armed student barricaded himself in the student housing on campus. No one was hurt in this incident, according to Shelly spokesman Rick Abasta.

            According to Navajo Times reporters Shondiin Silversmith and Stacy Thacker, who are in the field, traffic is currently being redirected at the intersection in Fort Defiance, with a few bystanders looking on.

            The reporters noted that over ten police units are on the scene, with police moving in on the subject in both housing areas.

            For more on this story, stay tune.

Photo: Heavily armed Navajo police, Apache County Sheriff's deputies and an FBI agent knock on a door during a search for an alleged shooter on Friday afternoon in the Rio Puerco Housing area in Fort Defiance, Ariz. Police have made no arrests. (Times photo - Donovan Quintero)

status_message:
JUST IN

NTU standoff ends with one arrest

Navajo Times staff

GALLUP - A domestic violence suspect who barricaded himself is behind bars after Special Reaction Teams with the Navajo Nation police forced their way into the Navajo Technical University family housing unit. 

According to a Navajo police who did not want to be identified, around 3:30 Wednesday afternoon, a man, who may or may not be a student at NTU, got into an altercation with his girlfriend. Campus security was called, who arrived to the home. The man then pulled a gun on them. Police was called. At that time, the man barricaded himself. 

A few hours later, Navajo police decided to breach the home when the man refused to cooperate. 

The woman and her daughter were not harmed. It is not known if they were inside the home at the time police forced their way in. 

The police continue with their investigation.

status_message:
JUST IN 

Benefit bike run for Officer Hale to take place in Shiprock

A motorcycle benefit run will be held Sunday for Navajo Nation Police Officer James Hale, who was injured in a shootout last month. The benefit run is set to start from the City Market parking lot in Shiprock, N.M. Registration begins at 9 a.m. Hale and Officer Herbert Frazier each took a bullet to the leg during a March 19 shootout with domestic violence suspect Justin Fowler, which took the life of fellow police officer Alex Yazzie. Hale, who was transported to the University of New Mexico hospital for his injury, was later released and transported to the San Juan Regional Medical Center in Farmington, N.M. For more information, call 505-406-1176, or 505-860-4673.

Officer James Hale is scheduled to be released from the University of New Mexico Hospital on Wednesday, President Ben Shelly's Chief of Staff Deswood Tome confirmed today. Hale, an officer with the Navajo Nation Police Shiprock Station, suffered a serious leg wound on March 19 in the gunfight that killed fellow officer Alex Yazzie, 42, and the suspected shooter, Justin Fowler, 27, after Fowler led police on a high-speed chase from Littlewater, N.M. to Red Valley, Ariz.

JUST IN 

New Mexico, Arizona phone customers affected by severed fiber optic cable near Gallup

Navajo Times

 

            WINDOW ROCK – A fiber optic cable in the Gallup area has been cut, causing an outage of service, including some mobile phone companies, reports the New Mexico Public Regulation Commission. 

            In an April 3 news release, the PRC noted the cut of the cable caused an outage of service to some of Sacred Wind's customers.

            It has also affected some mobile phone service that depends on Sacred Wind's fiber systems.

            "Those affected customers of Sacred Wind cannot place outgoing call, but they can call 911 and can receive incoming calls," states the news release.

            Sacred Wind notified the PRC of the issue and stated they do not know how many Century Link customers were affected. Verizon has reported, customers in parts of New Mexico and Arizona, have been affected, noted the PRC. 

            Information: Call New Mexico Public Regulatory Commission at 505-827-4446

status_message: The time for Officer Alex Yazzie's funeral has been finalized: 10 a.m. at Piñon Hills Community Church, 5101 N. Dustin Ave. in Farmington, N.M. To help the family with funeral expenses, a deposit can be made at any Wells Fargo Bank to the Alex K. Yazzie Memorial Fund.

FUNERAL SET FOR FALLEN OFFICER

The funeral for fallen Navajo Nation Police Officer Alex Yazzie has been set for Friday at the Pinon Hills Church in Farmington, according to a family member. 

An employee at Desert View Funeral Home in Shiprock, which is in charge of the arrangements, said the time has not been set yet but will probably be 10 or 11 a.m.

A reception will follow at the National Guard Armory and interment will be in Memory Garden in east Farmington.

Yazzie, 42, died in an exchange of gunfire with a suspect in a domestic violence case last Thursday night in Red Valley, Arizona. The suspect, 26-year-old Justin Fowler of Littlewater, New Mexico, also died, and two other police officers were wounded.

Shooter identified

Police in Red Mesa, Ariz., have traced a "shots fired" call to a man who may have been shooting at coyotes, according to a source familiar with the incident. Schools and the Red Mesa Chapter House were placed on lockdown around 2:30 p.m. after someone heard gunshots and called the police. Council Delegate Davis Filfred ((Aneth/Mexican Water/Red Mesa/Teec Nos Pos/Tólikan) said the Head Start and senior center in Red Mesa were evacuated and roadblocks were set up while police investigated. "It may have been a bigger response than usual because of what happened Thursday," said Filfred, referring to a shootout in Red Valley, Ariz. that killed the suspect and one police officer. A man dressed in black and carrying a gun was apprehended about 4 p.m., according to the source. It was not known if any charges were filed.

BREAKING NEWS

Schools in Red Mesa, Ariz. and Montezuma Creek, Utah were placed on lockdown since about 2:30 p.m., school employees reported, and the Head Start and senior citizens center in Red Mesa were evacuated after someone reported hearing gunshots in the area, Council Delegate Davis Filfred (Aneth/Mexican Water/Red Mesa/Teec Nos Pos/Tólikan) said. "They've also barricaded some of the roads," Filfred reported. Witnesses counted 15 police vehicles in the area.

The Times will continue to follow this story.

status_message:
BREAKING NEWS

Police officers involved in Littlewater, N.M. shooting are identified

Navajo Times

 WINDOW ROCK - The Navajo Nation president's office has released the names of the officer killed during a confrontation with an armed suspect last night as well as two other officers who were injured. Officer Alex Yazzie was killed at the scene. Officers Herbert Frazier and James Hale each took a bullet to the leg. Hale was transported to the University of New Mexico hospital and Frazier was taken to the Shiprock Medical Center.

Suspect, police officer dead after chase
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — A suspect in a domestic violence incident and one police officer are dead with another officer seriously injured after an armed confrontation in Red Valley Thursday night.

According to President Ben Shelly's spokesman, Rick Abasta, Shiprock police were called to the scene of a domestic violence incident in Littlewater, N.M., about 4 p.m. A single officer responded and found a male holding his family hostage with a AR-15 assault rifle.

The suspect, tentatively identified as Justin Fowler, 24, shot at the officer, "but the officer was able to take cover and was not injured," said Shelly's chief of staff, Deswood Tome. Family members also were not injured in the incident.
The officer called for backup and police from the Window Rock and Crownpoint stations, as well as more Shiprock officers responded.

The suspect, whom Abasta said was wearing a bulletproof vest, fled the scene in a silver Ford SUV heading west toward Red Valley. At least 18 police vehicles were involved in the chase, according to a witness in Red Valley.

About 10 p.m., "They caught up to him as he was about to head over Buffalo Pass," Tome reported. Gunfire was exchanged, resulting in the death of the suspect and one officer. A second officer was transported to Shiprock Hospital.
Tome said the weapon used was of a type usually carried by police rather than civilians.

"We don't know where he got it," he said.

The names of the officers were not immediately available. Tome said they were both male and from the Shiprock unit.

Shelly signs referendum into law. People get to determine fluency.

By Navajo Times Staff

WINDOW ROCK — The Navajo people will get a chance to decide for themselves just how important it is for their tribal president and vice president to be fluent in the Navajo language.

Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly signed into law Monday a bill approved by the Navajo Nation Council on Friday calling for a referendum.

The call for a referendum came from Council Delegate Leonard Tsosie who said that this was a decision that should rest with the Navajo voter and not the council or the tribal courts.

Shelly agreed with this, saying that "I maintain  that the Navajo people are the governing authority."

Shelly's approval on Monday also allocates $317,891 from the tribe's undesignated reserves to pay for the referendum.

The big question now is how that will affect the upcoming special election for tribal president.

Edison Wauneka, the director of the tribe's election office, said Monday that the council's push for a referendum puts him once again in the middle of a fight between the council and the Navajo Supreme Court which has ruled several times that the special election for tribal president must be held as soon as possible between Joe Shirley Jr. and Russell Begaye.

The big question now is just when the referendum will be held.

Will it be held before the special election and if so would the outcome of the special election affect who would run in the special election? Or will the court continue to order a special election only between Shirley and Begaye?

The answer to this may come later this week when Hank Whitethorne and Dale Tsosie, the two former candidate for tribal president who filed the original challenge that removed Chris Deschene from the ballot, file an expected motion before the supreme court to get the court to force the election office to move forward on plans to hold the special election on April 21.

Pick up a copy of the Navajo Times this Thursday for the full story.

The Navajo Nation Council held a special session on March 13 to address the legislation that would provide funding for the special election on April 21. 

Click the link for the full story: http://navajotimes.com/rezpolitics/election2014/council-passes-election-legislation-with-referendum-on-fluency/#.VQOaIo54rec
link_name: Council passes election legislation, fluency referendum - Navajo Times

status_message:
Laguna-Acoma boys wear down Clayton

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

            RIO RANCHO, N.M. – With contributions from nearly everyone, the Laguna-Acoma Hawks advanced into the finals of the New Mexico Class 3A state boys basketball tournament.

            Laguna-Acoma will play top seed Las Cruces Mesilla Valley on Saturday at 10:00 a.m. at the famed Pit on the University of New Mexico campus.

            In Thursday night's win, the Hawks had seven players score with five starters reaching double figures headed by the 24-point effort turned in by senior Ryan Arkie.

            Arkie, who also had four steals and three assists, felt that his team got a much-needed lift from the crowd as Laguna-Acoma took down the Clayton Yellowjackets, the tournament's No. 2 seed, with a resounding 89-72 win on Thursday night at the Santa Ana Star Center in Rio Rancho, N.M.

            "It motivates us," Arkie said of the electric atmosphere. "The louder the crowd the better we play." 

            The crowd got even louder when the Hawks opened the fourth quarter on a 10-0 run thanks to their suffocating defense as they extended a three-point advantage into a 67-54 cushion with 5:40 to play.

            "We weren't having trouble scoring but we weren't stopping them so the focal point had to improve defensively," Peil said of the adjustments they made. "Usually our defense creates a lot of our offense so when we're creating stops and rebounding we can get out and run.

            Peil said his team also did a good job of moving the ball on the offensive end.

            "We started attacking the middle of their zone and we got some good ball reversals so we got some open looks," he said.

            Laguna-Acoma guard Jalen Smith was one of the recipients that benefited from that scheme as he finished with 21 points, which was more than his average.

            "Every dish that I got I had to put up because I was wide open," Smith said. "I felt that nobody could stop me."

            The Hawks also got 13 points from David McGee while Kameron Joe and Matt Sanchez added 11 and 10, respectively.

            Going into their match with Clayton, Peil said they wanted to run the ball and wear the Yellowjackets out since they don't sub that much. 

            "They did more of that tonight than they did  in the past," Peil said of Clayton going seven deep.

            Clayton coach Jon Leal said his boys battled hard but they got into foul trouble early.

            "We didn't have a lot of depth this year," Leal said. "But hat's off to Laguna. They are a well-coached team and they came to play tonight. They were the better team tonight."

            Leal said with an uptempo game they had more turnovers than usually but he did acknowledged the discrepancy in the number of fouls called as his team was whistled 22 times while Laguna-Acoma had nine infractions.

            "The key stat that I saw was they went to the line 29 times and we had five attempts all game," Leal said. "There was a lot fouling but I really don't know what to think about that."

            Mark Craine led Clayton with 21 points while Koy Geary finished with 14 and Jorge Leos added 13.

            In Class 2A, Magdalena pulled away from Mora at Bernalillo High School as the top seeded Steers improved their record to 30-0 with a 78-65 win on Thursday.

status_message:
Gallup boys and girls have a chance to sweep Class 5A field

 

By Sunnie R. Clahchischiligi

Navajo Times

 

ALBUQUERQUE – For the first time, in a long time, the city of Gallup, N.M., will be a ghost town.

The Gallup High School boys and girls basketball teams have made it to the New Mexico Class 5A basketball finals.

The No. 1 seeded Lady Bengals will meet No. 2 Los Lunas at 7:30 p.m. today, at The Pit for their final game of the season.

The No. 2 Bengals will meet No. 1 Centennial tomorrow for a 2 p.m. game also at The Pit.

Gallup girls got past No. 4 Espanola Valley in the semifinals on Thursday, defeating them 78-51.

The Lady Bengals have been traveling back and forth to and from Gallup to play in the state tournament this week and yesterday it played a factor in the first quarter of their game.

Gallup head coach Kamau Turner said his team wasn't quite ready going into the game.

"They had to wake up, they had to come, they had to play and that's what they finally did in the second quarter," he said.

At the end of the first quarter Espanola Valley led the Lady Bengals 16-13. In the second quarter, Gallup went on an 11-0 run and never looked back.

Turner said if his team continues to play disciplined they'll be ready to go against Los Lunas.

In light of remarks made by Los Lunas coach Marty Zeller, who publically stated that Gallup should not have had the No. 1 seed, Turner said it will all be resolved this evening.

"That's fine for them, whatever they want. Tomorrow (today) we both get a chance to prove it," he said. "We're going to come, we're going to get to work and give them our best shots – I want to bring a state championship for these kids."

 

Gallup Boys

 

The Gallup boys made history yesterday by being the third team to make it to state finals. 

The Bengals came in runner up in the 1930s and recently in 2012, under now head coach Domonic Romero. 

They earned their third ticket in history when they defeated No. 6 Grants High School 70-36 in the semifinal yesterday.

Romero said his team had the right start to finish the win.

"We got to get an early start. That was one of our goals that we wrote on the board, we can't come out with sluggish legs," he said. "Right from the get go we got off to a good start like we wanted to, so I think that was the deciding factor."

The Bengals had a small 8-5 lead over Grants at the end of the first quarter.

A few runs in the second quarter put them ahead 29-14 at the half. The rest was history.

Romero said he and the team are ecstatic to be back in the finals.

"When I first got hired seven years ago my goal was I wanted to take Native American kids and put them in The Pit," he said. "We had a group of kids and I said 'how many of you guys have ever been to The Pit?' They had no idea what it looked like."
link_name: Photos from Navajo Times's post

status_message:
Champion speller named after eight rounds

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau

KAYENTA, Ariz. – It took only eight rounds, but fifth-grader Kelvin Winney won the Navajo Times' Navajo Nation Spelling Bee on Thursday afternoon. 

Keeping an eye on his family, the 10-year-old took home the championship with the word "virtuosa," meaning "a girl or woman who is a virtuoso – an experimenter or investigator, especially in the arts and sciences," according to the Merriam-Webster's dictionary. 

The crowd's clapping and cheers created a roar inside the Monument Valley High auditorium when Winney, from Canyon De Chelly Elementary, was declared the champion. 

So what does it take to win the Navajo Nation Spelling Bee? On one hand, Winney says it takes courage. 

"Just the feeling of all these people and what you've to do, it's kind of hard for some people to understand that," he said. 

His mother, Nora, on the other says she's exhilarated by his win. 

"He's been studying," she said. "It's great that he won. Every time he went up (to the microphone), we (as a family) were scared for him." 

"We practiced with him and we encouraged him," she added. "We always told him, 'Participation is good.'" 

Winney walked away at the end of the day with a number of prizes including an Apple iPad mini, Webster's Third New International Dictionary, and an all-expense paid trip to the 2015 Scripps National Spelling Bee contest in National Harbor, Md. at the end of May. The trip is paid for by the Navajo Times. 

For a full story, read the March 19 edition of the Navajo Times. 

Photo: Navajo Times CEO and publisher Tom Arviso Jr. congratulates Navajo Nation Spelling Bee champion Kelvin Winney on Thursday afternoon at the Kayenta-Monument Valley High auditorium. (Navajo Times photo – Krista Allen)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Gallup boys advance with last second shot

Bengals play Grants at the Pit, Laguna-Acoma boys also advance

 

By Sunnie R. Clahchischiligi

 

Navajo Times

 

            ALBUQUERQUE – Everything from a last-second shot to a defensive battle is what led three local boy'sbasketball teams to advance into the semifinals of the New Mexico state basketball tournament.

            The Gallup High School Bengals, the Grants High School Pirates and the Laguna Acoma High School Hawkswill play in today's semifinals for a chance to advance into Saturday's finals held at the WisePies Arena on the University of New Mexico campus.

            The No. 2 seeded Bengals defeated No. 7 Farmington High School in the quarterfinals on Wednesday with junior Colton Lowley hitting the game winning basket just as time expired for an exciting 61-59 win.

            The Bengals is scheduled to play No. 6 Grants at 3 p.m. today at the WisePiesArena (The Pit). Grants upset No. 3 Roswell in the quarterfinals with a76-71 victory.

            In their fourth meeting this season, Gallup played the Cinderella role to advance.

            The Bengals couldn't buy a basket for three quarters, but in the fourth stanza they came back from a 24-point deficit and hit a shot in the paint at the buzzer.

            Gallup head coach Domonic Romero said his boys had the fire lit underneath them.

            "Farmington kicked our butts all three quarters and I think we played one good, great fourth quarter,"he said. "When you have a fight to not give up, it's tough to stop us. That game was 100 percent on the players."

            In Class 2A, the No. 3 Laguna Acoma Hawks defeated No. 6 Texico High School, 60-55, in the quarterfinals.The Hawks are scheduled to meet No. 2 Clayton in today's semifinals. Tip off is at 6:30p.m. at the Santa Ana Star Center in Rio Rancho, N.M.

            The Hawks got off to a good start but they only scored five points in the second and trialed 28-24 at the half.

            Laguna Acoma head coach Ryan Peil said his team turned up the notch on defense, which clinched them the win.

            He said they were down by seven points and they turned it around, which lead to a 12-point  lead.

            "That's an 18-point stretch where we really played good defense," he said. "We forced them to take a lot of bad shots, we got out and ran better, and got some transition shots, and that makes all the different for us."

            The boy's teams whose seasons were cut short were Farmington and Kirtland Central High School.

            Farmington had a stellar start in their game with Gallup but fell short in the final quarter.

            Farmington head coach Paul Corley said there were a number of factors that played into their loss at theend.

            "I take a lot of blame for what happened there at the end," he said. "I should have done a better job of coaching, that's what it comes down to there at the end.Their pressure and their couple (of) 1,000 fans really got this place rocking."

            Farmington ended their season 20-10 overall.

            No. 8 Kirtland Central fell to No. 1Hope Christian 77-58 in the quarterfinals.

            Kirtland Central head coach Brian Dowdysaid his team was confident but mental fatigue set in and it got the best of them.

            "Even last night, this morning, we felt good about the matchup," he said. "We didn't execute theway we wanted to. The boys weren't afraid though."

            The Broncos ended their season 11-18 overall. 

     The No. 6 To'hajiilee High School fell to No. 3 Logan High School in the quarterfinals, 68-64.

status_message:
Shiprock, Gallup, advance to semifinals 

By Sunnie R. Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. – The Gallup High School Lady Bengals and the Shiprock High School Lady Chiefs are two games away from a blue trophy.
Gallup and Shiprock both survived the quarterfinals of the New Mexico high school state basketball championships on March 10.
They are the only area girl's teams left in the tournament.
No. 3 Shiprock defeated No. 6 Sandia Prep 61-50. They will meet No. 2 Hope Christian at 11:30 a.m., tomorrow at the University of New Mexico Wise Pies Arena (The Pit).
Shiprock head coach Larenson Henderson said both teams seek vengeance for different reason. 
The Lady Chiefs defeated Hope last year in the semifinals of the tournament but came up short to Portales in the finals.
"Hope is really looking forward to it, I know that," Henderson said. "Last year we gave them a good number ahead of them and I think they want some revenge, and right now my girls feel the same way; we want some Hope right now."
Shiprock struggled with their offensive game against Sandia Prep, shooting 1 for 21 behind the arch and 18 for 52 in field goals.
Their inability to light up the scoreboard resulted in a close first half with Sandia Prep. At the half the Lady Chiefs led 24-23.
The two teams were tied up at the end of the third at 40 points apiece. Shiprock managed a 10-0 run to start the final quarter and managed to keep the lead before closing in on the Sundevils. 
Henderson said knowing his team could pull together for the tough win made it that much sweeter.
"To have something like that and still pull off a win…I'm even more happy," he said.
No. 1 seed Gallup defeated No. 9 Belen High School 76-33 and will meet No. 4 Espanola Valley in the semifinals tomorrow at 1:15 p.m., also at The Pit.
In typical Lady-Bengal fashion, Gallup got off to a running start on Belen and led 27-7 at the end of the first quarter. 
They allowed Belen to outscore them 13-12 in the second quarter, but Gallup head coach Kamau Turner said his team managed to gather themselves.
"Overall you can't be mad. It's survive and advance, and that's ultimately what we want to do," he said. "The second quarter we had a little turbulent time where we forgot that we needed to play defense, but the girls came out in the third and they picked it up and made up for it."
Here is a look at the other local teams that were not as fortunate to advance to the semifinals.
In Class 4A, Kirtland Central High School and Santa Fe Indian School fell short.
The No. 5 Lady Broncos were defeated by No. 4 St. Michael's 45-37. No. 2 Hope Christian defeated the No. 7 Lady Braves 47-35.
The No. 6 Tohatchi High School Lady Cougars and No. 7Laguna Acoma High School Lady Hawks both came up short in the Class 3A bracket.
No. 3 Eunice defeated Tohatchi 56-54. No. 2 Texico defeated Laguna Acoma 43-29.
In Class 2A, No. 2 Melrose High School defeated No. 7 Ramah High School 59-38. No. 5 Magdalena High School upset No. 4 Jemez Valley High School 64-63. 
For more about the quarterfinals of the state tournament pick up a copy of the Navajo Times tomorrow. 
For updates from the tournament follow Navajo Times sports writer Sunnie Clahchischiligi on twitter @clahchischiligi.

status_message:
Three area teams driving the longest distance for their playoff bid

Navajo Times Staff 

Driving long distance will be the norm for three local teams during the opening round of the New Mexico state basketball tournament.

The Tohatchi High School Cougars, the Navajo Preparatory School Lady Eagles and the Shiprock Northwest High School Lady Falcons, will each have to travel more than 400 miles for their chance to play in the New Mexico high school state basketball playoffs that begin today.

According to Google Maps, the No. 15 seed Tohatchi boys' team will be putting miles on their bus than the latter two. Tohatchi is taking on the No. 2 seed Clayton Yellowjackets on Saturday at 6 p.m. The Cougars will be traveling 432 miles, one way, before they reach their destination. 

The second furthest drive goes to the No. 15 seed Navajo Prep Lady Eagles, who will be taking on the No. 5 seed Clayton Lady Yellowjackets tonight at 6 p.m. The Lady Eagles will drive almost 418 miles, one way, for their playoff bid. 

The No. 15 seed Shiprock Northwest Lady Falcons will have the third longest, traveling to Melrose, N.M., to take on the No. 2 seed Melrose Lady Buffalos on Tuesday, March 6 at 6 p.m. The Lady Falcons will travel a total of 804 miles roundtrip. 

The winner of tonight's and Saturday's games will advance to the next round on Tuesday and Wednesday, which will be played at the Santa Ana Star Center in Rio Rancho, N.M., and the University of New Mexico WisePies Arena (The Pit) in Albuquerque, N.M.

Snow, mud create treacherous conditions across rez
 

By Alastair Bitsóí
and Cindy Yurth
Navajo Times
 
CHINLE, Ariz. and NASCHITTI, N.M. — Schools were closed across much of the Navajo Nation Monday after an all-day snowstorm on Saturday that dumped as much as two feet of snow in the higher elevations, followed by warmer temperatures and rain on Sunday which melted the snow and made dirt roads into a muddy, slushy mess. And according to the National Weather Service, it's not over yet.
At least one Navajo Nation Council delegate has said she will ask President Ben Shelly to declare a state of emergency.
Robert Kirk, principal hydrologist with the Navajo Nation Department of Water Resources, said crews were still out gathering data from precipitation gauges Monday morning, but he could conclude from his own experience — including getting stuck in the mud in Rock Point, Ariz., on his way to work — that "parts of the reservation got significant amounts of much-needed moisture over the weekend."
Kirk said the department will put together a report on the storm and its impact on the ongoing drought by the end of the week.
Meanwhile, the lower elevations of the Navajo Nation were experiencing high winds Monday in advance of a cold front moving west to east that could dump another six inches in the Chuskas and 0.1 to 2 inches on the flats, according to the website of the National Weather Service's Flagstaff office.
An employee of the Navajo Nation Department of Emergency Management who hung up when asked for his name said Monday the office had received no reports of stranded families needing help, but in Tse AlNaoztii Chapter, officials reported at least five instances of stranded motorists.
At least 6 inches of snow fell in the chapter over the weekend that has since soaked into the ground and turned into mud. At the base of the Chuskas, Gerald Henderson, president of Tse AlNaoztii ALERT, said there was over 8 inches of snow. 
"As of yesterday, we are the chapter that got hit the hardest within the base of the mountain," Henderson said, noting that he's gotten calls from people who are stranded or got stuck in the mud.
 Last night, Henderson, members of the ALERT team as well as other volunteers, were out rescuing individuals from their vehicles at 1 a.m. Five vehicles were stuck, he noted. 
As a result of the treacherous conditions, the chapter will declare an emergency. So far, the chapter has been working with the American Red Cross to a set up a shelter, where it housed two elderly people last night. 
"Everything is just melting and creating a lot of mud," Henderson said. "At the base of the mountain there is still snow."
As of this morning, Council delegate Amber Crotty said she's working with officials in Window Rock, including Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly and the Navajo Nation Department of Emergency Management, to see if a declaration of emergency can be ordered Navajo Nation-wide.
"The chapter opened up the chapterhouse for those who are stranded, and are working with the American Red Cross," Crotty said. "They're helping people out of the mud."
Crotty also said ALERT officials have told her constituents there are out of wood, coal or other energy resources to keep warm.
"It's not  just our chapters on this side of the mountains, but on the other side like near Kayenta," Crotty said.
Declaring a state of an emergency, Crotty said, would help chapters and the Nation access emergency funding to help meet the needs of the people.
At a planning meeting Sunday in Two Grey Hills Chapter, Crotty heard reports of 18 inches there and at the mid-mountain level close to two feet of snow.
"No one is going out there with a ruler, but it's one of the biggest snowfalls in recent years," Crotty added. 
Now that the snow has melted into mud, the conditions most have to face now is mud. It's the reason schools in Naschitti and Newcomb, as well as Navajo Head Start cancelled classes for the day.
Melvin Stevens, president for the Naschitti Community Governance ALERT, said the Naschitti area is not has bad as in surrounding chapters — other than for those who live in the Fence Mesa area, which is mostly grass lands with clay and the Chuskas. Central Naschitti,where the chapter and NHA subdivisions are located is passable, with the BIA bus routes being muddy.  
Stevens said that about five familes live in the foothills, while another five live further up or half-way up the mountain, where snow is at least one foot.
One of those individuals living in the mountains is Freddie Wilson, who is in his mid-70s.
"Freddie is the only one up in the mountains," said Stevens, who knows this from the ALERT's assessment of families in the area. "He's the only one that stays up there year round. He's been doing that for years and I guess he's accustomed to the weather."
The ALERT president added that the chapter is "mud-bog down" just like other chapters of the reservation.
"The mud factor will probably be the worst, just based off of talking to people from those areas," he added.
Residents in Chinle reported a series of brief power outages Saturday, and Chinle Unified School District closed its schools today, although the BIE elementary and high school in Many Farms remained open.

status_message:
Nation activiates EOC
 
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — As rain and snow continued to pelt the Navajo Nation Monday, the Department of Emergency Management established an emergency operations center in response to the numerous weather-related requests for assistance from the chapters, according to an email to emergency personnel in the chapters from Rosalita M. Whitehair, director of the department.
In the email, Whitehair urged the chapters to fill out an incident report form for each occurrence, so the DEM can evaluate the situation and send aid to the most critical areas. The form can be filled out electronically or printed out and faxed in.
The phone number for the EOC is 505-371-8415.
"We have DEM staff out in the field conducting assessments," Whitehair wrote. "Please continue to keep us updated."
Whitehair said the DEM is working closely with the community health representatives to identify high-risk populations and the Navajo Department of Transportation, the Navajo Tribal Utility Authority and the BIA to maintain important roadways and power systems.
"Please remind our communities that heavy equipment will sink and make matters worse," Whitehair wrote. "The best thing to do is to wait for the mud to dry."
Whitehair suggested checking on the elderly or high-risk families early in the morning while the ground is still frozen.
The DEM is also receiving requests for help from chapter personnel who do not know how to write an emergency declaration, Whitehair reported. The DEM can forward these chapters emergency declarations from other chapters to use as models.
The DEM is preparing a spreadsheet of current conditions, actions taken and needs "and will do the best we can to keep you all updated," Whitehair wrote, adding "Please track all costs."

Slow start spoils Valley's state title bid

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

            PRESCOTT VALLEY, Ariz. – The Valley girls basketball team had a few things go against them in their pursuit for its first state championship.

            The Pirates could not overcome a slow start as they dropped a 67-61 decision to No. 8 seed Phoenix Christian in the Division III girls final at the Prescott Valley Events Center in Prescott Valley, Ariz.

            "We had too many turnovers and we did not shoot enough," Valley coach Julia Six said. "Every time we got the ball we turned it over. I think if we took control of the ball we could have put up more shots."

            Six also cited poor free throwing shooting as a factor in their six-point loss as they connected on 13-of-27 from the charity line.

            "If we made six of those it would have been a tied game," she said. "After that it could have been anybody's game."

            It also didn't help that Latisha Nastacio, Cherelle Speen and Terri Mitchell received their fourth infraction in a 52-second span at the end of the third quarter.

            For the most part those three players helped Valley trim a 47-32 deficit down to single digits heading into the fourth with Nastacio and Speen flustering Phoenix Christian with their defense while Mitchell added a couple of long range shots.

            "That made a difference," Six said, as Nasticio and Speen eventually fouled out. "Playing defense with four fouls is tough."

            The Pirates got as close a 53-50 on a three-point shot from Mitchell with six minutes left but Phoenix Christian got a little breathing run behind an 7-0 run from senior Dinah Watson.

            Watson scored two quick baskets in transition and she capped the run with a trey with 5:06 to go.

            "We weren't getting back," Six said. "We didn't find her on defense and she killed us."

            Watson finished the game with 28 points.

            For Valley, Tamara Nez finished with 17 points while Mitchell added 14 and Nastacio chipped in with 13.

            For a more in-depth story pick up Thursday's Navajo Times.
