status_message:
Page girls back on top, wins fourth state crown

 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

            GLENDALE, Ariz. – It wasn't easy, but the Page girls basketball team collected its fourth state title, the second under head coach Justin Smith on Saturday night.

            The Sand Devils chipped away a 10-point deficit in the second half and rode out that momentum to score a hard-fought 56-42 victory over league rival Tuba City at the Gila River Arena in Glendale, Ariz.

             The Sand Devils put their depth on display with sophomore guard Natasha Henry scoring the first five points of the half before junior Ashley Dempsey and senior Amber Sloan combined for eight points as Page trailed 36-34 after three quarters.

            In the fourth, Page got a big boost from Dempsey as she two treys with her second one spearheading a game-ending 13-2 run.

            "I was really nervous but once we started to go on that run I knew that it was ours to win, " Smith said. "Everyone did what they were supposed to do. We got some big shots from different girls and I thought Ashley Dempsey's three-point shot was huge."

            Sloan led Page with 23 points, including 12 in the second half.

            "I just tried to help my team out," said Sloan about her production, which included a 16-of-18 effort at the charity line.

            "It feels amazing and there is no words to describe it," she said of closing out her year on a high note. "It's a relief that we won but it's nice to know that our hard work paid off."

            For Tuba City, senior Tate Tsingine finished the game with a double-double, scoring 23 points and grabbing 10 boards.

            For a more in-depth story pick up a copy of Thursday's Navajo Times.

Weather wreaks havoc on district tournament games

By Sunnie R. Clahchischiligi

FRUITLAND, N.M. – The winter storm that is sweeping through New Mexico is leaving many high school gymnasiums empty and district championship games postponed.

According to the New Mexico Athletic Association and coaches, many district boys' basketball championship games set for today have been postponed or rescheduled.

As of this morning, the District 1-3A championship game between Newcomb High School and Tohatchi High School has been rescheduled to Monday, Mar. 2 at 6 p.m. in Newcomb, N.M. The District 1-4A game between Bloomfield High School and Thoreau High School set for today has also been postponed and rescheduled for Monday, Mar. 2 at 6 p.m. in Bloomfield, N.M.

According to Gallup High School athletic director Domonic Romero, the District 1-5A game between Gallup and Farmington High School set for today at 6 p.m., has been rescheduled to Monday, March 2 at 7 p.m., in Gallup.

For New Mexico High School basketball updates follow Navajo Times sports writer Sunnie Clahchischiligi on twitter @clahchischiligi.

Tuba City girls knock off Safford to reach championship game 

By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

            GLENDALE, Ariz. – The Tuba City Lady Warriors are acquiring a taste for knocking people down.

            On Friday night, the Lady Warriors made it two in row as they reeled off the last 10 points to pull off an exciting 56-49 win over the Safford Lady Bulldogs at the Gila River Arena in Glendale Ariz.

            The Warriors looked to be down on their luck when Safford, the tournament's No. 4 seed, took a 49-46 lead with 2:52 to go on a lay-up by sophomore guard Crystal Hasse.

            But instead of buckling the Warriors got two straight buckets from an unlikely source as senior Samytha Parrish put in four of her 13 points.

            Earlier in the quarter, the Tuba City post got hurt when she got tangled with a Safford player while grabbing for a rebound.

            "She's one of the toughest ones we have and no one is going to take her out of the game, and not on a foul like that," Tuba City co-head coach Kim Williams, said of Parrish. "Her desire to win and to be a good teammate says a lot about her character. That's how she is."

            Parrish got her arm twisted in awkward way with seven minutes left in the game. She lay on the court for a few minutes in obvious pain before the athletic trainer whisked her away.

            Needless to say, she returned to the game with a chip on her shoulder.

            "I'm a senior and I didn't want to lose this game," Parrish said, "so I felt like I had to step up."

            Down the stretch, the Warriors iced the game by knocking down 4-of-4 free throws.

            In addition to Parrish, the Warriors got 15 points from sophomore forward Keisha Classay.

            "I never count my team out, they always find a way to come back," Williams said when asked if there was any hint of doubt when they were down three points. "I have seven seniors on this team and they want this more than ever before."

            With the win the Warriors move into the Saturday's championship game with Page, which defeated Winslow 52-48 earlier on Friday.

            This will be the fourth meeting between the two schools with Page leading the series at 3-0.

            "The odds are in our favor," Williams said. "I like our odds and having a healthy squad is going to make a difference in our game."

            Williams said she is not anticipating to see anything different but the outcome is going to come down to execution.

            "They know us and we know them but I really hope that the kids from both sides will have a good game," she said. "I know that (Page coach) Justin (Smith) wants to win the game as much as I do but sometimes we just have to let the kids play. They are the ones that worked hard to get here."

Sanders Valley boys and girls are scheduled to play at the Prescott Valley Events Center in Prescott Valley, Ariz., beginning at noon. The Lady Pirates tangle with Patagonia Union followed by the boy's game. They will be facing the No. 3 seed Pima at 1:30 p.m.

At the Gila River Arena in Glendale, Ariz., the Chinle Wildcats will take on the Palo Verde Magnets at noon.
To reach the quarterfinals, the Wildcats defeated the Alchesay Falcons in a 58-55 epic game last Friday night at the Ganado Pavilion in Burnside Junction, Ariz. 

In Div. III girls, Holbrook and Page will play at 4:30 p.m. with the winner moving into the semifinal game on Friday at 11 a.m. against the survivor of the Winslow and Thatcher game. The Lady Bulldogs play Thatcher today at 1:30 p.m. in Glendale, Ariz. 

Tonight at 7:30 p.m., the Tuba City Lady Warriors have a tall task of matching up with top seeded Valley Christian, also in Glendale, Ariz.
Tribute or theft?

status_message:
Area schools canceled due to snow

CHINLE BUREAU - Whether your school is closed this morning depends largely on which side of the Chuskas you live on. 
   All schools on the New Mexico side of the "big rez" are canceled today with residents east of the mountains reporting up to 6 inches of the white stuff and treacherous roads.
   Of the main school districts on the Arizona side, however, only Ganado, Kayenta and Piñon closed their doors this morning, and it was business as usual at San Juan School District in Utah. Most of the BIE boarding schools remained open. Snowfall amounts west of the Chuskas ranged from an inch-and-a-half in Chinle to five inches in Tuba City, with more in the higher elevations.
   The far eastern satellite chapters were also mixed, with Ramah reporting closure and Tohajilee open. No one answered the phone at the Alamo School Board office.

JUST IN

WINDOW ROCK, AZ, - The Navajo Nation Science Fair, which was to begin at the Red Rock State Park, Gallup, NM, is cancelled today (Feb. 24) due to l adverse weather.  
In addition, many schools are closed making it difficult for students to participate.

In Arizona, the teams that are still in the title hunt: Flagstaff boys and girls, Chinle boys, St. Michael girls, Valley Sanders boys and girls, Holbrook girls, Page girls, Tuba City girls and Winslow girls. 

New Mexico begins their district games on Monday. 

For a more in-depth coverage, grab your copy of the Navajo Times on Thursday.

link_name: Shelly, Jim take oath of office - Navajo Times

status_message:
JUST IN

Newly sworn-in Council Delegate Kee Allen Begay becomes Speaker Pro Tem of the 23rd Navajo Nation Council for two weeks from Jan. 13 to 26, when he won by a coin toss. 

Begay called tails in the coin toss, while 22nd Navajo Nation Council Speaker Pro Tem LoRenzo Bates called heads. 

The coin toss, administered by the Navajo Election Administration, came after a 12-12 vote. When Council delegate Mel Begay asked legislative counsel what happens in matters of a tie, Ron Haven, an attorney from the Office of Legislative Counsel, recommended the coin toss.

Early in the special session, Bates had been recommend as speaker pro tem through an amendment to insert his name into the bill. But, the issue of Bates signaling to Council delegate David Filfred to make a motion to have him as speaker was an unfair process to Council delegate Dwight Witherspoon. 
Witherspoon's concerns eventually led to Filfred withdrawing his motion to have Bates' name inserted in the bill, which then resulted in the nomination process for speaker pro tem. Witherspoon advocated for the nomination process to the amendment process. 

As as result, Bates was then nominated by Filfred and Begay by Witherspoon. Council delegate Tom Chee was nominated by his peer Otto Tso, but he declined the nomination.

That pitted Begay against Bates for speaker pro tem.

Begay, a former member of the 21st Council and former legislative district assistant to ousted and former Speaker Johnny Naize, said he's not running for speaker during the winter session, when he was asked by Council Delegate Leonard Tsosie to step away from his nomination after the 12-12 vote.
But, Begay said that it wasn't fair for him to step down unless Witherspoon withdrew his nomination and if the 12 council members, who voted in his favor, agreed. 

At the winter session, which begins on Jan. 26, the new Council will select a new speaker from among its body, a two-year appointment.

The Council adjourned at 6:59 p.m.

For more on the new Speaker Pro Tem, grab your copy of the Navajo Times on Thursday.

In a brief ceremony, Ben Shelly and Rex Lee Jim take the oath of office for President & Vice President of the Navajo Nation in the Presidential State Room at noon in Window Rock, Ariz.

status_message:
SPORTS UPDATE 

Defense helps Gallup defeat Grants

By Sunnie R. Clahchischiligi

Navajo Times

 
GALLUP, N.M. -- The Gallup Bengals are the 71st Annual Gallup Boys Invitational Champions.

The Bengals defeated Grants Pirates 70-63, for the tournament title this evening in Gallup.

The competition was set to be a rematch between the two teams, as Gallup defeated Grants in the Pirates' home tournament just weeks ago.

Gallup head coach Domonic Romero said the team was able to clinch the win with their defense.

"It's kind of been our key to success, being able to put pressure (on teams)," Romero said.

For more from the tournament, pick up a copy of the Navajo Times next Thursday.

Rock Point girls improve 2-0 in conference play 

Navajo Times sports

The Rock Point girls basketball team improved its conference record 2-0 with a 51-21 win over El Capitan on Friday night. The Lady Cougars had to overcome a slow start as they lead 10-8 after one quarter. The Rock Point coach attribute that to not playing a game for three weeks. 

Nonetheless, her club got going in the second quarter and led 23-12 at the half before exploding for twenty two points in the third quarter for a 45-16 lead. 

In the boys' action Rock Point dropped a 67-28 decision. At halftime, the Cougars trailed El Capitan 52-8 at the break before they outscored the visitors 13-10 in the third quarter. Despite missing a couple of key players, first-year coach Ralston Descheny said his boys gave a better effort in the second half.

"We're missing my two point guards so my power forwards were bringing down the ball down the court all night " he said. "But at half time we were playing tough defense."

In addition, Descheny said they were not turning over the ball and they also scored transition points to fuel the run in the third quarter. 

For a more in-depth coverage, grab your copy of the Navajo Times on Thursday at your nearest newsstand.

SPORTS UPDATE 

Monument Valley Mustangs boys and girls teams make it to Striking Basketball Tournament finals
 
 
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. - On the final day of the Striking Basketball Invitational  the Tohatchi Lady Cougars dropped a 54-52 decision to the Magdalena Lady Steers in the finals of the middle school division. The Cougars went on a 13-0 run the end of the third quarter to get back into the match.
 
Tohatchi, however, were outscored 15-11, in the final stanza. 
 
In other tournament action the Monument Lady Mustangs will play the Grants Lady Pirates in the big school finals at 8 p.m. followed by the MV boys who will take on the Albuquerque East Mountain Timberwolves. Both games will be played at the WisePies Arena on the University of New Mexico campus in Albuquerque, N.M.
 
For more on the Striking Basketball Invitational, grab your copy of the Navajo Times this Thursday at your nearest newsstand.

JUST IN

Shelly vetoes language fluency bill for a second time 

WINDOW ROCK - For the second time, President Ben Shelly exercised his veto authority to a bill that would have amended language fluency requirements of elected positions found in the election code.

This is according to a Dec.31 memo he wrote to Speaker Pro Tem Lorenzo Bates and the Navajo Nation Council. 

"In October, legislation that addressed a similar issue was submitted for my consideration," Shelly said. "At that time I exercised my authority vested in me and vetoed it."

"A thoughtful and deliberative conversation should occur regarding the qualifications an individual must meet," Shelly added. 

For more in-depth coverage, grab your copy of the Navajo Times on Thursday at your nearest newsstand.

Red Valley-Cove advances

The Red Valley-Cove Miners advanced into the championship game of the Striking Eagle Basketball Invitational in the small schools bracket on Friday at Johnson Center at the University of New Mexico campus. 
The Miners held Tse Yi Gai scoreless for nearly three minutes in the fourth quarter for a 69-48 win.
Red-Valley Cove is scheduled to play To'hajiilee in the finals at 7:30 a.m. at the WisePies Arena in Albuquerque on Saturday.

status_message:
JUST IN

Council passes resolution for a new presidential election to be held in June

WINDOW ROCK - In an 11-1 vote, the Navajo Nation Council approved legislation for a special run-off election and a special general election for the offices of the President and Vice President, during a special session Tuesday, according to a press release.

Council Delegate Charles Damon II voted against the bill.

Another legislation that seeks to pardon and reinstate nine former members of the Navajo Board of Election Supervisors was also approved.
President Ben Shelly has 10 calendar days to consider both resolutions. 
In addition, the bill would provide approximately $317,000 to the Navajo Election Administration to fund the elections.

Legislation sponsor Council Delegate Leonard Tsosie has repeatedly urged Council to seek a new presidential election since Navajo Nation Presidential candidate Chris Deschene was disqualified by former Office of Hearings and Appeals hearing officer Richie Nez on Oct. 9. 

The run-off election would occur in June of 2015, and a special general election would take place in August with the swearing in of a new president in September.

The legislation states that only the 17 original candidates who ran in the 2014 primary election would be qualified for the special run-off election if they choose to do so.

status_message:
Steamboat official dies in wreck
 
Tséyi' Bureau
 
CHINLE — Steamboat, Ariz. lost one of its commissioners and an important member of the community in a car crash Friday, Commission Manager Flora Nez confirmed Monday.
Deborah Cayedito, 59, was the president of the Navajo Nation Government Development Commission and a member of the Diné Community Advocates Alliance as well as a commissioner for Steamboat community.
Funeral services will be Thursday at 9 a.m. in the Steamboat LDS Church with Peter Yazzie officiating.
Cayedito and another person died in a one-car rollover near Bitahochee, Ariz., Friday. A third occupant was taken to an area hospital and is in critical condition. The names of the other two victims could not be confirmed by press time.
According to Yazzie, who was related to Cayedito by marriage, the car was not Cayedito's and it is not yet clear who was driving as all three occupants were ejected. The car rolled repeatedly for about 50 feet, Yazzie said.
Cayedito was an outspoken proponent of the recently passed Healthy Diné Nation Act, which will levy a tax on junk food to be put toward diabetes prevention.
Nez described Cayedito as "happy."
Cayedito was born and raised in California, according to Yazzie, and came back to the reservation as an adult.
"She was involved in all kinds of community activities," Yazzie said. "One thing she did was a music festival, Steamboat Rocks. She would get donations and feed the whole crowd for free.
"The loss to our community is unfathomable," he added.
The day before her demise, Cayedito had posted on Facebook a thank-you to Council Delegate Jonathan Nez for supporting the Healthy Diné Nation Act and a quote from Ferdinand Foch, the supreme commander of the Allied Forces during World War I: "The most powerful weapon on earth is the human soul on fire."
"Yup, my soul is on fire," she had written above it.
Cayedito is survived by a brother, Ralph Cayedito of Michigan.

status_message:
BREAKING

Western Agency Bureau

 

     TUBA CITY - A 4.7 magnitude Earthquake shook the city of Flagstaff on late Sunday evening. 

     According to the U.S. Geological Survey, the earthquake occurred at 10:57 p.m. about 7.46 miles north of Sedona, Ariz.

     It shook our (entire) house," Windy Harris said, who was knitting at the time. "It felt very weird, like you're about to (collapse)." 

     "It seemed like everything was going to fall," Martha Nez said, who said the quiver was very strong. "The washer was going. I thought the washer fell. It was (for) a few seconds."

     According to the Arizona Earthquake Information Center on the Northern Arizona University campus, anything in the five or six range would get their attention and would likely cause some damage.

     The quake was also felt as far as Tónaneesdizí which more than 77 miles away.

For more on the earthquake, grab your copy of the next edition of Navajo Times this coming Thursday.

status_message:
About 25 Navajo Voter's Right Coalition members marched Wednesday morning to the Navajo Nation Council where the Naabik'iyátí' Committee was meeting to consider an override veto legislation.

The coalition marched from Bashas to show their support for the override and to hand-deliver around 8,000 signatures on petitions, which they gave to legislative officials.

President Ben Shelly vetoed a resolution approved by the Navajo Nation Council on Oct. 24 , which sought to amend language requirements within the Navajo Nation Election Code.

On Wednesday, the Naabik'iyátí' Committee voted 12-5 and approved the language requirement override legislation.

The override will be considered during a two-day special session, which begins on Thursday.

Navajo Voter's Rights Coalition member Dusty Lee said the coalition and its members would continue to speak to their elected leaders about their rights as Navajo voters.

Navajo Nation receives funds from $554 million settlement

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz. _ The Navajo Nation has received funding from a massive settlement in a case that alleged the federal government mismanaged the tribe's natural resources, according to a press release from the legislative branch. 

The $554 million settlement represents the largest, single amount for an American Indian tribe among more than 100 similar cases filed against the U.S. government. The Navajo Nation Council approved it in May.

According to the press release, 12 percent goes to the Permanent Trust Fund, 2 percent to the Land Acquisition Fund and 4 percent for the Veterans Trust Fund after attorneys' fees are paid. The remaining balance will be $409 million. 

The legislative branch is holding public hearings on how the funds should be used. The latest was held Saturday at the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute's Science and Technology Center in Albuquerque, New Mexico.

The funds cannot be used or invested until the ongoing legislative public hearings conclude, and legislation is introduced and approved by council said Bates.

For a more in-depth coverage, grab your copy of the Navajo Times this Thursday. The newspaper of the Navajo people.

status_message:
Diné College Women's Cross Country team brings home a national cross country title

By Quentin Jodie 

Navajo Times

 

WINDOW ROCK – The Diné College women's cross-country team brought home the team title at the 2014 United States Collegiate Athletic Association Cross Country National Championships, which was held in Syracuse, NY on Friday.

The Lady Warriors, who finished fourth last season, packed six runners in the top 12 to dominate the 30-team field.

Diné College accumulated 37 points while second place finisher Cleary University of Howell, Mich., finished with 88 points. 

On the men's side, Diné College made the podium as well finishing second to SUNY ESF. The New York-based university scored 39 points, 19 markers ahead of Diné College.

"Their performance was awesome," Diné College coach Shaun Martin said. "They had very specific individualize goals and they hit them."
Martin said the courses for both the men and women were much to their liking as it featured a lot of hills and grasses.

"It played to our benefit," he said. "It was a strength runners course and knowing that they got out well."

All together Diné College had eight runners earnedAll-American honors with the women's team hauling in six awards.

Pick up a copy of next week's edition of the Navajo Times for a more in depth story.

Presidential election still hot topic at chapters
 
By Cindy Yurth
Tséyi' Bureau
 
BLUE GAP, Ariz. — Out here on Johnny Naize's old turf, a close contest has developed between two young, energetic Council candidates who have both been campaigning hard.
Yeah, nobody wants to talk about that.
One voter couldn't even remember the name of the candidate he chose.
"You know … the lady," he said.
That would be Crystalyne Curley, since her opponent, Kee Allen Begay, is a guy.
But the name on everybody's tongue, even though any votes for him today will not be counted, is Chris Deschene, the candidate ousted by the Navajo Nation Supreme Court Thursday for not speaking fluent Navajo.
"It's all confused," complained Eula A. Begay of Nazlini, who came to the poll not knowing whether she'd be able to vote for president or not. Deschene's name was on the ballot, but voters were being instructed by poll workers not to vote for president, since that election will be postponed following Thursday's Supreme Court hearing in Chinle.
Af that hearing, the justices found the Navajo Nation Board of Election Supervisors in contempt of court for not postponing the election and removing Deschene's name from the ballot as the court had previously ordered.
"What are they going to do next, postpone Christmas?" asked Kathy Begay of Tsélani/Cottonwood Chapter after casting her ballot. "Why don't we just have Christmas in January this year!"
Nelson Bahe, also of Tsélani/Cottonwood, said he had already voted early for Deschene and was upset his vote would not count.
"I fought in Vietnam in 1968," he said. "I never thought I would return to my own reservation one day and they would throw away my vote."
Avis Thomas of Chinle said she had voted for Deschene and she's not giving up.
"See my truck?" she asked, pointing to a pickup with two Deschene/Atcitty posters affixed to its tailgate. "I don't care what they tell me. I'm driving it around like that until Chris is sworn into office. It's my vote and I'm going to defend it."
Even some Joe Shirley supporters seemed sympathetic.
"I'm voting for Shirley," said Eula Begay, 65, "but I don't like the way they kicked that young man off the ballot. It's just dividing us. Who leads us is important, yes, but is it more important than all of us getting along?"
Out in Blue Gap, Ella Vena felt the same way. "I support Joe Shirley," she said, "but I think the right thing to do is to let this kid in. Give him a chance. Not letting him in is going to further divide our people."
Calvin Begay, also of Blue Gap/Tachee Chapter, disagreed.
"He straight-out lied!" he said of Deschene. "Why would you vote for a liar?"
Another woman, who declined to give her name, thought the Supreme Court had made the right decision.
"The law says he has to be fluent," she said. "That's the qualification. I don't know why they had to wait till the last minute to decide this."

A group of about 300 people congregate outside the Chinle District Court. Chris Deschene's supporters have already started contributing money to help him cover the $6,130 in legal fees awarded to Hank Whitethorne and Dale Tsosie. Holding sign is Zenus Yazzie, 18, of Chinle.

    The hearing will begin at 10 a.m. and can be viewed at www.ustream.tv/channel/nnobs

status_message:
After deciding to postpone the election in a  2-1 vote, the Navajo Supreme Court has also written its ruling, a plea to the people of the Navajo Nation. 

The Navajo Times translated the Supreme Court's plea, which they explained in the Diné language.

"T'ahdoo díkwíił yiłkáahą́ądą́ą́' (Ghąąjį' náhást'éigóó yoołkálę́ędą́ą́) bee haiidzíí; Diné Bizaad bił ninhi't'eelyá áádóó t'áá háadida nihizaad nihił ch'aawóle'lágo nihidoo' niidne' haalá nihi bee haz'áanii at'é. 

Áko, k'ad éí baa saad hólǫ́, hónáásdóó ániid naagháhágíí ání, "Shí hanii doo Diné nishłį́įda?" Akót'éigo niha'áłchíní yiniinaa ák'e'edlįį doleełígíí éí doo biniyé áhát'į́įda. 

Ákó, tsełkę́ę́h' dóó ch'kę́ę́h' nohlłínígíí t'áá ánółtsxó' éí niha'áłchiní nohłį́įgo nihaantsáhákees. Ákó, t'ááshį́į́ aanii ashiilcíhínígíí dóó Diné bi naat'ááh bił haz'ą́ą́dę́ę́' nihinaanish bi'oh ádeiilyaandi, dóó éí biniinaa ałk'ihwiit'áahda dooleeł, éí bininaa aniid naagháhágíí dóó nááas silį́'ígíí áadoo ał'aago nihaantsáhákeesí. Hazhó'ó' nihizaad baa'áhółyą́, baantsókees, áádóó ááhani'níge' át'éigo bik'i' doohtįįh dóó baa'ákonohsin, díí baa nanhiikąąh. 

Naat'áanii dajilį́nígííshį́į́ baa txį́į́sh dookahgo, niha'áłchíní ínáhwiidooł'ááł dóó bizaad yaa'ákónízin, yidiits'a' dóó yee nihishjizh, nihił hahodiilaago biniinaa nihizaad nihił ch'aa silį́į́'dóó nihił nantł'á silį́į́' ; éí biniinaa nihi beehaz'áanii, nihizaad dóó nihee'ó'ool'įį éí ak'i hahiiláago ándoolniił hwiindzin. Azháshį́į́ ákót'éígo t'ahdii ana'á k'ehgo nihił haz'áandi nihizaad éí doo nihił ch'aa dooleełda. Nee'nijį' t'áá'áníit'é nihizaad bee Diné náániidłį́į dooleeł. Hózhǫ́ Náhodoodlééł."

"Long ago, it was said: The Navajo language was given to you, "don't lose it," we were told. "It is your everything."

But, there is argument over it now, that the young have started asking, "Am I not Navajo?" Our children, we are not doing this to break our family.

So, young men, young women, and all of our children, we have you in mind. It is probably true, we as parents, did not pass on our teachings, but this does not mean our young ones and our elderly should blame one another for it, nor should they think they are not one and the same. Take care of our language, think about it, and that way, you will understand and know it. This is our plea. 

Perhaps our leaders will start working on this issue, so that our children will learn our language, hear and speak our language again. But, because we were colonized through assimilation we have started losing our language and it has become difficult to speak; we want to keep our Navajo way of life, our language, our prayers and songs, alive. Even though it seems we have made enemies of one another, we will not lose our ways. Through our language, we will always be Diné. Everything will be beautiful again."

Chris Deschene makes a quick stop at campaign headquarters to tell his supporters he is still on the ballot and that they should continue to vote, despite the Navajo Supreme Court's dismissal of his appeal. 

"The people are the ones who will resolve this," Deschene said. "The council will have to decide this one and I hope they make the right decision,"

The Navajo Nation Council is expected to resume fall session on Thursday morning at 10 a.m. after recessing on Tuesday.

Navajo Nation Council Delegate Jonathan Nez explains why the fall session was recessed and having community name of Navajo Mountain, UT changed to Naatsís'áán in Navajo, on Tuesday in Window Rock. 

"Áádóó ła' éíya shinaaltsoosígíí shízhi' bikáá'ishłaah. Éí nléí Naatsis'áándę́ę́' ádaaníníígíí éí bínahjį' éí kódóó naaltsoosíígíí náás kóshłaah béésh bąąh dah si'ą́ní bich'į'. Éí shį́į́ baan'deiht'į́į́ dooleeł," Nez said of his legislation.

Navajo presidential candidate Joe Shirley Jr speaks at his campaign rally in Sonastee, N.M. on Sunday. Shirley addressed his supporters entirely in Navajo. General election is a little over two weeks away.

status_message:
Navajo police officer shot but in stable condition. Suspect apprehended
 
By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau
 
 
 
     KAIBETO, Ariz. - Authorities say Navajo police officer Joseph Gregg was shot in the face with a 12-gauge shotgun and is now in stable condition at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix, Ariz.
 
     Gregg, 40, who is with the Tuba City Police District, was caught up in gunfire on Saturday at a residence along Route 21 where he was responding to a domestic disturbance call. 
 
     Gregg's family says he was working alone in the area every weekend. 
     Navajo Nation spokesman Deswood Tome said, "The assailant shot and wounded him, Gregg."
 
     Tome says Gregg returned fire and shot the suspect. The name of the suspect was not released. Authorities say the suspect then barricaded himself in a home. Thereafter, Gregg was airlifted to Flagstaff Medical Center. 
 
     Later on, the suspect was apprehended.
 
     "This unspeakable violence and alcohol is tearing our families and communities apart," said Coconino County District 5 Supervisor Lena Fowler of the incident. "Our prayers are with officer Joseph Gregg and his family tonight."
    
     In 2011, the late Sgt. Darrell C. Curley, was shot and killed in the line of duty while also responding to a domestic disturbance call.
 
     It is not uncommon that Navajo police officers work individually, rather than with a partner.
 
     "It breaks my heart knowing he did not have backup, "Shanna Gregg-Starblanket said, sister of Gregg. "It makes me wonder how long did he have to suffer alone, wounded, not knowing if there was anyone else around who would hurt him."

       The photograph, taken by Western Agency Bureau reporter Krista Allen, shows officer Gregg, 40, paying tribute to police officers killed in the line of duty on Memorial Day in Page, Ariz., during the Wall of Honor dedication, which took place at the Page Memorial Plaza. 
 
     The Navajo Times will provide updates as they are made available.

status_message:
Deschene to give deposition in Navajo

By Krista Allen

Navajo Times

 

WINDOW ROCK - Once again, the decision to disqualify Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Christopher Clark Deschene was pushed back "until further notice."

In a confined room at the Office of Hearing and Appeals Friday morning, the matter whether Deschene is qualified for president or not was taken before Richie Nez, OHA's hearing officer assigned to the case.

The circumstance came before the Navajo Nation Supreme Court on Sept. 26 at Tuba City Judicial Court on an appeal from an election grievance concerning the 43-year-old candidate from LeChee, Ariz.

The court last Friday reversed the OHA's decision, which it said erred in summarily dismissing the grievances filed by the appellants - Dale Edison Tsosie and Hank Whitethorne. Both Tsosie and Whitethorne are from Western Navajo and former presidential candidates that lost during the Aug. 26 Navajo Nation Primaries. The high court stated at last Friday's hearing OHA had the authority to consider the grievances and remanded the case back to the lower court.

In remanding the matter, the court stated that the qualification for fluency in the Navajo language is a reasonable regulation to a candidate's right to political liberty. And the court ended by asserting that the meaning and standard of "fluency," as Whitethorne suggested in Navajo: If one speaks Navajo, they will interpret and understand Navajo.

Nez opened the hearing about whether Deschene needs a Diné Bizaad fluency test or not according to the standards of the court. The high court reaffirmed the importance of an elected leader speaking Navajo, essentially a directive or guideline the OHA has to use in its decision.

In his motion, Deschene's attorney Brian Lewis said the OHA should dismiss the hearing.

"This matter represents a case which is not entirely a case," said Lewis. "There's not a proper party respondent here to grant the relief. And the relief in remedy sought here are really what's key."

"The petitioners (Tsosie and Whitethorne) aren't seeking some sort of vague declaration or even specific declaration that Deschene is disqualified or ineligible to run for president of the Navajo Nation," continued Lewis. "The petitioners need injunctive relief. They actually need a mandatory injunction which would direct the Navajo Election Administration to reverse this, of Deschene's qualifications."

In response, Tsosie's attorney David R. Jordan said, "This is not that kind of case."

"We're (Tsosie and Whitethorne) directly challenging the candidate's actions," continued Jordan. "We're saying that Deschene lied when he told the Navajo people in April 2014 that he was fluent in the Navajo language."

Arguments from both parties lasted until about 11:45 a.m. before Nez called recess. The hearing officer stated that a decision would be made of whether Deschene would take the fluency test or not.

But, as soon as the parties reconvened at 1 p.m. Friday afternoon, Nez informed the parties, who met behind closed doors, that Deschene would give a "deposition" in Navajo at the Gallup law office of David R. Jordan.

Deschene is scheduled to offer his deposition at 9 a.m. Monday. A deposition is an out-of-court statement that, in this case, would be specific to the presidential candidate's qualifications. 

After Deschene's deposition, Nez said a decision would be made on whether the candidate successfully meets the Navajo language requirements for the tribal presidency.  

For a full story, pick up the Navajo Times on Oct. 9.
link_name: Photos from Navajo Times's post

status_message:
Western Refining withdraws liquor application for Tohlakai store 

 

By Alastair Lee Bitsoi
Navajo Times

                  

WINDOW ROCK – Western Refining Southwest Inc., has withdrawn its application for a liquor license at its Tohlakai Giant Convenient and Gas Station, according to Gary Hanson, the company's vice president for corporate communications.

                  In a telephone interview with the Navajo Times Friday afternoon, Hanson verified the news, saying, "We made the decision this afternoon to withdraw that application."

                  Hanson said that the company contacted New Mexico's Alcohol and Gaming Division Friday at noon informing the entity of its withdrawal of the liquor application.  Western Refining had notified the public of its liquor license on Sept. 16, and had an Oct. 6 deadline for the public to object to its proposal. 

"Our customers have spoken," Hanson added. "We wanted to hear their needs and its something they didn't desire. We agreed to withdraw that (liquor license) application." 

                  News of the company's liquor plans at the gas station, which borders the Navajo communities of Tohlakai and Twin Lakes, N.M., had resulted in the formation of community protests led by the "Standing for Tohlakai Alliance" and Dine Bidziil.   

                  Early Tulley, spokesman for the alliance, stated that the community of Tohlakai had faced the threats of alcohol sales since 1987. And, he said, the news of the company withdrawing its application largely comes from the united front that protested the company's alcohol sales plans.

The alliance had organized two protests in the last two weeks at the convenience store, and also circulated a petition and letters of objection to Western Refining's plans that it will submit to the Alcohol and Gaming Division.

                  "The community has carried on a very strong message," Tulley said, adding that the media also had a major influence on advocating for the local communities. 

                  He added, "The media is the true crier for our community and the reporters are the ones that are the historians, and I believe they didn't want to have this written down as such." 

                  The alliance, in response to Western Refining's plans, had circulated petitions – with more than 8,000 people signing it – that oppose the liquor proposal.  The alliance was out in Shiprock at the annual Northern Navajo Fair Friday collecting signatures from people there, Tulley said. 

"There is no secret, but reaching out and getting support," Tulley said about Tohlakai's successful track record of denying alcohol sales for the third time since 1987.

                  Tulley said he would call the Alcohol and Gaming Division on Monday to verify the company's decision.

"Until we get official notice, we still want to go to Santa Fe to deliver this (petitions and letters of objection)," he added. "We're still going to go through with it and follow up. Its not to say I don't' trust them, but I hate to do all this work and not deliver on our end."

                  For more information on this developing story, buy an Oct. 9th Edition of the Navajo Times.

status_message: What do you think Diné Nation? Is knowing your language so important it supercedes education and experience?

Former Navajo Nation Speaker of the Council Johnny Naize, right, walks with his wife Barbara Naize into the Window Rock Judicial District Court on Tuesday in Window Rock. After months of claiming his innocence of all wrongdoing, Naize entered his plea of guilty to the offense of Conspiracy to Commit Bribery before the Window Rock District Court. Naize has also agreed in his plea and disposition agreement accepted by the District Court that he will assist the Special Prosecutor of the Navajo Nation in its efforts to prosecute the remaining corruption cases against other current and former council delegates. (Times photo - Donovan Quintero)
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
BREAKING NEWS: Naize steps down as Council speaker ...

            According to a press release from the Navajo Nation Council, Johnny Naize today resigned from his position as speaker and council delegate of the Navajo Nation Council.

            "I have been privileged to represent the communities of Tselani/Cottonwood, Nazlini, Many Farms, Tachee/Blue Gap, Low Mountain," stated Naize. "The progress made in my sixteen years of service as an elected official fills me with the utmost thanks for the projects and improvements made for my communities."

            Naize, who began serving in 1999 as a member of the 19th Navajo Nation Council, also thanked members of the Council, legislative staff, and President Ben Shelly for their service and assistance in helping the Navajo people. 

            "I wish him and his family the best as they move forward," said Speaker Pro Tem LoRenzo Bates (Nenahnezad, Newcomb, San Juan, Tiis Tsoh Sikaad, Tse'Daa'Kaan, Upper Fruitland).

            According to tribal law, upon written notice to the Navajo Election Administration, the resignation shall be effective and the Navajo Election Administration shall be authorized to declare a vacancy.

            Edison Wauneka, executive director of the Navajo Election Administration, said a vacancy declaration is expected to be issued today. Following the declaration, each of the impacted chapters will have 45 days to recommend an individual to fulfill the vacant position.

            Appointment of an individual to fill the vacancy will be at the discretion of the speaker or speaker pro tem of the Council, in accordance with Navajo Nation law.

Vietnam vet Gilbert Shorty, who has been sober for 27 years, speaks about how alcohol and how it should not be sold at the convenience store in Tohalakai, N.M. during a protest on Saturday morning. The store, owned by Western Refining Southwest, has applied for a liquor dispenser's license. 

For a more in depth story, look for it in the next edition of the Navajo Times.

JUST IN:
The case of Chris Deschene v. Dale E. Tsosie has been sent back to the Navajo Nation Office of Hearing and Appeals. No decision was reached by the Navajo Nation Supreme Court today.

The ceremony officially announcing a $554 million settlement for a lawsuit against the federal government, filed by the Navajo Nation for the mismanagement of trust assets, has concluded. Among others, officials who spoke at the ceremony included U.S. Dept. of Interior's Secretary Sally Jewell and Assistant Secretary Kevin Washburn, U.S. Dept. of Justice's Sam Hirsch, Navajo Attorney General Harrison Tsosie, and Navajo Nation Executive Director Clara Pratte. (Times photos - Candace Begody)

status_message:
Funeral for Navajo Code Talker Wilford Buck to be held in Farmington

Funeral service for Navajo Code Talker Wilford Buck, 88, from Window Rock, Arizona, will be on Saturday, September 20th, 2014, at Oasis Ministries, 1601 N. Dustin Avenue, in Farmington, N.M. according to Buck's daughter, Meri Redhouse. 

Viewing will be from 10 A.M. to 11 A.M. and service will begin after the viewing. Burial service will be at Memory Gardens. A reception will follow at World Harvest Center, 1024 N. Butler Avenue. 

Buck passed on Tuesday, September 16, 2014, at Rehoboth McKinley Christian Hospital in Gallup, N.M. Survivors include his wife, four daughters, eight grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren. He was proceeded on death by his son and grandson.

There she is, Miss Navajo Nation 2014!

Newly crowned Miss Navajo McKeon Dempsey waves to the crowd on Saturday evening at the Navajo Arts & Crafts store in Window Rock. Dempsey is from Oak Springs, Ariz.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Childhood dream comes true for Oak Springs native

By Krista Allen

Navajo Times

 
     WINDOW ROCK – Just a day before she would be coroneted as 2014-2015 Naabeehó Bich'eekį', McKeon Dempsey smiled and greeted an eager public with the charm and grace of a queen during the Miss Navajo Contestant Meet & Greet.

     On Saturday evening, she walked across the platform in an elegant, purple traditional outfit in hopes of her childhood ambition of becoming the next Miss Navajo. Moments later, her dream came true in front of a capacity crowd and the World Wide Web, courtesy of NNTV5. Dempsey is now officially an ambassador and educator for Diné Bikéyah.

     In her acceptance speech, she said tearfully with a trembling voice, "I'm honored and privileged to be your new Miss Navajo Nation. It was a long process and it has been a lifelong dream … I will do my best to represent you and our people – what we stand for and what we've been fighting for."

     Dempsey, 24, is Kinyaa'áanii, born for Tsé Deeshgizhníí. Her maternal grandfather is Bįįh Bitoodnii. She is the daughter of the late Marilyn Dempsey, who was a Diné culture teacher in Oak Springs, Ariz.

     About her mother, McKeon said, "She supported me throughout my educational goals. I know this is what she wanted for me. I wish she was here with me now."

      The new Miss Navajo's platform will center on the Diné language. Her plan incorporates implementing art into community projects for the youth.

     "It's surrounding art," said Dempsey in an interview with the Navajo Times after the coronation ceremony. "I'll be trying to influence the youth through art, culture, language, and values."

     She is also the recipient of the best essay award. Among her prizes includes a traditional outfit sponsored by former Miss Navajo Winifred Bessie Jumbo (2010-2011), a silver pin and a Pendleton bag from NACE, and a trophy from former Miss Navajo Jonathea Tso (2007-2008).

     She received the best butcher award from Navajo Gaming Enterprise.

status_message:
Election Day at Steamboat Chapter House
By Shondiin Silversmith
(@DiinSilversmith)
Navajo Times

STEAMBOAT, ARIZ. - With primary elections underway all across the Navajo Nation many Navajo communities are executing their right to vote at their local Chapter House.

In the western agency Steamboat Chapter has 1150 registered voters and has seen a steady stream of them come into vote for either the Navajo Nation or Apache County. There at over 45,000 people registered to vote in Apache County, according to officials at Steamboat Chapter.

For local voter Roselyn Barney along with her parents, coming to the chapter house has been a tradition for their family every four years. 

"We always vote every four years and for them (her parents) it's a good time for them to see there friends and relatives they never see," Barney said, adding that they chose to vote because they believe it helps the Navajo Nation. 

But not everyone has a voting tradition in fact for local Rita Kee she hasn't voted since Peterson Zah ran for presidency. 

Her reasoning was she just never re registered to vote when she moved away from Steamboat several years ago. 

But now Kee said she was happy to cast a vote today because she likes it. 

"I don't know which one is going to win, but I don't mind," Kee added, noting that she only knew who a few of the candidates were. 

The Navajo Times editorial staff is visiting various chapter throughout the Navajo Nation for primary elections. For updates visit www.navajotimes.com or follow Navajo Times on twitter (@navajotimes), instagram (@navajotimes) and facebook.
link_name: navajotimes.com - The newspaper of the Navajo People

The final Navajo Nation Presidential Candidates Forum is over.  

Thank you for tuning in and your attention!

Primary election are next Tuesday on August 26th.  Please get out there and vote!

#RezPrezForum

Donald Benally is the last candidate to address the crowd for the forum.  

"The Navajos were the most powerful Indian country over 35 years ago."  

"Dine first." 

#RezPrezForum

Edison "Chip" Begay's said, "Enough is enough!"

He went on to detail that he hasn't seen any good come from the government yet. 

"Have that respect for the people."  

#RezPrezForum

"My reason for running was because I felt our government was broken."

"Opportunities are not available for the people." 

That's why I laid down that $1500, so that I can have a voice.  I paid the price to be here.  We have to hold our leaders accountable.  Our leaders say, "Don't say mean things to me,"  I will say something!  You have to be honest and speak up." 

"The government needs to work for you, not for themselves." 

-Dan Smith's closing remarks

#RezPrezForum

"I'm a strong leader.  We need it in Window Rock." - Myron McLaughlin

McLaughlin thanked his wife and children for listening from home due to their unavailability.  

#RezPrezForum

Hank Whitethorne just finished his concluding remarks.  

Edison J. Wauneka, Edison Begay, Dan Smith, Myron McLaughlin, and Donald Benally remain to deliver their concluding remarks.

#RezPrezForum

Russell Begaye said, "We have our own way of government, we have our own laws." 

#RezPrezForum

"My whole emphasis is that the structure and process of our Navajo government is not adequate to take care of our children in the future.  We also need to take care of the structure of our earth because that is what we leave for the children." - Duane "Chili" Yazzie

#RezPrezForum

Moroni Benally said, "This election is not about choosing a prom king or prom queen .. most often the most popular one is not the smart one."  

He continued with, "We can not allow continued exploitation of our land.  We have to challenge the federal government.  I am not afraid to challenge the federal government.  It's time to start behaving like a nation."

"I will say no to wasteful spending.  Accountability begins in the president's office."

#RezPrezForum

Panelist Katherine Benally asked, "Should you be president of the Navajo Nation, should you get the blessing?  In the event you get elected how will you deal with the obtaining the rights to the Colorado River, Little Colorado River and San Juan River?" 

Dan Smith responded, "We need to take a step backwards and if it takes negotiation to get it, we will." 

Donald Benally said, "First thing I will do is change the water law and that we own 100% of that water... Let's assert our rights, our water rights." 

#RezPrezForum

The final round of question will feature three candidates once more but they will only have one minute to respond.

#RezPrezForum

The 2nd round of questioning has concluded.  

#RezPrezForum

Duane "Chili" Yazzie responds that government reform is necessary. 

"That's why I advocated for a complete change of the structure and form and process of our government."  We our Dine, we have our unique thought process.  We need to redo our government."  

#RezPrezForum

Moroni Benally replied that the Navajo Nation is limited in their prosecution due to federal government constraints.  

"We need to change the way we think, we need to value our women," he added, "Half of these candidates should be women."  

#RezPrezForum

Joe Shirley Jr. believes there should be trash dumps placed at strategic locations across the reservation for people to dump their trash at free of charge. 

#RezPrez Forum

Panelist Ernest Tsosie III asked candidates Hank Whitethorne, Cal Nez, and Joe Shirley Jr. about how they would resolve the illegal dumping on the Navajo reservation.  

#RezPrezForum

The forum is broadcasted live on KTNN (660 AM) and on KWRK (96.1 FM) not 94.5 FM, apologies for the error.

#RezPrezForum

The first round of questions is over.  

For the second round of questions, three candidates will sit together on stage to answer the same question.  

#RezPrezForum

Panelist Radmilla Cody asked Dale E. Tsosie, "How can we ensure that women are properly represented in government?" 

What would your answer be?

#RezPrezForum

Deon Ben, from Tohatchi, standing in line outside of the Red Rock Park auditorium in Church Rock, N.M. Ben says he's still undecided because none of the candidates have mentioned anything about working with the Navajo Nation Council. He hopes to hear a candidate speak about it tonight.

All 17 candidates are now present.  

They are given two minutes to respond a question asked by a panelist.  

#RezPrezForum

Panelist Radmilla Cody's question regarded the recent killings of homeless Navajo men in Alburquerque.  She asked Russel Begaye how he will prevent this from occurring in the future.  

In part of his response, Begaye said he would like to see Navajo Police officers have more power by having the ability to patrol towns with large Navajo populations such as Gallup, Farmington and Albuquerque.  

#RezPrezForum
It's as lively outside as it is inside, here at the Navajo Nation Presidential forum at Red Rock Park.

Panelist Manuelito Wheeler asked Joe Shirley Jr.,
"Many people believe you can seek a third term through a legal loophole, what is your response to that?"

Shirley responded,
"I knew there was a law and that's why I stepped down," in reference to the two consecutive terms her previously served.

Shirley explained that his campaign for this year is allowable since a term has lapsed since he was in office. 
He continued with, "As far as a loophole, I'm not sure there is a loophole...If she or he wants to run again, the law permits it."  

#RezPrezForum
Navajo Nation Presidential forum now happening at Red Rock Park in Church Rock, N.M.

Semi-trailer fire closes U.S. Highway 491 in Naschitti, evacuation ordered

By Alastair Lee Bitsoi
Navajo Times

                NASCHITTI, N.M. – For the second time this summer, Arlene Baloo was asked by Navajo Nation Police Officers to evacuate her home.

                She was told by police officers Thursday morning to evacuate her home because, at mile marker 43 on U.S. Highway 491, a tractor trailer hauling toxic material caught fire. The burning trailer emitted huge plumes of dark smoke that could be seen for miles.

                The accident forced the shutdown of the major highway, which serves as a corridor to the Four Corners area. As of noon, the road was still closed, according to New Mexico State Transportation officials.  Southbound travelers will be detoured onto Navajo Route 5, north of Newcomb, N.M., then U.S. Highway 371.  There is no alternative route, at this time, for northbound travelers.

                "All I heard was a big boom or something this morning when I was in the house," said Baloo, who lives less than half a mile and in plain view of where the semi-trailer caught fire.

                It occurred at about 6:40 a.m. this morning, Baloo said, noting that she saw the driver of the semi detach one of the trailers of the two-trailer diesel truck.

                Seeing the fire and then the smoke from outside her house, said she called the local police and fire departments, who were on the scene between 7:30 and 8 a.m.

                The evacuation was mandated by the Navajo Nation Emergency Response Team, and applies to residents living within a two-mile radius of the accident.

                "That even includes the Naschitti Chapter House," said Rose Whitehair, director for the Navajo Nation's Department of Emergency Management, about the evacuation order, which is merely a precautionary measure.

                Currently, the hazardous materials waste team from San Juan County is on scene assessing the incident, Whitehair said.

                In response to the evacuation, shelters have been set up in Tohatchi and Newcomb chapters. Evacuees who live north of the scene will be sheltered at Newcomb and those south of the scene will seek assistance in Tohatchi, Whitehair said.  

                The evacuation order is the second the community of Naschitti has experienced this summer. In June, community members living in the Chooshgai Mountains and in Naschitti were told to evacuate their homes by fire and police officials because of the raging 14,000-acre Assayii Lake Fire that went out of control from strong, gusty winds and blanketed the community with intense smoke.

                Whitehair said these emergency situations serve as a reminder for the public to always be prepared for a disaster and have a to-go survival kit readily available.

                "For your safety, stay away from the smoke," Whitehair stated in an Aug. 7 press release. "The more distance between you and the source of the smoke, the better."

                Whitehair also stated that it's vital for the public to close and lock doors and keep windows of their homes closed. Other reminders include seeking medical attention if individuals have difficulty breathing, irritation of the eyes, skin, throat or respiratory tract, she said, among other health issues.

                "The hazardous material team is on site and will make a final determination of the chemicals and how they're going to handle the scene," Whitehair added.

                For more on this developing story, visit www.navajotimes.com.
link_name: navajotimes.com - The newspaper of the Navajo People

status_message:
Hank Whitethorne said that Diné people should be able to speak freely and have freedom on how they use the land "Resources on the Navajo Nation are sacred in every aspect." 
#RezPrezForum

"How many terms will it take them to correct a problem!", exclaimed Edison "Chip" Begay in his ending remarks.  Begay spoke primarily in Navajo detailing the inefficiencies of the government and the need for change.  

"You can't train an old dog new tricks!" he ended with. 

#RezPrezForum

"We need a man that has been helping the people since 1965," said Duane "Chili" Yazzie and he finished with, "I am that man." 
#RezPrezForum

"We are considered a third world country.  The Navajo Nation is considered a third world county," said Kee Yazzie Mann in his closing remarks.  He also added that the Navajo Nation could be improved with a fraction of the money from the national government. 
#RezPrezForum

Dale Tsosie emphasized there needs to be better 'checks & balances', more public safety, better education, an improved Navajo Housing Authority and creating a strong infrastructure. 
#RezPrezForum

Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly's concluding remarks were full of the successes his administration has committed over the past four years. 

"You have a strong leader here.  There are a just a bunch of random conversations going on here," Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly ended with in reference to the forum.  
#RezPrezForum #NavajoNation

"This is our land and we should decide what we do with it.  Let's defend the land people!" - Duane "Chili" Yazzie 
#RezPrezForum

The question asked by Nelson Yellowman was concerning Utah Navajos seeking to initiate land development projects and how they (candidate) would address this. 

#RezPrezForum

Edison "Chip" Begay passionately answered the question by saying that people need to be out there in the 'field' and to do work with their hands.  
#RezPrezForum

"59 years old and I can still run with Jonathan Nez," said Hank Whitethorne.  

He encouraged people to set aside 30 minutes to exercise everyday to pave the way for a healthier life in addition to a healthy diet.
#RezPrezForum #Health #Wellness

"You are not the forgotten people."   

"What kind of question is that?" 

Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly responded to the question and he also continued with saying that the community needs to empower itself in order to not think they are "forgotten".  
#RezPrezForum

"There is a dire need and that is the infrastructure of this place (Monument Valley area)," said Dale Tsosie. 

He believes that funds gained from tourism should be utilized correctly and be directed back into the local area through means of proper infrastructure development.

"This will be my plan to help you." 
#RezPrezForum #Infrastructure

Candidates Donald Benally, Dale Tsosie, Ben Shelly and Joe Shirley Jr. are up now to respond to Candace Begody's question regarding how the Navajo Nation will address the "forgotten people" of the Monument Valley community.  
#RezPrezForum

Candidate Edison J. Wauneka said he would hire Moroni Benally for economic development.  Laughter erupted among the entire crowd.  Benally smiled and laughed at the remark.  
#RezPrezForum #EconomicDevelopment

"I think Moroni would be a great Secretary of Labor," said Carrie Lynn-Martin, the crowd responded with laughter.  

"We can not leave ourselves defenseless.  We do not make enough revenue at this time.  Diné sovereignty leaves us on our own." 
#RezPrezForum

"We each have our specialties to bring business to the reservation.  My belief is it goes back to the home."

Dan Smith detailed that Navajos do not help the Navajo economy by shopping in border towns and that we need to help ourselves now.  
#RezPrezForum

Duane "Chili" Yazzie replied that he doesn't believe in government reform in the style of a two-party system because it is of the colonial influence. 

"it's time we stop copying the Americans.  We are Diné it's time for us to go our own way!" - Duane "Chili" Yazzie
#RezPrezForum

Candidates will respond to a question by panelist Nelson Yellowman concerning if there is a need for a two-party system such as Democratic and Republican.  This system could reduce having 17 candidates.  
#RezPrezForum

The last four candidates to answer questions are Moroni Benally, Carrie Lynn-Martin, Donald Benally and Duane "Chili" Yazzie.  A true representation of "old guard" and "new guard".  
#RezPrezForum

"The question is, 'Will it be overturned?' That is your decision," candidate Kenneth Maryboy responded as he pointed to the crowd.  

#RezPrezForum #GayMarriage #LGBT

"I think the Navajo Nation Council made the right decision and that law (Diné Marriage Act) shouldn't be overturned." - Candidate Edison J. Wauneka 
#RezPrezForum #LGBT

"Do you think the Navajo Nation should overturn that law (Diné Marriage Act of 2005)?" asked panelist Candace Begody.
The law bans same-sex marriage on the Navajo Nation. 

Candidates Hank Whitethorne, Edison J. Wauneka, Joe Shirley Jr. and Kenneth Maryboy will answer.
#RezPrezForum #LGBT #GayMarriage

"Are there alcohol treatment centers on the reservation for people who suffer from addiction?"  
#RezPrezForum

Candidate Duane "Chili" Yazzie responds to a question regarding how he would reorganize the Department of Justice system to better serve the people.

"The first thing I would do is to tell the non-Diné attorneys that we want their letters of resignation," he said. 
#RezPrezForum

"We need more parents to get involved in the education of their children." - Candidate Russell Begaye
#RezPrezForum #Education #Parenting

Candidate Chris Deschene replies to a question regarding the recent murders of homeless Navajo men in Albuquerque, N.M. and how it was not considered a hate crime by the Albuquerque district attorney.  

"We ourselves can not let this happen, Albuquerque got it wrong with how they approached it.  With the Deschene administration we will address it." - Deschene 
#RezPrezForum #HumanRights #IndigenousStrength

"Monument Valley is known for its red buttes but it's also notorious for its crime.  What is your position for strengthening public safety in this area?"

Dale Tsosie responded by saying there is a disconnect amongst leaders and public figures.  He believes if there is a better sense of communication then the police force can be strengthened almost overnight.  
#RezPrezForum

Candace Begody, Navajo Times editor asked candidate Moroni Benally, "Who should administer the Utah Navajo Trust fund and how could you break the stale mate in the fund and get the money flowing?" 

Benally responded that you need the necessary people to manage the policies and procedures regarding issues like these.  He continued that certain industries should not effect the environment and those people affected should be compensated.  
#RezPrezForum

"If you put me to work for you, we will see some results." - Candidate Dan Smith
#RezPrezForum #Results

"We need to progress as a nation, I think young leadership will do that." - Candidate Carrie Lynn-Martin  
#RezPrezForum

Almost all of the candidates introduce themselves entirely in Navajo, beginning with their clans and where they are from.  
#RezPrezForum #Navajo #Diné
Local candidate Kenneth Maryboy receives much applause from the crowd during his introduction.  #RezPrezForum

Chris Deschene's introduction, "I'm an attorney, engineer and 10 year veteran of the Marine Corps." 

He added, "I stand for four things. Leadership, protecting and preserving our culture, building a healthy economy, and working to address our future by investing in it."
#RezPrezForum
Candidate introductions are about to begin.  Each candidate is given one-minute to introduce themselves.  #RezPrezForum #FirstImpressions
A total of 16 candidates are present with the exception of Cal Nez.  #RezPrezForum
The Oljato, Red Mesa, and Monument Valley Veterans Organizations posted colors to begin the Navajo Nation Presidential Forum.  #RezPrezForum #NavajoNation #NavajoVeterans

"How will you address the stray dog problem on the reservation?"

Moroni Benally answered with,
"This gets back to the entire management system of the Navajo Nation, they are stretched beyond their means."

Moroni Benally explained that the tribal government lacks the capacity to successfully resolve this problem due to a lack of logistics, education, skill or credentials.  The people running many programs are not qualified to do so, he says.

"We need to replace these people right now.  This is not just about dogs, it is about a larger issue."

#RezPrezForm

"Do you think our laws are sufficient to hold Navajo Nation government officials accountable?  Why or why not?"

What are your thoughts?
Please comment in a respectful manner.

#RezPrezForum

"We need to form a government based on our Diné values." - Duane "Chilli" Yazzie
#RezPrezForum

You can listen to the Navajo Nation Presidential Candidates Forum in Crownpoint, New Mexico LIVE on KTNN 660 AM!  
or
Watch LIVE on http://www.ustream.tv/channel/nnpresidentialforum

#RezPrezForum

Since the introduction of casinos, many crimes and issues have arisen.  The panelist asked Candidate Dan Smith how he would resolve these casino related issues.  

Candidate Dan Smith replied, "I'll shut them down.  It's a bad business ... If you're going to put alcohol and gambling in front our people.  We are going to have a problem."

He elaborated that the money going to the casinos should go towards beneficial causes such as education.  

"We have to face the fact that (casinos) doesn't work.  It takes money from people that don't have it."

#RezPrezForum

Many candidates speak a mixture of Navajo and English when they respond to the questions asked by panelists.  

What do you think of the bilingual responses?  

#RezPrezForums

"Mr. Tsosie, its a known fact that the Navajo Nation does not have enough police officers...How would your administration improve same day response time?"

Candidate Tsosie responded, "The police are not at fault ... they are overworked.  It's the system that is at fault.  We can increase our police force." 

Tsosie details that combining divisions such as the police force, wildlife, rangers and more can completely transform the police force almost overnight.  

#RezPrezForum

The record number of 17 presidential candidates are all in attendance at the forum tonight!

status_message:
Yá át ééh shí diné éh!

The wind is calm, the sun is out and blessing mother earth with its warmth today. 

What is on your agenda for today?

The Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Forum has concluded. All 17 candidates delivered their closing remarks. The next forum is set for July 23rd at Navajo Technical University. For a full report on the forum pick up a copy of this weeks Navajo Times.
To listen to the Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Forum live from Grey Hills Academy Auditorium in Tuba City turn into KTNN 660 AM or KWRK 96.1 FM. The forum is broadcasting live right now.

Female Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Carrie Lynn Martin was asked. "There are a lot of Navajos who believe that a woman should not lead the Navajo Nation as tribal president. What can you tell them tonight that would convince them that you can and should lead the nation?"

Concerning the spending habits of the Navajo Nation administration panelist Manual Watchman, a retired Navajo Nation judge, asked Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Edision J. Wauneka of Oakspring Chapter, "If you were to be elected to the Presidents office will you carry on this kind of activities?"
Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Cal Nez from Sanostee Chapter was asked "What are your ideas to prevent unintentional injuries?" Such as motor vehicle crashes, suicide and elderly falls.
Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Duane H. Yazzie of Shiprock Chapter was asked "What needs to be done to get wind energy back on the table?"

"How do you intend to meet the desire of qualified graduates from High School, College and Trade School that want to return to and remain on the Navajo Nation in consideration of jobs?" A question addressed to Presidential Candidate Joe Shirley Jr.
"As Navajo Nation President how would you improve partnership and collaboration among County, State and Federal Governments, and why?" was the question addressed to Dale E. Tsosie of LeChee Chapter.
"How will you advocate for improvement of the Navajo Public Safety?" is a question addressed to Navajo Nation Presidential Candidate Russell Begaye of Shiprock Chapter.

Each candidate is asked a different question from the four panelist of at the forum. Each candidate has two minutes to answer the question. The order the candidates answer the questions in is selected at random.
The question addressed to Kenneth Marboy of Mexican Water Chapter is how concerns are often raised about the Navajo Nation government. If he is elected what will he do to ensure government reform.
What are you thoughts of legalizing alcohol on the #NavajoNation? was the fifth question addressed to Edison Begay of Tohatchi Chapter.
"How will you as Navajo Nation President will support the revitalization of the Bennett Freeze areas?" is the second question asked to Carrie Lynn Martin of Bodaway/Gap Chapter.
All 17 Navajo Nation Presidential candidates are present at the Navajo Times, KTNN and KWRK forum at the Grey Hills Academy High School in Tuba City.

status_message:
JUST IN

According to the latest update from the Southwest Area Incident Management Team 3, Assayii Lake Fire is now 5 percent contained, thanks to hard work by 24 crews, 27 engines, 10 helicopters & 4 dozers. Firefighters took advantage of lighter winds and aerial support, and as a result, there was minimal fire movement. This will be the last night shift for firefighters. Public is encouraged to avoid access roads leading to Bowl Canyon.

Shelly issues executive order for tribal divisions to assist with Asaayii Fire

WINDOW ROCK, Ariz.— On June 12, Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly issued an executive order calling for a fire restriction based on the advice of the Navajo Nation Forestry Department.

More than 11,000 acres have burned after an unattended fire near Asaayii Lake ignited on June 13 around 3:30 p.m. 

Authorities are evacuating families in Sheep Springs and Naschitti due to fire danger and limited visibility from excessive smoke. Travelers are encouraged to avoid the are

Forestry officials were preparing for the high fire danger due to low precipitation, high wind conditions, low humidity and high temperatures. 

On June 16, the Navajo Nation Commission on Emergency Management passed CEM 14-06-16, a resolution declaring a state of emergency for the Assayii Lake Fire. President Shelly signed the declaration and ordered applicable tribal resources to assist with efforts to contain and extinguish the fire. 

"I direct all Navajo divisions, departments and programs to commit resources to the Assayii Lake Fire. We need to do all we can to stop the fire from spreading further," Shelly said.

Asaayii Lake Fire update

TMC Incident Command System on Standby

FORT DEFIANCE - Tséhootsooí Medical Center's Incident Command System is on stand by to assist with the Asááyi Fire victims and firefighters, according to a press release.

TMC officials are extending support to tribal, state, and community fire management officials dealing with the Asááyi Fire.

TMC's ICS team is concerned about any possible health effects with community members from smoke inhalation and the possible consequences its' toxicity. We encourage anyone who may be experiencing trouble with their health to visit TMC immediately. TMC is ready to provide any health care related support needed. TMC continues to be on standby for any trauma cases.

TMC is aware, the Asááyi Fire is not contained and high winds and extreme dry conditions combine for a long battle. 
 
The Incident Command Team met at 8:20 a.m and at 2:00 p.m. today to pre-plan.  TMC is not setting up the complete full Incident Command Center at this time but is still on direct stand-by as needed.  

TMC ICS has also received numerous inquiries from staff wanting to assist and/or donate to those impacted. The TMC ICS will remain on stand-by, until further notice.   Water, food, bedding, and even board games are being accepted at the Medical Center for employees to donate to the communities impacted by the fire.

For donations, contact: Edison James @ 928-729-8316

Dry vegetation, sustained winds fuels Asááyi Lake Fire

By Terry Bowman
Navajo Times

 
            CRYSTAL, N.M.— A blaze that started in the Chuska Mountains on Friday has consumed more forestland near Asááyi Lake as fire crews try to contain the inferno.

            According to Patrick Willeto, the lead dispatcher with the Bureau of Indian Affairs of Forestry and Wildland Fire Management, the fire has reached roughly 200 acres traveling due east, nearing the Whiskey Lake area.

            With plenty of dry vegetation and sustained winds of over 30 mph, Willeto said the fire has grown by over 125 acres within the last 24 hours.

            Willeto said the Navajo Scouts fire crew will be working around the clock until the blaze is fully contained.

            The area is under a fire weather watch according to the National Weather Service until Monday evening, where strong winds and low humidity are present.

            No injuries have been reported since the fire started on Friday. According to officials, the source of the fire has not been determined.

            For more information call the Bureau of Indian Affairs Division of Forestry and Wildland Fire Management at (928)-729-2307 or the Window Rock Police District at (928) 871-6111.

status_message:
Fire consumes close to 100 acres near Crystal, N.M.

Terry Bowman
Navajo Times
 
CRYSTAL, N.M. — At least 90 acres of land have been consumed from a forest fire burning in the Chuska Mountains north of Asááyi Lake Friday evening, and no one knows why.
Officials say the cause of the fire is still unknown as fire crews from the Navajo Pine Volunteer Fire Department, Bureau of Indian Affairs Division of Forestry and Wildland Fire Management and workers from Navajo Parks and Recreation rush to stop the blaze that occurred around noon on Friday, June 13 on Indian Service Route 311 near Navajo, N.M.
As of 5:30 p.m. 75 acres had already been reported gone as smoke and flames sprouted north of Asááyi Lake from a ridge known as Big Bowl Canyon.
According to Navajo Pine Fire Chief Denniford Deschine, the fire sparked in the early afternoon and was reported by people fishing at Asááyi Lake around 2 p.m. With two fire crews from Navajo Pine first responding, Deschine said the cause of the fire is still unknown and an investigation is pending. The fire may have resulted from extreme dry conditions and drought brought on by hot temperatures and dry vegetation, according to Deschine.  
Johnson Benally of the B.I.A. Wildland Fire Management said the current plan is to secure the south side of the fire near Bowl Canyon Creek to keep the fire away from spreading to nearby Bowl Canyon Recreation Area and the Asááyi Lake Youth Camp.
With the Navajo Scouts Type 2 IA fire crew still en-route, Benally said the next course of action would be to secure the north side of the ridge near Big Bowl Canyon to keep the fire from spreading north along Indian Service Route 32 towards Narbona Pass.
"Once they (Navajo Scouts) get here we're going to try and flank off the north side," said Benally, who said that all fire crews will stop around 10 p.m. and will be back early this morning to continue the fighting the fire before the morning winds pick up.
Any information regarding the fire, call Navajo Pine Volunteer Fire Department at (505) 777-2233 or Window Rock Police District at (928) 871-6111.

Navajo Times Editor receives Game Changer award 

Navajo Times Editor Candace Begody was honored as a "Game Changer" at the 10th Anniversary Spelman College Women of Color Leadership Conference in Atlanta on May 14. Begody was one of 18 inducted into the 10th Anniversary Academy of Game Changers in Atlanta. She received a Game Changer medal for being a twenty-first century leader who is powerful, forward-thinking, and embraces her drive for excellence. Begody earned earned her journalism degree from the University of Arizona in 2010.

status_message:
BREAKING

President Shelly orders flags at half-staff in honor of Navajo Code Talker Corporal Tom Jones, Jr.

 

WINDOW ROCK - Another Navajo hero has passed.

Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly ordered flags on the Navajo Nation to be flown at half-staff in honor of Navajo Code Talker Cpl. Tom Jones, Jr., from sunrise on May 14 to sunset on May 17, according to a press release from his office. 

"The Navajo Nation has lost another hero and role model to our people," Shelly said. "We are saddened by the loss of Tom Jones, Jr. and the Nation sends our condolences and prayers to his family." 

Jones passed on May 12 at the San Juan Regional Medical Center in Farmington, N.M., after a battle with pneumonia and other medical conditions. He was 89 years old.

His service in the U.S. Marine Corps began on Nov. 16, 1943, and he was honorably discharged on Dec. 30, 1945. Jones was a messenger for U.S. Marine Corps 3rd Division, Unit 297 and served with the Navajo Code Talkers 767 and Navajo Code Talkers 642 Platoons at Camp Pendleton.

"Our father was a private, humble, simple, caring and giving father, grandfather, brother, friend and comrade," said daughter Carmelita Nelson. "His heart was caring, his mind was strict, his life was blessed and his soul was graceful."

Funeral services will take place on May 17 at the Diné Christian Center in Shiprock, N.M., beginning at 10 a.m.

An account with Wells Fargo Bank has been established for donations under account number 2221454164.

Jones leaves behind three children, eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.

Frying for a world record

By Cindy Yurth
Tseyi' Bureau

While some of their colleagues were at the annual powwow or leaving for home for the weekend, a crew Of Dine College students were hard at work Friday evening creating what they hope will be the world's largest frybread. The huge hunk of dough will introduce a new category to the Guinness Book if World Records. "We wanted something that would unite the community," explained student body president Robin McGee, "Somthing the whole campus could get involved in." At 6:40 pm the students had mixed 267 pounds of dough in three batches and were preparing to carry it to an outdoor fire where it will be fried in a giant pan created by welding students at Chinle High School. Although no previous record exists, the students are hoping the finished product will weigh at least 150 pounds.

For a more in-depth story, look for it in the next issue of the Navajo Times.
