Navajo Word Of The Day- Atsiits'iin

This Navajo word means "the head." Or, it can also refer to something that functions like the brain, meaning that it provides the controls to move the rest of the body.
To say "my head" the word becomes "shitsiits'iin" and "your head" is "n(i)tsiits'iin" and "his/its head" is "bitsiits'iin." You can see with these words how to use shí, ní and bí.
So if I say to the phrase, "chidí bitsiits'iin" what do you think I am talking about? That phrase is a creative use of atsiits'iin to refer to a car or truck's engine, referring to the piston heads that drive the motor.

http://navajowotd.com/post/21642910333/atsiits-iin
link_name: Atsiits'iin - Navajo Language (Diné Bizaad) - Word of the Day

NEWS

Most candidates waiting for election filing deadline

By Bill Donovan 
Special to the Times

WINDOW ROCK - The latest readout of people who have gone to the election office to pick up filing papers for the upcoming election as well as those who have paid their filing fees shows that a lot of people are taking a wait-and-see attitude. While the filing of candidates is usually slow in tribal elections, the last two weeks have seen only a handful of new candidates picking up filing papers and no new candidates for president. People have until May 28 to officially file their candidacy and pay their fees ($1,500 for tribal chairman, $500 for council and $200 for other positions), and election officials said they are expecting that most will probably do it, as happened in past elections, in the last two days before the deadline.

Please click on the link to hear how the word is pronounced.

Navajo Word Of The Day- Shik'is

Literally: my friend.
The Navajo word ak'is means friend, so shí, ní, or bí is attached to mean my, your, or his (her). This word is essentially used to describe siblings and maternal cousins, but in all of these cases it only applies to people of the same sex.

Modern usage has somewhat allowed the word to be applied to friendships between men and women. But, in the old days, you simply could not say that a woman was just your friend (if you were a man), or that a man was just your friend (if you were a woman). Especially when it was not uncommon for men to have multiple wives.

http://navajowotd.com/post/19284180762/shik-is
link_name: Shik'is - Navajo Language (Diné Bizaad) - Word of the Day

Navajo Word Of The Day- Béégashii bitsį'

English translation: beef. The word actually translates to "a cow - its meat." So this is more like two words.
Béégashii is the Navajo word for cow, or cattle. The latter part of the phrase, bitsį', uses the bi- suffix to mean "he" or "it" along with the word -tsį', which means meat (atsį').
Here's a quick info-bit: the Apache language and the Navajo language share similar words for cow — the Apache word using the "maa" sound in place of the Navajo "béé" sound.

http://navajowotd.com/post/20459336605/beegashii-bitsi
link_name: Béégashii bitsį' - Navajo Language (Diné Bizaad) - Word of the Day

Navajo Word Of The Day- 'Óbáámá

Continuing today with words adopted by the Navajo language, obáama is one of those unique words that use the letter 'm.' In most cases, you could use the word to simply imply that an act was performed completely autonomously. Furthermore, there are times when you may hear this word used excessively in order to convey immediate hardship experienced by the speaker, with the implication that such hardship is directly unwanted nor desired.

Example: Yádiláh! I had to bring the sheep in óbáámá self!

http://navajowotd.com/post/20331303928/obaama

Two more days of voting will determine if this couple will be lucky enough to win their dream wedding.

By: Shondiin Silversmith

Almost everyone has an image of what their wedding would look like when the time comes, and for couple Shannon Watson and Matt Zullo it involves not only matrimony but also the stress-free feeling that comes with not picking up the tab.

"We just want to enjoy our wedding," said Watson, 30. "Spend the day with our friends and family and celebrate. Matt and I have been dating for more than 12 years, so during that time we have had tons of people ask us, 'So, when are you two getting married?'

"The true answer to that questions is that we have not been able to afford to get married without putting a financial burden on our families or ourselves," she added. "So, when this contest came along, it seemed like the perfect chance at getting the dream wedding that we have always wanted."

Out of nearly 200 video submissions to the "Say Yes!" Wedding Sweepstakes held by Encanterra Country Club, Watson and Zullo were one of 16 couples selected as a finalists.

Voting ends on April 2. To vote, go to: http://bit.ly/mattandshannon

Warrant issued for former Hopi chairman Benjamin H. Nuvamsa 

By Krista Allen

Western Agency Bureau

     TUBA CITY − The Hopi Tribe's former chairperson is a wanted man.  

     Benjamin H. Nuvamsa, 65, from Shungopavi Village in Second Mesa, Ariz. is facing a warrant for theft, in violation of Hopi Code Section 3.8.4.B., which states that theft of property or services with a value of $2,000 or more is guilty of a serious offense.

     According to the criminal complaint provided by the Hopi Tribal Court, Nuvamsa knowingly took a Louis Tewanima sculpture from the Hopi Museum in Second Mesa. 

     The bronze sculpture is of Louis Tewanima, a Kiis'áanii two-time Olympic distance runner and silver medalist in the 10,000 meter run in 1912 at the Stockholm Games, measures about 13 inches wide and 24 inches in length.

     The complaint states that Nuvamsa had no permission from the Museum to take the bust valued at approximately $8,000.  

     Nuvamsa failed to appear in court earlier this month for arraignment. An arrest warrant has been issued against him under a $200 secured bond. 

     Benjamin Nuvamsa is the founder of the KIVA Institute and a former Agency Superintendent. The Institute's website reveals that he is a noted national expert on the Indian Self-determination Act.

HBO's Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel will air "Rez Ball," featuring Native American basketball players, at 10 p.m. tonight. 



   The top-ranked Louisville women's basketball team is being led by two Native American sisters.  Shoni, superstar senior guard, leads the team in scoring and is projected to be top WNBA draft pick next year and sister Jude, a junior, is the team's steady sixth woman. 
   According to hbo.com, the Schimmels' have come to represent the hopes and dreams of thousands of Native Americans across the country for whom basketball is much more then just a sport... it is an escape - literally and figuratively.
   Life for Native Americans living on reservations in the US remains difficult, the website states. Chronic unemployment, poverty, limited educational opportunities and high levels of drug and alcohol abuse have plagued residents for decades...and life on the Umatilla reservation in Pendleton, Oregon is no different. This is the world Shoni and Jude Schimmel grew up in... becoming familiar with the history of their people, participating in tribal customs such as the pow-wow, and learning the native and vanishing language of her Umatilla ancestors.
   For the Schimmel sisters and many other Native Americans living on the reservations, basketball is the national pastime. It is a sport that isn't expensive to play, and brings close-knit communities indoors during the cold winter months. Everyone on the reservation has a hoop. On dirt courts, with bent rusted rims, flour is used to mark sidelines.
   The segment will also feature video footage and interviews from the Arizona state tournament game, which included the Chinle Wildcats and the Alchesay Falcons in Kayenta, Ariz. in February.
   For more information, go to www.hbo.com.

Navajo Word Of The Day- Shicheii

Shicheii is my mother's father, or my grandfather (aka maternal grandfather).

In the Navajo way, shicheii is also my grandson by my daughter (a kind of nickname or recognition). In the clanship way, shicheii's first clan is my "dashicheii" clan, which often is the third to be listed after my father's clan ("báshíshchíín").

Shiprock Lady Chieftains loses to Portales for 3A championship title

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. – It took about four months, 29 victories and team from Southeastern New Mexico for the Shiprock Lady Chiefs to pick up their first and only loss of the season.
The No. 1-seeded Lady Chiefs fell to the No. 3 Portales Rams 62-59, in the 3A championship game Friday afternoon at The Pit. Shiprock wraps up their season 29-1 overall.
Missed shots and fouls got the best of the Lady Chiefs as they gave the Rams 28 points from the free-throw line and shot an average of 36-percent throughout the game.
Shiprock head coach Larenson Henderson said for the first time all season his team may have met their match.
"We missed a lot of shots and free throws kind of hurt us too, if we were playing again I think it would go the other way…they just got the big one," he said. "They (Shiprock) were determined to come back and win it all. This one is going to really hurt them."
The Lady Chiefs were led by senior Taylor Henderson who had 13 points and Tanisha Begay had 10. Portales was led by Kambrey Blakey who had 23 and Sheraya Cox who had 17.
To read the full story and other stories from the New Mexico state basketball tournament pick up a copy of the Navajo Times next week.

Navajo Word Of The Day- Shádi'ááh

This is the second of the four cardinal directions of the Navajo: South. (The first being ha'a'aah). Though the direction is South, the meaning of the word itself refers to the sun, where at its highest point it is generally in that direction - shá being the sun.

As such, the direction is traditionally significant because it symbolizes the beginning of order to freedom of thought and creativity — a kind of purpose or aim.

Undefeated Shiprock Lady Chieftains only area team left in state basketball tournament

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. – The Shiprock Lady Chieftains are not just No. 1, they are the only one.
The only area team left in the state basketball tournament that is.
The Lady Chiefs defeated No. 4 Hope Christian 63-35 in the semi-finals on Thursday to advance to the 3A title game with No. 3 Portales that is set for today at 3:30 p.m. at The Pit.
The match with Portales is a rematch of the 2002 state title game when the Lady Chiefs defeated the Rams 75-60 for the championship title. It was the last time Shiprock earned a state title in girls' basketball.
This year is also the first time in 25 years the Lady Chiefs have entered the state tournament with an undefeated record. Shiprock is now 29-0. In 1989, coached under Jerry Richardson, the Lady Chiefs entered the championship game 26-0. They then went onto win the state championship title over archrivals Kirtland Central 85-55.
Coincidently, the 1989 Shiprock Lady Chiefs will be recognized at 3 p.m. today at The Pit, before Shiprock and Portales tip off.
The last time Shiprock girls made it to the championship game was in 2011, coached by former Shiprock coach Brady Rivers, and lost to Santa Fe Indian School to finish in second place.
Those who didn't fair as well in the semi-finals yesterday were the Gallup Lady Bengals and the Laguna Acoma boys' and girls' teams.
Gallup was defeated by district 6-4A rivals and No. 1 Los Lunas 67-41. The Tigers got a jump-start on the Bengals and Gallup had trouble finding their offense. They end their season 21-9.
Laguna Acoma girls suffered a 35-26 loss to No. 1 Texico. They finished their season 24-6
The No. 1 Laguna Acoma boys' team faced an upset by No. 4 Texico, 63-59. Texico gave them their only loss of the season 29-1.
To read more from the state tournament, pick up a copy of the Navajo Times this week and next week.
For updates from the championship game follow Navajo Times sports writer Sunnie Clahchischiligi on Twitter: @clahchischiligi.

status_message:
Wingate and Tohatchi are out, but six teams make it to the quarterfinal round

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
FRUITLAND, N.M -- Six area boys' basketball teams have moved on to the quarterfinals of the New Mexico state high school basketball tournament. Some barely escaped their first-round opponents while others breezed through.
Here's a look at the teams that came up on top and will continue their season.
 
1A
The No. 11 To'hajiilee Warriors upset No. 6 Logan 60-58 on the road. To'hajiilee will now meet No. 2 Hagerman in the 2A quarterfinals at Bernalillo High School on Wednesday, March 12 at 3 p.m. If the Warriors pick up another win they could face the winner of No. 7 Springer and No. 2 Magdalena in the semifinals on March 13.
 
2A
No. 1 Laguna Acoma had little trouble getting past No. 16 Eunice in Laguna on Saturday. The Hawks defeated Eunice 84-56. They will now meet No. 9 Tularosa on Wednesday at the Santa Ana Star Center in Rio Rancho, N.M. for a 6:30 p.m. game. The winner of that game will face No. 5 Santa Fe or No. 4 Texico in the semi-final.
 
3A
No. 10 Shiprock upset No. 7 Sandia Prep 55-50 on the road. The Chiefs will now face No. 2 St. Michael's in the quarterfinals at SASC on Wednesday, March 12 for a 4:45 p.m. game. If the Chiefs pick up a win they will meet the winner of No. 3 Silver and No. 6 Lovington.
 
4A
Three local teams saw success Saturday night in Class 4A. The No. 5 Kirtland Central Broncos defeated No. 12 Artesia 80-65 at Bronco Arena in Kirtland, N.M. The Broncos will now faceoff with No. 4 Centennial at 11:30 a.m. at The University of New Mexico The Pit on March 12. If the Broncos pick up a win they will meet the winner of No. 1 Roswell and No. 8 Gallup.
No. 8 Gallup defeated No. 9 Espanola Valley 69-55 in Gallup yesterday. The Bengal will now meet No. 1 Roswell at The Pit on March 12 at 6:30 p.m. If the Bengals win they will meet the winner of Kirtland Central and Centennial.
No. 11 Grants upset No. 6 Goddard 71-68 on the road. The Pirates will meet No. 3 St. Pius X on March 12 at 8 a.m. in The Pit.
 
Eleven local boys' teams fell short and finished their seasons in the first round of the state tournament.
 
1A
No. 1 Cliff 88 defeated No. 16 Tse Yi Gai 88-36. The Dine Warriors finished their season 11-15 overall.
No. 3 Hagerman defeated No. 14 Jemez Valley 74-39. They were 17-12 overall this season.
No. 2 Magdalena defeated No. 15 Shiprock Northwest 94-39. Shiprock Northwest finished their season 12-11 overall and District 6-1A champions.
 
2A
No. 9 Tularosa defeated No. 8 Tohatchi 56-55 in Tohatchi. Tohatchi went 23-6 this season and are the District 1-2A champions. The Cougars lose eight seniors.
No. 5 Santa Fe Prep defeated No. 12 Crownpoint 65-53. The Eagles ended their season 19-11 overall.
No. 3 Clayton defeated No. 14 Dulce 83-43. Dulce ended their season 14-12 overall.
 
3A
The No. 8 Wingate Bears fell to No. 9 Portales 54-49 in Fort Wingate. The Bears are the District 1-3A regular-season champs and finished the season 16-12.
No. 13 Thoreau fell to No. 4 West Las Vegas 84-63. The Hawks ended their season 16-10.
The No. 14 Santa Fe Indian Braves loss to No. 3 Silver 77-40. They end the season 8-20 overall.
 
4A
No. 10 Farmington fell to No. 7 Albuquerque Academy 68-59. The Scorps ended their season 15-14.
No. 13 Piedra Vista fell to No. 4 Centennial 74-32. The Panthers went 14-13 this season.

status_message:
New Mexico Class 4A state girls playoff
 
Gallup advances behind McIntosh's all-around game
 
By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times
 
GALLUP – For most of the night, Ni'asia McIntosh was just being herself.
Lately, the Gallup sophomore has been putting up some gaudy numbers.
On Friday night, the Gallup team turned to her as she put forth a dominant performance in leading the No. 4 seed Bengals to a 62-45 win over Artesia in the opening round of the New Mexico Class 4A state girls basketball tournament.
McIntosh scored a game-high 27 points, to go along with 20 rebounds and six blocks.
"She had a killer game and the scary thing is she is not close to being finish developing as a player," Gallup coach Kamau Turner said of his 6-foot-2 post. "If she wants the sky is the limit for her. If she wants to work she can become a real great player."
Despite Artesia's length and size, Turner said McIntosh found other ways to score as the Bulldogs packed the paint and limited the number of touches she had inside.
"One thing I give Artesia credit is there size," Turner said. "Their game plan was to take away from us throwing the ball inside. Their size was able to do that a lot and I don't think we fed Ni'asia enough on the inside."
Instead McIntosh made her presence felt by hitting the boards on the offensive end. She scored the games' first eight points with three baskets coming on putbacks.
"I was just focused on getting position and that lead to some of my points," McIntosh said. "What I did was good but I thought we played as a team and we wanted to get this win."
McIntosh added three more putbacks in the second quarter and by the half she had put up 17 points. But the biggest difference came on the other end of the floor as Gallup took a 31-13 halftime advantage.
"I thought we played real well, especially defensively," Turner said. "We only gave up 13 points in the first half, which is real good."
In the final six minutes of the half, the Bengals held Artesia to only one field goal. Those defensive stops helped Gallup go on a scoring run as they closed out the half on a 17-3 spurt.
Fifteen of those points were made in a three-minute stretch as the Bengals scored on six consecutive positions to break open a close game.
"Early on we were settling for jump shots and they were open jump shots," Turner said. "We worked hard for those open jump shots but after two or three that don't go and then you have to get more aggressive and attack the hoop."
In the midst of that rally, Gallup also made two treys – one each by senior Rebecca Herrera and junior Tilea Reyna – and finished the game with a 3-for-16 effort.
"We haven't shot or made a lot of threes this year," Turner said. "One thing I did notice that we were passing up a lot of them through the year and if we're going to be 3-for-16 that's fine because the shots we were getting were good three-point shots. All we have to do is knock them down."
After the break, the Bengals pushed its lead to 41-13 behind a 10-0 run with McIntosh and senior forward Rachelle Blackgoat combining for eight points.
With that, the damage was already done even though Artesia managed to outscore Gallup 32 to 19 the rest of the way.
The Bulldogs put together its best quarter of the night in the fourth by scoring 21 points behind junior guard Santana Calvillo's 10 markers.
Calvillo finished the game with 11 points and shared top team scoring honors with teammate Madison Willingham.
For Gallup, McIntosh led the way but she got plenty of help. Nine players scored with Kaylee Tsiniginie, Rebecca Smith, Blackgoat and Torrez scoring six points each.
On Tuesday, Gallup is scheduled to take on No. 5 Espanola Valley at 8:15 at the Pit in Albuquerque. Espanola Valley eliminated No. 12 seed Belen, 54-42.

Navajo Word Of The Day- Dził

Meaning: mountain(s). 

Navajo land (Dinétah) is traditionally bordered by four mountains, each with their own unique names and symbolic meanings. If you remember the post for ha'a'aah, the number four is a recurring quantity in Navajo culture, and that is the case with the four sacred mountains. UPDATE: 

NM State girls' and boys' basketball first-round game times have been released
 
By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
KIRTLAND, N.M. – Seeding for the New Mexico Activities Association boys and girls state basketball tournament has been made.
The selection includes 33 area boys and girls teams. The announcement was made Sunday afternoon in a live broadcast.
Those with the higher seed will host the first-round games.
The first round girls games will be played Friday, March 7 and the boys will play Saturday, March 8. The rest of the tournament will continue on March 11-15 in and around the Albuquerque area at various locations.
The seeding, opponents and game times for local teams are as follows:
 
1A
Girls-Friday, March 7
No. 8 Jemez Valley vs. No. 9 Dora in Jemez Valley at 5 p.m.
No. 16 Tse' Yi' Gai' at No. 1 Tatum at 6 p.m.
 
Boys-Saturday March 8

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
KIRTLAND, N.M. – Seeding for the New Mexico Activities Association boys and girls state basketball tournament has been made.
The selection includes 33 area boys and girls teams. The announcement was made this afternoon in a live broadcast.
Those with the higher seed will host the first-round game. Times for each game were not made available during the announcement, but will be posted on the NMAA web site some time tomorrow.
The first round girls games will be played Friday, March 7 and the boys will play Saturday, March 8. The rest of the tournament will continue on March 11-15 in and around the Albuquerque area at various locations.

status_message:
Window Rock faces tall task against Valley Christian
 
By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times
 
PHOENIX – As a first-year coach Mac Beach knows enough about the program's history at Window Rock High School.
For more than two decades Window Rock has been a fixture at the state basketball tournament. And for the last two years the Lady Scouts have reached the semifinals of the Arizona Division III bracket.
Needless to say, reaching this year's Final Four round was a tall task considering the talent they lost from last year's squad.
"I am not surprised," Beach said of his squad reaching this stage for the second straight year. "We've had our ups and downs during the season but right now we are doing what we need to do…we are playing good defense so I think we're in good shape."
As the tournament's No. 4 seed, the Scouts will be a heavy underdog against top-seeded Valley Christian in today's semifinals, which is scheduled to take place at 6:15 p.m. at Jobing.com Arena in Glendale, Ariz.
"This is going to be a good test for us," senior guard Naomi Klah said. "Valley Christian is a good team but we're excited to play them."
Beach said they have to make smart decisions as Valley Christian enters this contest riding on a 32-game winning streak.
"They (Valley Christian) play defense very well," Beach said. "We need to limit our turnovers and look for some decent shots."
In addition, the Window Rock coach said their success will depend on how they do on the boards.
"We're going to need to rebound," he said. "We have to do a good job at boxing out."

status_message:
LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

Uncertainties still concern for people

Lorenzo Bates stated in Tuesday's Farmington Daily Times newspaper that he informed the community members in all six chapters about the mine purchase. However, as I stated in this same article, only English was spoken by Mr. Bates, so how does he know if he got his message across. He only speaks English, so he can't really explain an important issue such as "the purchase of BHP mine" to the non-English speaking community members. Most of these community members are our elders. Some elders from Tiis Tsoh Sikaad Chapter complained they did not understand a word their Council delegate talked about and they said, "We don't know what he talked about and it would have been better if he had an interpreter."

Mr. Bates did not try very hard to inform his chapters, he did not provide an interpreter, and he himself did not bother to organize any public meetings, or pass out information at the special Council sessions. Not only the six chapters he serves but what about the 110 chapters across the Navajo Nation? So he failed the people.

As for Speaker Johnny Naize, he stated in Tuesday's Farmington Daily Times, "When the council took office, they took steps to be more transparent." He also said, "The one way they are transparent is by implementing a five-day comment period, which allows the public's written comments to be passed along to delegates and ensures that the public's voices are heard by their leaders." I disagree - this five-day comment period does not work and it is made to fail.

Even Council Delegate Katherine Benally has stated to forget the five-day comments because it don't mean a thing. We have people living out in the country far from power lines, some have electricity but they do not have Internet and no computers to get their information on comment periods. We have people who can't read English and have no idea what Internet is. This western system of transparency does not work for Diné people, so I say our rights as Diné people is being violated when it comes to big corporation deals, it's all done in Window Rock behind close doors with no transparency and accountability.

As for the BHP Billiton loaning $85 million to NTEC, Mr. Pat Risner states that this money will be paid back through cash flow generated by coal sales from the mine to Four Corners Power Plant. My question is, "What if the coal sales is a failure and what if it does not generate enough money to pay back BHP Billiton? What happens then? Will Navajo Nation have to step in and help pay the loan back? All these uncertainties along with the liability waiver are still a big concern for the Diné people.

Sarah Jane White
Tiis Tsoh Sikaad, N.M.

status_message:
The Following is a post shared by Ronnie Towne, daughter of Arthur Hubbard:

Good afternoon Everyone. It is with a heavy heart I send word out that my dad is at the End of Life stage. He is currently in Scottsdale under Respite Care but he will be moving to Hospice shortly. As most of you know, he has lived a long, full life (102 yrs) and we are sad to see him leave but we know through our Christian upbringing & through the native teachings he & mom have given us that this is just part of the path we all much take.

We send out love out to all & ask that you help get the word to our friends & family that his next stage of this life will be coming soon. Take care, love those close to you, forgive those who have done wrong to you & others, & pray for healing in all this land. Many blessings to all.

Who are you pulling for?

Flu cases 'widespread' this year

   PHOENIX - After a steady increase in flu cases this year, Arizona flu activity hit widespread this week, the highest category possible, according to a news release from the Arizona Department of Health Services.
   Influenza has been reported in all 15 counties. Most of the circulating flu is the 2009 H1N1 virus. Doctor and hospital visits for flu have increased over the last few weeks around the state.
   Influenza is a serious illness with symptoms similar to the common cold. However, the flu comes on quickly and is more physically draining. For most people, the best care is to stay home, rest and drink plenty of fluids. For others, especially those with certain medical conditions, the flu can be more severe.
   "Some of the symptoms of the flu are very similar to those of a cold," said Cara Christ, chief medical officer for the Department of Health Services. "Some people treat the flu like it's a cold and continue working. The truth is influenza can be fatal. If you suddenly feel sick, tired and begin coughing and sneezing, take care of yourself. Stay home and don't spread the virus to others. If you have a hard time breathing or have chest pains, you probably need to check with your doctor or get immediate help."
   At this time of year, urgent care sites and hospitals are overcrowded with ill people so it is important to call your doctor first unless you are severely ill. The good news is if you haven't been sick yet, the flu shot can still offer you protection from flu. Simple, everyday prevention measures, like washing your hands, will help stop flu and other illnesses.
   "Obviously, the best thing you can do to protect yourself and others is to get vaccinated. With our community reaching widespread status, this means that flu is circulating and even if you get vaccinated today, it will take 2-3 weeks to build up antibodies," said Bob England, director of the Maricopa County Department of Public Health. "In the meantime, stay home when you are sick, wash your hands frequently and make sure to cough or sneeze into your sleeve. Simple, but tried and true public health practices."
   While Arizona typically sees most of its flu cases in February or March, flu is unpredictable and can peak earlier or later in the season. This year, flu reports started early and have been increasing over the past few weeks, 824 cases of the 2,424 we've had this season were reported last week. However, because many people are not tested for the flu, those figures are just a fraction of the true number of cases.
   Arizona is not alone in this uptick of influenza - 40 other states reported widespread activity last week. The official Centers for Disease Control and Prevention influenza season begins in October and carries through the following September.

KC coach's funeral set for Monday

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times 

 SHIPROCK - A public viewing for Kirtland Central coach Kevin Holman will be held Sunday, Jan. 26 at 5 p.m. at St. Mary's Catholic Church, 2100 E. 20th St. Farmington, N.M. A rosary will follow at 6 p.m. where the public will be given an opportunity to speak at Holman's wake, according to a post on Holman's Facebook page. The post was made by those involved in the funeral planning.
 The funeral has be scheduled for Monday, Jan. 27 at 3 p.m. at St. Mary's Catholic Church with a short reception will follow in the St. Mary's Catholic Church Parish Center and where visitors will have an opportunity to meet Holman's family.

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

Opposition of same-sex marriage

Hello. My name is Kenard Dillon. I am of the Bitter Water Clan, born for the Apache Standing Rocks Clan. I was born, raised and educated on the Navajo Nation in Tuba City. I am 18 years old and currently in my first year of study at Harvard University, where I hope to concentrate in history or government.

Recently, I stumbled upon an article in The Albuquerque Journal, which highlighted the plethora of delegates to the Navajo Nation Council, including Speaker Johnny Naize, that oppose same-sex marriage under Navajo jurisdiction, in lieu of its recent legalization in New Mexico, on whose land the reservation stretches into.

Given the jurisdictional nightmare, I know that such unions are currently prohibited under a 2005 law, passed following an override of Joe Shirley's veto, and that for the most part it is a nonissue amongst tribal members. Although marriage equality itself is a complicated issue in the queer community and is not a priority for me personally, Speaker Naize's comments remain unacceptable. They are not only unsettling to me as a queer individual, but also completely unfounded to me as a Navajo.

Naize backed up his views with claims that such beliefs have always been part of Navajo culture and can be found woven into our traditional stories and religious dogma.

"The tradition with that says that the marriage has to be between a man and woman. That's how we respect our tradition," he said. He is wrong to declare such prohibition is respectful of our traditionsÑit is the opposite.

Under my own lens of understanding cultural tradition, atypical gender and sexual relations were never an issue for the Navajo, and his comments seemed flawed at best.

Our traditions as Diné people should be the parts of our culture that fill us with pride, not tools of prejudice used to discriminate against our own, which undoubtedly distorts and damages them.

Naize has his right to speak out on marriage equality, as a private citizen, but none whatsoever as a leader to hide behind tradition in attempt to justify legal discrimination on our reservation. It begs to question why someone with such ignorant views can be elected to tribal office.

Furthermore, if the Constitution and legal system of the United States guarantee "equal justice under law," and our own cultural traditions promote equality for all beings, why then do current tribal laws reflect the opposite? Why do they betray our own cultural values?

For our pre-contact ancestors, who operated under a communal, socialist, libertarian and egalitarian system, this must seem abhorrent.

The views that the speaker and many contemporary Navajos hold are the byproduct of our "civilization," "Americanization," and "Christianization" by the United States government, which did nothing more than nearly annihilate us and our way of life, leading us into the present system of socioeconomic subjugation. What his comments and their context do, however, is shed light on more pervasive and hidden facets of the problems that remain inherent and entrenched in contemporary Navajo society -- inviting a much-needed discussion and reparation.

We can do so much better than this. I and other queer/LGBT Navajos deserve so much more than this vitriol coming from our leaders. Having grown up gay on the Navajo Nation, free of any pressure or harassment to conform to gender and sexual binaries, I am proud of my Navajo identity and the rich tradition that entails, but not the current complacency of my fellow Diné with regard to social issues.

Kenard Dillon 
Cambridge, Mass. 
(Hometown: Tuba City, Ariz.)

status_message:
Navajo Transit buses grounded

By Shondiin Silversmith
Navajo Times 

   WINDOW ROCK — The Navajo Nation Transit System grounded six buses this past Friday due to contaminated fuel, but Department Manager Lee Bigwater said they should have all routes back in operation by Tuesday evening.
   "We've been working on it all day. We got most of the vehicles back up. Fuel's been drained out and new fuel's been put back in," Bigwater said, adding that they don't know how the contamination happened but it involved someone pumping gasoline into the diesel-fueled buses.
   "When (regular) gasoline goes into a diesel engine you know there is going to be a problem, especially in the fuel injectors. It might have burned them out," Bigwater explained. Once the department discovered the problem, he said, they drained the buses of the contaminated fuel and refueled with clean fuel. 
   "Hopefully there are no major problems as we take off this evening along the routes," Bigwater added. They have also had the engines running just to make sure nothing is wrong.
   "We should have all our routes back in operation by this evening," Bigwater said. Those routes include Route 4 — Crownpoint to Ft. Defiance; Route 7 — Newcomb to Ft. Defiance and Newcomb to Farmington to Shiprock; Route 9 — Dilkon to Ft. Defiance and Route 15 — Sanders to Window Rock to Gallup.
   "We don't know what kind of damage has already been done to our fuel system in our buses," Bigwater said, adding that they're hoping nothing major has impacted their vehicles.
   Bigwater said the routes that were grounded are some of their popular routes because they cater to employees of the Navajo Nation. Concerned bus riders have been calling the office all day wondering about their rides. 
   "The buses average about 40 seats. So that's a lot of people," Bigwater added.
   For more information: 928-729-4006 or go to their website, www.navajotransit.com.

status_message:
Scouts to play inside the Thunderdome one last time

By Quentin Jodie
Navajo Times
 

            WINDOW ROCK – After overcoming a number of hurdles, the Window Rock Scouts will be jumping ship when the Bee Ho'ldzil Fighting Scouts Center opens its door next Saturday.

            The $40 million dollar project took over 10 years to complete but the new 6,500-seat arena will replace the aging Veteran's Memorial Field House that was built in the 1950s.

            The new event center will contain six basketball goals, a state-of-the-art climate control system, a sports training center, a press box, and a wrestling room to house three large mats. More importantly, it will have four times the seating capacity as the old field house.

            But before the Scouts move into their new facility, they will play one more game tonight against the Tuba City Warriors in their legendary arena. And for good measure, this historic structure has hosted a number of classical games. 

	So as the Scouts enter a new era, what do you remember most about their old stomping grounds?

status_message:
Wingate Holiday Classic

Thoreau, Wingate boys advance to championship game with big wins


By Quentin Jodie

Navajo Times

 

            FORT WINGATE, N.M. – After dramatic victories on Thursday, the Thoreau Hawks and the Wingate Bears turned up the defense at the right time as both squads advanced to the championship game of the Wingate Holiday Classic on Friday night.

            First it was Thoreau who tore apart Miyamura with its full-court press as they opened up an early 20-8 lead en route to an 81-67 win.

            Then, the Bears capped the night with a 72-40 victory over Hotsprings after leading the contest by only four points after one quarter of play.

            "I am so happy with our team tonight," Wingate coach Al Martinez said. "You always wish that these game are always going to go in your favor (every night) but they usually don't."

            Martinez is expecting a tougher matchup with Thoreau in tonight's championship game since the Hawks have multiple weapons, which includes senior guard Shanton Yazzie and junior Alfred Smith III. Tipoff is scheduled for 6:00 p.m.
            "We know Shanton real well and he spearheads that team real well," Martinez said. "They have a lot of other parts as well. Alfred Smith does a real good job for them as well. They like to spread you out, ball handle and shoot that three.

            "We have to counteract that with our inside game," he added. "We got a couple of 6-3 guys and hopefully we can take advantage of that."

            Thoreau coach Earvin Bennett said playing Wingate for the championship game is what they were hoping for.

            "It'll be a great deal to come out with a W (on) Saturday night," Bennett said. "We know Wingate very well and we know what they like to run so it should be a fun game."

            Before that game, the Hot Springs Tigers and the Miyamura Patriots will battle for the third place trophy at 4:30 p.m.
            In the consolation bracket, the Tohatchi Cougars will take on Zuni at 1:00 in the seventh place game while Crownpoint and Rehoboth will play for the consolation championship at 3:00.

            In their game with Miyamura, the Hawks quickly jumped on them with a barrage of treys – all coming from Smith.

            Smith, who led all scorers with 32 points, credited Yazzie for allowing him to hit those open shots.

            "When he started to penetrate inside, it left me open on the outside," Smith said of Yazzie. "I just tried my best to make them."

            The junior sharpshooter made six consecutive treys, which all came in the first half as he finished 20 points at the break. To add some perspective, he almost matched Miyamura's total as the Hawks led the Patriots 45-25 heading into the locker room.

            "We made most of our shots and we controlled the ball a little bit better tonight," Smith said, while recalling their recent loss against Miyamura. "We played better defense and we got some points off our press."

            For much of the second half, the Hawks managed to keep margin around 20 points before Miyamura narrowed the gap down to 76-60 on a three-pointer by Josiah Reimonenq with 3:40 left to play.

            "They (Miyamura) started to comeback on us," Bennett said. "And you know coach (Matt) Vail did a good job tonight; he was missing two of his key players."

            The Patriots had two players in double figures with senior post Anthony Lee leading the way with 21 points. Chandler Charles helped out with 10 while Jeremy Bill and Vince Begay added nine points apiece.

            For Thoreau, Yazzie finished with 17 points while Nathan Francisco chipped in 12.

            In Friday's finale, the Hot Springs Tigers played on even terms with Wingate until the Bears dictated the game with their defense in the last eight minutes of the first half.

            Wingate held the Tigers to only seven free throws in the second quarter while they lit the scoreboard with 20 points with seven different players scoring.

            With that the Bears extended a four-point lead into a 36-19 cushion at the break.

            "I think it was mainly because of our defense," Wingate senior forward Kaycee Begay said of the turnaround.

            In the first quarter, Begay said they were sloppy on defense, which allowed Hot Springs to stay in the game.

            "Every time they came down the court they would score on us," he said. "We were not as active so I told the guys we had to play defense."

            That pep talk seemed to work as the Bears held Hot Springs without a field goal for almost 14 minutes. After hitting an inside bucket with two minutes left in the first quarter, the Tigers didn't nailed their next one until Ryan Johnson got an open look inside with 4:24 to go in the third.

            By that time the Bears lead 46-23, which allowed Martinez to rotate players in and out. For the game, Wingate managed to get all of its players to score with Begay leading the way with 12 points.

            Junior Kennel Jones helped out with 10 points while Geoff Deswood and Benson Perry helped out with seven apiece.

            "It's nice to have these types of games," Martinez said. "Hot Springs come down here for a reason and that's to get better … Tonight it was a learning experience for them and you know they play good football down in the south and a lot of times it's a different story for basketball."

status_message:
New Mexico legalizes gay marriage, ban still in effect on the Navajo Nation 
 
By Shondiin Silversmith
Navajo Times
 
WINDOW ROCK — As of today, it is legal for same-sex couples to get married in the state of New Mexico, but it's ruling still does not affect the Navajo Nation.
The New Mexico Supreme Court legalized same-sex marriage Dec. 19 by declaring that it is unconstitutional to deny a marriage license to gay and lesbian couples. New Mexico joins 16 states and the District of Columbia in allowing the union of same-sex couples.
The ruling states, "Prohibiting same-gender marriages is not substantially related to the governmental interests advanced by the parties opposing same-gender marriage or to the purposes we have identified. Therefore, barring individuals from marrying and depriving them of the rights, protections, and responsibilities of civil marriage solely because of their sexual orientation violates the Equal Protection Clause under Article II, Section 18 of the New Mexico Constitution."
Amber Royster, executive director of Equality New Mexico said that the recent ruling might not be the silver bullet needed for everyone to have equal rights across the U.S., "but it does put us at the table in an entirely different way."
Equality New Mexico is a statewide Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender civil rights, advocacy and education organization.
"This is incredible for thousands of New Mexico families in the state, especially the more than 1,700 people who got married this year," Royster said, adding that the court's ruling "made it crystal clear that our founding constitution grants that basic freedom to everyone."
Well, except on the Navajo Nation, where the Diné Marriage Act, a tribal act signed into law on April 2005 bans same sex marriages. According to provisions in the Act, "marriage between persons of the same sex is void and prohibited."
Being that the Navajo Nation is a sovereign nation, the New Mexico Supreme Court's ruling has no effect on Navajo lands in the state of New Mexico.
But, that didn't stop New Mexican born Navajo Renaldo Chapman from celebrating today's passing with pride. Chapman has been married to his partner Demetrius Chapman for the past 5 years, and will celebrate six years on Dec. 21.
In fact, his first reaction when the news broke of the high court's ruling was taken to Facebook when he posted, "OH HAPPY DAY!"
"I feel like I have dignity, my dignity has been restored because not only was my right's being suppressed by the state but also the Navajo Nation, which is still in effect, but the United States," Chapman said during a phone interview with the Times.
"New Mexico has affirmed human dignity, and all families of New Mexico are now protected by the fundamental right to marry," Chapman added.
Chapman, who now lives in Albuquerque with his family, said he is happy that "the place I call home is where I can be protected and not fear for the safety of my family."
"I would like to see this progression at some point reach the Navajo Nation government," Chapman added.
There is currently an effort in place in hopes of getting the Diné Marriage Act of 2005 changed on the Navajo Nation, and the person headlining that effort is Alray Nelson, founder of the Coalition for Navajo Equality.
"This ruling in favor of the freedom to marry in New Mexico is a clear message to our Navajo leaders that the Diné Marriage Act is wrong and a law of discrimination," Nelson said.
Nelson added that "we can do better and the Navajo Nation will be on the right side of history when we repeal this discriminatory law. Love wins and we saw that today with this ruling for love, family, and equality in New Mexico."
"There is an active effort in place, and given that such a significant portion of the Navajo Nation lands is in New Mexico, hopefully it will give that momentum to move forward," Royster said on how this ruling benefits the Navajo Nation, adding that Equality New Mexico supports the coalitions efforts.

status_message:
Explosion at Page High School 

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau



     PAGE, Ariz. − An explosion in the janitor's room at Page High School on Tuesday morning set fire to a portion of the main building, causing all four schools within the Page Unified School District as well as Tse'Yaato' High to close for the day.
     The explosion occurred around 4 a.m. and blew out the back doors, according the security tapes that the staff reviewed. 
     The Page Fire Department, however, has not determined the cause of the fire. 
     "It exploded (the doors) open into the parking lot," said Page Unified School District Superintendent Jim Walker who received an emergency call at 4:30 a.m. "Fortunately, our sprinkler system worked well and seemed to control the flames." 
     Walker says the entire main building was filled with thick smoke. 
     "We're really not sure how long we're going to be out of that building," said Walker. 
     Due to a mixture of particles and chemicals that might have been produced by incomplete burning of carbon-containing materials, Walker says he's not sure how long the main building (that contains administration and counseling offices, more than 20 classrooms, and student lockers) will be closed down, which prevents students and teaching staff from their lockers and classrooms. 
     "We're making plans to relocated all those," said Walker. "Just in case it ends up being a long-term issue." 
     PUSD canceled all schools today and tomorrow for all students and faculty. Maintenance and custodial, though, will need to report for duty. 
     Page High School has a 75 percent American Indian population from neighboring communities including Bitter Springs, Bodaway-Gap, Cedar Ridge, LeChee, Kaibeto, Navajo Mountain, Shonto, Tonalea-Red Lake, and Ts'ah Bii Kin.

     All schools will resume on Thursday.

status_message:
Officials celebrate one year of successful Navajo Beef Program

            FLAGSTAFF – The Navajo Nation Gaming Enterprise (NNGE) in conjunction with Labatt Food Service and Navajo Nation leadership are celebrating the successful first year of the Navajo Beef Program.

            The program features local Navajo ranchers raising high quality beef, Labatt Food Service distributing it and NNGE purchasing it to serve in its resort, casinos and restaurants. Since its launch last November, the program has generated half a million dollars for Navajo ranchers and their communities.

            "We are proud to be such an important part of the Navajo Beef Program's success, which is just one component of NNGE's larger commitment to buy Navajo," stated Derrick Watchman, CEO of NNGE. "The Navajo Beef Program allows our properties to better showcase Navajo, provide world-class cuisine and generate revenue and jobs for the Navajo people."

            To date, the Navajo Beef Program – through Navajo ranchers – has produced 545 head of cattle and generated more than $500,000 of revenue back into the local Navajo community.

            "It has been a privilege to ensure the hard-working local ranchers receive the fair payment they deserve for this high quality beef," said Al Silva, chief operating officer of Labatt Food Service. "We know the success of this program allows the ranchers to improve their lives and increase the quality of life in their communities."

            Through the Navajo Beef Program ranchers – at Padres Mesa Ranch in Chambers Ariz., 14R in the New Lands area and Turquoise Grazers in Window Rock, Ariz. – uphold traditional practices to produce premium, quality beef that is always tender and full of flavor. Navajo Certified Beef is Choice grade or better and aged 21 days.

            Labatt Food Service, the tenth largest food distributor in the country, ensures the quality of the beef, that local Navajo ranchers receive fair payment and that the entire animal is used. The initial success of the program is motivating Labatt to expand the program for 2014.

status_message:
Western Agency Hit By Late November Winter Storm 

By Krista Allen 
Western Agency Bureau

   WESTERN NAVAJO AGENCY ‑ As the cold air remains, snow, ice, and drenching rains ‑ blamed for a number of slide-offs and fender benders ‑ have caused havoc within the western region of the Navajo Nation. 

     A strong winter storm system swept across Northern Arizona over the weekend, leaving a soggy mess.     

     Snow accumulations varied from three inches around LeChee to nearly 10 inches around Coppermine and Navajo Mountain, Utah, according to chapter officials on Sunday.  

    "The wind's been blowing day and night," said Naatsis'áán Chapter Vice President Jaime Holgate, who's been plowing snow all day. "Most (areas) have snowdrifts, anywhere from three to six feet deep." 

     "We've got (many) vehicles, mostly cars, that are stranded on the road," added Holgate.  

     In Ts'ah Bii Kin, just southeast of Navajo Mountain, where the elevation is more or less than 6,732 feet, the snow saturated the ground.

      "Wet and white," said Ts'ah Bii Kin Chapter Vice President Geraldine Chee as she described the snow in her community. "So it's kind of muddy.    San Juan Southern Paiute President May Preston says her people in Paiute Mountain (Naatsis'áán to the Diné) have been snowed in for at least three days.

     "The roads are treacherous," said Preston, who also reported rain in the Paiute territory near Tuba City. 

     The storm, however, only brought rain to several communities including Kayenta, Tonalea-Red Lake, and Tónaneesdizí. 

     "Roads are very muddy," said Tonalea-Red Lake Chapter President Darryl Jim. 

     It will be mostly sunny on Monday, according to the National Weather Service.  

     The Tuba City and Kayenta police districts both reported that U.S. highways 89 and 160 as well as State Route 98 are now passible.

An icy Interstate 40 had traffic backed up for miles Saturday night in Gallup, N.M. Law enforcement responded to a barrage of accidents, vehicle slide offs and jack-knifed semi-trucks all evening. Law enforcement eventually closed part of the Interstate and had the road department de-ice both the eastbound and westbound lanes. The roads have been re-opened but traffic continues to travel at a very slow pace. 

A winter storm warning remains in effect for parts of the Navajo Nation until early Monday morning.

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times

RIO RANCHO, N.M. -- Out of the 11 New Mexico area volleyball teams that qualified for the state tournament only two remain.

The No. 1 ranked 4A Piedra Lady Panthers will play the No. 4 ranked Centennial here at the Santa Ana Star Center in Rio Rancho, N.M. shortly. 
Piedra Vista defeated No. 5 Espanola Valley this morning in the semi-finals. 
In the small schools competition, the No. 11 seed Ramah Lady Mustangs upset district rivals No. 10 seed Navajo Prep 3-0 in the quarterfinals. Ramah will meet No. 2 seed Bosque in the semi-finals beginning this evening at 6:30 at the Santa Ana Star Center.

Ramah was given a bye in the first round and met Navajo Prep in the quarterfinals, the two teams met three other times in the season and were 2-2 against each other after the quarterfinals.

The area teams defeated in the first round were: Tse Yi Gai, Newcomb, Cuba, Laguna Acoma, Wingate, Shiprock, Farmington and Aztec. Navajo Prep fell to Ramah in the quarterfinals. 

For live updates from the state volleyball tournament follow Times sports writer Sunnie Clahchischiligi on Twitter: @clahchischiligi.

11th annual Page-Lake Powell Balloon Regatta off to successful start  

By Krista Allen 
Western Agency Bureau

PAGE, Ariz ‑ Nearly 60 colorful, hot-air balloons in all shapes and sizes took to the sky for the annual Page-Lake Powell Balloon Regatta.
     Pilots from the region flocked to the regatta fields for the four-day balloon rally that kicked off with a mass ascension, in which all the brightly colored balloons lifted off in waves. 
     The 11th annual Page-Lake Powell Balloon Regatta will continue with a street fair and a night glow Saturday evening on South Lake Powell Boulevard where more than 20 balloons will light up the street.

For more pictures and a story about the Page-Lake Powell Balloon Regatta, pick up a copy of the next edition of the Navajo Times.

The Boston Red Sox are the 2013 World Series Champions 

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi
Navajo Times
 
Jacoby Ellsbury is a World Series champion again.

For the second time in his professional baseball career the 30-year-old Navajo outfielder is part of another Boston Red Sox World Series championship team.
Ellsbury and the Red Sox won the title tonight when they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals 6-1 at Fenway Park.
It is the first time since 1918 that the Red Sox have won a World Series title at Fenway.
The Red Sox finished the series 4-2.
Ellsbury lead the Boston off with a single to right at the bottom of the third. A double by Shane Victorino brought Ellsbury, David Ortiz and Jonny Gomes in for three runs to lead 3-0.
Ellsbury had another base hit to right at the bottom of the fourth and ran as far as second base. A single by Mike Napoli brought Ellsbury in for his second run of the game.
The soon-to-be free agent lit the stage at the bottom of the fifth when he tried to steal second. Ellsbury escaped a tag out four Cardinals players and got back to first base.
Ellsbury finished the game with five at-bats, three hits and a batting average of .296.
He was a part of the Red Sox 2007 World Series team.

Ellsbury, Redsox one win away from World Series title
 
By Sunnie Clahchischiligi 
Navajo Times 

Navajo center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury contributed to the Boston Red Sox 3-1 win in Game 5 of the World Series over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight at Busch Stadium. Boston leads the series 3-2.
With two outs, and Red Sox Stephen Ross at third and David Ross at second in the seventh, Ellsbury hit an RBI single to center to bring Ross in for the run.
The play put the Red Sox up 3-1. It was the last run of the game as Boston held the Cardinals for the win.
Ellsbury led off for the Red Sox and entered the game 3 for 16. He is now 4 for 20 in the series with a batting average of .200.
The World Series returns to Fenway Park on Wednesday, Oct. 30 beginning at 6:07 p.m. MST.  The game will be televised on FOX.
For continuous updates of Ellsbury and the Red Sox throughout the World Series follow Navajo Times sports writer Sunnie Clahchischiligi on Twitter: @clahchischiligi.

SPORTS WRAP-UP

St. Louis ties the series, 1-1

By Sunnie Clahchischiligi 
Navajo Times Sports Writer

The St. Louis Cardinals tied the World Series up 1-1 with the Boston Red Sox as they took Game Two of the World series, defeating Boston 4-2 tonight at Fenway Park.

Red Sox's Jacoby Ellsbury once again contributed to the game. The centerfielder had a single in the third but was left on base without getting a chance to try score.

Ellsbury had 1 hit with 4 at-bat appearances. His batting average was .143 with a .250 OBP.

He struggled on defense in the 4th when he struggled with an off-the-wall catch with Cardinals' Matt Holliday hit a lead-off triple.

Ellsbury went on to make three big catches on defense and closed with a lead-off single to 2nd at the bottom of the 8th. 

the Red Sox travel to Cardinals country for Game Three on Saturday, Oct. 26. The first pitch will be at 6:07 p.m. MST. FOX will televise the game.

status_message:
FYI - Navajo Nation Council Fall session starts off today in Tségháhoodzání. Tune in  online by going to www.ustream.tv/channel/navajo-nation-council.

Proposed agenda:
1. Calling the Fall Session to Order; the Roll Call; the Invocation, the Announcements.
2. Recognizing Guests and Visiting Officials to the Navajo Nation.
3. Review and Adopt the Agenda for the Fall Session of the Navajo Nation Council.
4. Receive the State of the Nation Address from the President of the Navajo Nation.
5. Receive Report from the Speaker of the Navajo Nation Council.
6. ORAL REPORT(S):
a. Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA)  b. Indian Health Service (IHS)   c. Financial Report by the Navajo Nation Controller   d. Report from the Navajo Nation Attorney General   e. Report from the Chief Justice of the Navajo Nation   f. Report from Felecia Rotellini for Arizona Attorney General
7. WRITTEN REPORT(S):
a. Standing Committees  b. Boards and Commissions   c. Bureau of Indian Affairs Regional Director   d. Indian Health Service Area Director

Cameron Community Celebration

By Krista Allen
Western Agency Bureau


      CAMERON, Ariz. ‑ Residents marked the 5th annual Cameron Community Celebration on Oct. 18. 

      Every year, just a day before the annual Tó Naneesdizí Diné Fair, Cameron community members gather to simply have fun. 

     Cameron Chapter president Milton Tso says it's an alternative to the fair, reasonably for those that cannot make it to the fair.

A New Miss Northern Navajo is Crowned

Megan Badonie from Shiprock, N.M., was crowned the new Miss Northern Navajo Friday evening at the Phil Thomas Performing Arts Center in Shiprock, N.M. Badonie is a 2012 graduate from Kirtland Central High School. Seven young women, including Badonie, vied for the crown. She'll be introduced Saturday morning during the 102nd annual Northern Navajo Nation parade. Stay tuned for a more in-depth story and photos of the newly crowned queen in the next Navajo Times issue.

Bomb scare

By Antonio Ramirez

 
WINDOW ROCK - This morning a suspicious package was found outside of the prosecutor's office around 8:00 a.m. Wednesday, and another package was reported outside of Navajo Arts and Crafts around 12:20 p.m.
Both scenes have since been cleared and no bombs have been found.

The package outside the prosecutor's office was determined to be a hoax package around noon. It was describes as computer hardware duck taped together.

The package outside Navajo Arts and Crafts brought police officers to the area. However, since then officers have left.

About 270-300 people have been evacuated from the area surrounding the prosecutor's office. Including employees with the Department of Public Safety, Criminal Investigations Unit, Navajo Nation Window Rock Police, Window Rock District Court, Dispatch, and inmates at the jail.

Bomb squads from Arizona Department of Public Safety in Phoenix and New Mexico State Police were immediately contacted after the initial package was found. Flagstaff FBI agents are on the crime scene as well.

As a precautionary measure, traffic had previously been diverted off Window Rock Boulevard and through the NHA housing complexes. Outside the prosecutor's office there is a 1000-foot safety zone established by the officers.

The Navajo Times will provide more up-to-date information as soon as possible

FYI -

   Life is getting back to normal in Crownpoint, N.M. where residents have been worried for the past five days about the possibility that the Crownpoint Dam may break or overflow.
   The Navajo emergency management officials said Monday they were comfortable with the situation in Crownpoint, indicating that the worst may be over as officials for Navajo Technical University spent Sunday and Monday cleaning after portions of the campus were flooded on Friday and Saturday.
   Navajo officials were still getting reports from various chapters throughout the reservation about the damage that was done last week by flooding and they are now in the process of trying to determine the cost of the flooding to the tribe and to the chapters.
   While some secondary roads remain difficult to travel on because of mud, no roads were reported to be closed to traffic.

Ya'at'eeh abiní shik'éí, shidine'é. It's a great morning here in Dinétah. Already mid-way through September... can you believe it?

Blessings to all for a terrific Tuesday! Share a smile : ) u just might get one back.

FYI - Local News for 09/16/13

BUSING COMPROMISE BETWEEN CCSD & GMCS

 A verbal compromise between Central Consolidated School District and Gallup McKinley County Schools was reached on Friday that could stop the bus pickup of students in Naschitti, N.M. attending GMCS public schools in Tohatchi, beginning Tuesday.
     The verbal agreement also could mean that GMCS continues the bus service of the already 45 or so students enrolled in the Tohatchi schools from Naschitti but with feeder route money, money that would paid to the parents to transport their kids to the county line.
     The agreement calls for these students to catch the bus at the San Juan-McKinley county line, which they had been doing during the first two weeks of school, before GMCS Superintendent Frank Chiapetti decided to bus students from Naschitti instead of them walking five miles to the bus stop for their safety.
The meeting also included the involvement and facilitation by Council delegate Jonathan Hale, Rep. Sandra Jeff, Rep. Sharon Clahchischiligi, Department of Dine Education Superintendent for Schools Andrew Tah, and Ferlin Clark, who was there on behalf of the New Mexico State Education Department and the State Indian Affairs Department.
     At the meeting on Friday, Chiapetti said if the Fort Defiance Agency Council approved a resolution recommending NMPED to resolve the bus boundary issue between both school districts, he would proceed and request the NMPED to interfere through the legal process.
GMCS has already gone through the state-tribal consultation process with the passage of resolutions from Naschitti Chapter, District 14 Council and the school board of DODE. Chiapetti added.
     Meanwhile over the weekend, the Fort Defiance Agency Council passed the resolution. The resolution also has supporting resolutions from Naschitti
Today at 6 p.m. the school board of GMCS is scheduled to meet and discuss the bus boundary issue and the verbal compromise that was reach on Friday between Chiapetti and Levinski.
     On Tuesday, the CCSD school board is also slated to meet and discuss the bus boundary issue and verbal agreement in Naschitti

61st Miss Navajo Nation is from Hunters Point, Ariz.

 

WINDOW ROCK – Hunters Point, Ariz., native Natasha Hardy was announced as winner of the 2013-2014 Miss Navajo Nation pageant.

Hardy, 24, won the crown Saturday evening in front of a large audience at the coronation ceremony, held in a tent behind the Navajo Arts and Crafts Enterprise, pageant sponsor.

"Oh, my gosh," exclaimed Hardy, as tears were streaming down her checks in her 10-minute acceptance speech. "This is something else."

 Hardy is the daughter of Katherine and Gerald Nez of Hunters Point, Ariz.

She is Kinyaa'aanii (Towering House Clan), born for Pima-Tachii'nii (Red Running into Water Clan). Her maternal grandfather is Hashk'aa Hadzoho (Yucca Fruit Clan), and her paternal grandfather is Naakai (Mexican Clan).

She is the eldest of four sisters, who include Ernestine Hardy, Sheridan Nez and Latisha Nez.

As Miss Navajo Nation, Hardy plans to revitalize the Navajo language and culture among all facets of Navajo society, particularly the youth, the future of the Navajo Nation.

"Please talk to your kids in Navajo," she said to the hundreds of pageant-goers in attendance.

In a close contest of eight contestants, Hardy beat out first runner-up Versheena Dempsey, of Lukachukai, Ariz., and second runner-up Lailauni Moore, of Wheatfields, Ariz.

The Miss Congeniality award went to Moore and the Best Essay award went to Brittany Hunt, of Shonto, Ariz.

Dempsey won the Best Butcher award, while Cherish Tso of Chinle won the Miss Photogenic award.

Hunt, Tso, Joni Pino, of Twin Lakes, N.M., Darian Isaac of Hard Rock, Ariz., and Wallita Begay, of Oljato, Utah, received honorable mention.
Hardy is the 61st Miss Navajo ever to win the coveted title, 61 years after the first Miss Navajo, Dr. Beulah Melvin Allen, won it in 1952.

For a more in-depth story, please buy a copy of the Sept. 12 edition of the Navajo Times.

FYI...
Navajo Code Talkers Day will be celebrated Aug. 14 at the Veterans' Memorial Park in Window Rock.
	Members of the Young Marine of the Marine Corps League will set up flags for the Parade of Colors, which will start at 9 a.m. at the Navajo Nation Museum.
	For the parade, families and friends are invited to create a float in honor of their Navajo Code Talker. Young Marines will march alongside each float.
	The parade will end at the Veterans' Memorial Park, where invocation and posting the colors will be at 10 a.m.
	The event will continue with presentations and speeches from code talker historian Zonnie Gorman, Navajo Nation President Ben Shelly, New Mexico Cabinet Secretary Timothy Hale, Navajo Nation Council Speaker Johnny Naize, Council Delegate Jonathan Nez, and Code Talkers Peter McDonald Sr. and Bill Toledo.
	Lunch will be at noon along with entertainment from Lil Miss Navajo Central Rachelle James and Sister Nations Honor Guard.
	Throughout the day the Young Marines will monitor the park, take care of the code talkers then help clean up after the event is over.
	President Ronald Reagan proclaimed the first National Navajo Code Talkers Day on Aug. 14, 1982.

Monsoon rains close U.S. Highway 491, expected to open by Monday

By Alastair Lee Bitsoi
Navajo Times

                NASCHITTI, N.M. – Torrential monsoon rains have "completely closed" a portion of U.S. Highway 491, after runoff from the Chuska Mountains undermined a culvert with the force of the water ultimately creating a 10-feet-by-6-feet crevice across the roadway.

New Mexico Department of Transportation Officials, Navajo Nation Police and Newcomb Fire Department District 13 have been on scene, diverting traffic to alternative routes, including through U.S. Highway 371. U.S Highway 371 runs parallel to U.S. Highway 491 about 50 miles east of the closed highway between Bloomfield and Crownpoint, N.M.

                Locals call the site of the damaged road Stinky Water Wash, which is near Miles Post 44. Commuters driving through the corridor will be told to turn around to take the alternative route via U.S. 371. The road is closed off to northbound motorists in Naschitti, near the intersection of the Naschitti Cattle Auction and second turnoff to the community, and for southbound motorists, the road is closed by Mile Post 45, just south of Sheep Springs, N.M.

                Area folks told the Navajo Times that Friday evening when the storm struck there was heavy rain for about two hours with thunder and lightning. One local described the monsoon shower as "pouring rain" and "a few minutes later you could hear the frogs croaking."

                According to Delane Baros, management analyst for NMDOT District 6, state road department officials are working on creating a detour near the area of the collapsed road. She said that materials are currently being shipped to the area of the road disaster.

                "It's amazing what water can do," she said, adding that the culvert under the roadway had collapsed because of the force of the gushing water lifted up the culvert and caused the road to fail.

                Baros cautioned motorists not to cross flash flooded areas on any part of any highway, adding that it's about their safety.

                "Use caution and don't try to cross running water," she said. "We don't know what's underneath and we just want to be safe."

                One family of four, from Idaho, didn't use that caution, as evidenced by their damaged car. The family was transported to Northern Navajo Medical Center in Shiprock, according to Newcomb Fire Department Chief Michael Joe, after attempting to cross the damaged roadway Friday evening.

                In an interview with the Navajo Times, before a Shiprock District Police Officer asked the Navajo Times to step-away from what he dubbed a "criminal scene," Joe said the family crossed the highway at a high rate of speed and obviously didn't know the damaged road had a 10-feet-by-6-feet ditch under the running water.

                Joe said the runoff caused the Idaho family's car to hydroplane away from the gushing water into the shoulder of the highway. Luckily, he said, the family didn't sustain any major injuries, but were taken by ambulance to Northern Navajo Medical Center.    

"Got to fix the whole thing before anyone can cross it," Joe said about the collapsed road.

                Asked when the road could become passable, Baros anticipates the road to be open by Sunday afternoon, and, if not, by Monday morning.

                "When Monday comes around, they'll send out engineers to look at the structure," Baros said.

Baros explained that the site of the collapsed road was scheduled for repair incidentally on Monday, as part of U.S Highway 491's expansion into a four-lane highway.  Construction efforts are currently being concentrated on in this area of the road, from Sheep Springs to Naschitti, N.M.

Meanwhile, as the damaged road is detouring people through Crownpoint, locals have used backcountry roads to pass through the area.

And for those participating in the 34th Annual Narbona Pass Classic, which is scheduled for Sunday, organizer Chester Carl is recommending motorists to go through Window Rock and Fort Defiance on Indian Route 12/N.M. Highway 134 to get to Narbona Pass.

"Be safe and don't cross running water," Baros said. "We hope to have it open tomorrow or Monday."

status_message: ATTENTION Facebook Friends: A section of highway around mile marker 44 on highway 491 just north of Naschitti has collapsed caused by yesterday's rainstorm. Navajo Nation police have set up roadblocks and are restricting traffic from driving through and are having them seek alternate routes to get to their destinations. It is not known how long it will take to repair the road. Pass on the word. Thank you and be safe out there.

Navajo Nation's Monument Valley Park.  One of the most majestic - and most photographed - points on earth.

Sandstone masterpieces tower at heights of 400 to 1,000 feet. The landscape overwhelms, not just by its beauty but also by its size.  The fragile pinnacles of rock are surrounded by miles of mesas and buttes, shrubs, trees and windblown sand, all comprising the magnificent colors of the valley.

The Treaty of 1868 was signed on June 1, 1868 and ratified on July 25, 1868 by the U.S. Senate. The signing of the Treaty of 1868 allowed the Diné people to return from Bosque Redondo ending a dark and turbulent period in Diné history. (courtesy LAPAHIE.com)

Remembering the June 1st signing between Diné and the US government, this week's NT edition features a coloring page for all to enjoy. Here's one for you. Ahe'hee to our grandparents for bringing us home.

The following are local events that inadvertently missed publication in this weeks NT edition. Our apologies to the advertisers for this oversight.

4th of July dance schedule
KAYENTA – The Kayenta 4th of July Rodeo country and western dance schedule from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. is as follows: June 28, Aces Wild and Country Troubadours; June 29, Renegade Boyz and Stone Country; July 4, Aces Wild and Hop...i Clansmen; July 5, Stone Country and Hopi Clansmen; and July 6, Aces Wild and Stone Country. Information: www.kayentarodeo.com.

4th of July song and dance
KAYENTA – The District 2 and District 8 Kayenta 4th of July Song and Dance is scheduled Thursday, July 4, at the Monument Valley High School Student Activity Center. Host drum will be Todi Neesh Zhee Singers and master of ceremony will be Albert Nelson Jr. Registration opens at 9 a.m., grand entry begins at 10 a.m. Admission is free. Event is sponsored by Kayenta Township. Information: 928-286-7269.

Fundraiser cakewalk, bingo
MARIANO LAKE, N.M. – A fundraising cakewalk and bingo event will be held Saturday, June 1, at Mariano Lake Chapter at 6 p.m. There will be lots of great prizes and concession will be available. Fundraising event for Zane Charleston heading to Australia Down Under Sports for cross-country. Come out and support one of your own.

Blues dance in Pinon
PINON, Ariz. – The SkoolBoyKook blues dance live at the Pinon District gym will be held Saturday, June 1, from 8-11 p.m. Admission is $5 per person. Event is a fundraiser for the Pinon High School Student Council.

Tohatchi High summer vacation dance
TOHATCHI, N.M. – The summer vacation country and western dance will be held Friday, May 31, at Tohatchi High School. Admission is $10 and $5 re-entry. Concession will be available. Event is a fundraiser for THS Student Council and Business Professionals of America.

Aces Wild in Towaoc
TOWAOC, Colo. – Aces Wild will be playing at Ute Mountain Casino on Sunday, June 2, from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. Admission is $10. Door prizes will be given away. Information: Beverly Lehi, 970-560-9954.
Here's a peek at the news that made front cover for this weeks edition

Navajo Word of the Day- Łééchąą'í

Also shortened to just łééchąą', the Navajo word łééchąą'í refers to domesticated dogs.

This, like many other Navajo words, is intended to be an easy, yet unique, descriptor. So the entire word is saying, in not a vulgar sense, 'the pooping pet.' It is perhaps a remark on the relative lack of discretion on a typical dog's part when "doing business."
link_name: Łééchąą'í - Navajo Word of the Day

Navajo Word of the Day- Át'ahálo

Át'ahálo is a Navajo expression that means "wait!" It's a way of saying, "hold on" or "sit tight" without needing the entire set of conjugated verbs for "to wait."

In speech, it is sometimes shortened to either át'ah or t'ahálo.

The word áłtsé also has a second meaning of "wait" but is primarily used to denote the first in a series of either nouns or actions. So both words can be used in the same sentence (e.g. "Wait, we will eat first.").

Navajo Word of the Day- Łitso

The Navajo word łitso is commonly translated directly as yellow. Whereas the English word is an adjective, in Navajo it is a state. So łitso, as with all other Navajo colors, operates as a verb.

This is why łitso comes at the end of statements. For example, "Chidí éí łitso" is the same thing as "the car is yellow." The word "chidíłtsooí" is "the car that is yellow."

A plural form of this word is daaltso - they (3rd person) are yellow - and is sometimes used instead of the actual thing they are describing. "The yellow ones" can refer, for instance, to the yellow m&ms if they are the only notable yellow objects around.

There is a similar word łitsxo. That extra 'x' forces the word to be pronounced with more force resulting in an amplification of sorts. In this case, it refers, more or less, to an intense yellow, or orange-colored.
link_name: Łitso - Navajo Word of the Day

Navajo Word of the Day- Bą́ą́h ílį́

Bą́ą́h ílį́ is a Navajo expression that means "it is worth" or "it costs".

Together with díkwíí, which denotes a query, you can ask "Díkwíí bą́ą́h ílį́?"  and you would be asking "How much does this cost?" or "How much is this worth?"

Of course, this does not always apply to cost in terms of money. It can be used to denote the cost of a trade, as in "It cost 14 (woven) rugs."

Beyond bą́ą́h ílį́, there is also bą́ą́h azlį́į́' which is the past tense. (When I say past tense, I really mean 'perfective' - which is a way of saying the action was finished, perfected, or completed.) Bą́ą́h azlį́į́' means "it will cost."

Going the other direction in time is bą́ą́h adooleeł, or "it will cost."

Using béeso (money - dollars) as the currency, you can state a price:

Naakits'áadah béeso bą́ą́h ílį́. It costs 20 dollars.

Or, confirm a price using a conditional:

Da' dízdiin béeso bą́ą́h azlį́į́'? Did it cost 40 dollars?
link_name: Navajo Word of the Day

Navajo word of the day- Tóta'

Today's Navajo word is tóta', which means 'in between water'.

Tóta' is also the name for Farmington, New Mexico because the city is situated between bodies of water to its east, south, and west.

This word is made up of tó and -ta' (as in bita').

Tó, which was our word for October 23rd, means water.

The -ta' root is related to another word, bitah - without the abrupt glottal stop - which means 'among it'. Add the glottal stop and the word bita' becomes 'in between it (or them)'.
link_name: Tóta' - Navajo Word of the Day
